Mr Costello interjecting—

PARA.TAB: This strike has been created by Jeff Kennett and the Liberal Party's policies. It is as simple as that. The public of Australia have to know that they will see that transcend nationally if ever they see a Hewson Government in the Commonwealth. They will see exactly the same things happen.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Value Added Tax: Building and Construction Industry

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Treasurer aware of the argument that value added taxes have economic advantages over the traditional types of indirect tax because they are completely visible to the consumer? What advantages does the current Australian taxation system have for the building and construction industries over the alternative proposed by the Opposition?

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order No. 144 part (d) and also part (g). Clearly the honourable member offends against both of those sections of that standing order and you should rule the question out of order or ask him to revise the wording of it.
—Does the honourable member for Bennelong have a point of order?
—No, I was just getting ready for the call in case you ruled the question out of order!

—The honourable member for Bennelong might be a little pre-emptive here. The first part of the question is in order and the second part is not in order. The Treasurer may answer the first part of the question.
—Your time will come, John; your time will come.
—You never tell us anything.
—That is why he is keeping up the pressure on you.

PARA.TAB: Mr Snowdon interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for the Northern Territory will cease interjecting.

—There are those who argue, when they actually get around to arguing, the merits of a value added tax or a GST—a topic upon which the Opposition has gone strangely mute in recent times. This centrepiece of its policy has somehow been disguised in all kinds of other ways. But when they get around to talking about it, they often refer to the fact that it is the transparency of value added taxes which is so important as an argument for introducing them into a country like Australia.

PARA.TAB: Unfortunately, one of the many problems that the Leader of the Opposition has is that he has created a fight with the National Building and Construction Forum over the way in which a value added tax would be applied to that industry. The way in which the Opposition has tried to handle this is to fob it off to the Cole Committee, telling the industry to take all of its questions to that Committee. The Cole Committee is reported as saying that it actually accepts the argument of the industry that the design of the tax as proposed by the Opposition is flawed. But of course the Opposition will take no notice of the Cole Committee.

Sir William Cole has to realise at some point that his Committee has been created as a kind of stunt—a political cul de sac; a blind alley—where all of these questions can be raised, in the words of the Leader of the Opposition, `in the interests of consultation'. But industries never get an opportunity to actually talk to the organ-grinder; they only get an opportunity to talk to Sir William and his pals who all come from the big accounting firms. They never get an opportunity to put their point of view to the architects of this scheme.

The reason why the Opposition has got into this problem is that it wanted to introduce a hidden tax as far as the housing industry was concerned. It did not want to have to confront the fact that home buyers would have GST added to the cost of building a house. So those opposite decided that they would call the housing and construction industry `exempt', hoping that people would think that that meant no GST was applied in that industry. But, as anyone knows, `exempt' Liberal style does not mean exempt. What it means is that the builder has to incur the cost of the GST on the architects' fees and the various inputs which are involved, and which he has to purchase, in the building of a house or a factory. But of course the extra costs that the builder pays get built into the final cost of the house or the factory, but they never actually show up in a way which could identify them as a tax.

What the Leader of the Opposition wanted was a hidden tax in the housing industry. In the process he has created a monster for himself as far as the commercial construction industry is concerned. By making this industry `exempt', even those buildings which are used for commercial and business purposes cannot have the tax deducted but must have that tax reflected in the cost of the building.

Far from this being a transparent tax, far from this being a means by which you can avoid taxes for business, as a result of trying to impose a hidden tax on the housing industry those opposite have created this monster as far as the commercial construction industry is concerned. It is no wonder they are protesting and taking their complaints to the Cole Committee. What they have to work out sooner or later is that the Cole Committee has always been just a ruse, a kind of waste paper basket for all of these too hard problems which the Opposition will not face up to.

—about that particular problem. On this flimsy pretext, the honourable member for Bennelong gets up in here and tries to make a point about the damage to Victoria of what is going on there today. PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Bennelong is frequently keen to refer to the SPC example. He says this is an example of Liberal policy at work. Well, what does the manager of SPC have to say about what Mr Kennett is doing? He is asked:

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

PARA.TAB: Perhaps the real Liberal motivation is disclosed in what Mr Boyle had to say on the television last night. When he was asked about this question of people who might not give up their penalties, he said he would look for someone who would be prepared to give up those penalties because, he said, `I mean, now beggars can't be choosers'. This is the core of Liberal Party policy, to turn working men and women in Australia into beggars—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise.

—into people who must go cap in hand to their employers to see what concessions they can get from their employers, to see what scrapings off the plate they can get from their employers in order to get a return for a fair day's work. Mr Boyle has long been an advocate, a primary adviser of the Liberal Party about its industrial relations policy. He has let the dead cat out of the bag. Of workers he says, `beggars can't be choosers'. In other words, as far as Mr Boyle is concerned, he wants the Liberal policy which will turn decent working men and women into beggars.
—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister.

—Can the Prime Minister advise the House whether he is aware of any recent information confirming that a wide range of companies are using the Government's industrial relations system to introduce more flexible working arrangements?
—Order! There is far too much noise in the chamber. Honourable members on both sides will cease interjecting.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Keating The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend to the House a report of research recently undertaken by the Group Industrial Relations Manager of Shell Australia, Mr John Keily. This research has been published by the Department of Industrial Relations, and I table a copy for honourable members. The study demonstrates clearly that many companies are now using the Government's reforms of the IR system and the cooperative spirit which has been created over the past nine years to make dramatic changes in workplace flexibility.

PARA.TAB: The report articulates some of those changes and explains how they work and how they are undertaken. I mentioned in answer to a question earlier that the changes include continuous 12-hour shifts; loaded base hourly rates to replace penalty time; annualised salaries to incorporate penalty rates, overtime and allowances; flexible working hours; and time off in lieu. Any of the things which our conservative friends opposite might wish for—that is, continuous hourly shifts, the replacement of penalty time by loaded base hourly rates, annualised salaries which incorporate penalty rates—are all there. It can all be done and it is all being done.

What we have seen from the Opposition is not a movement towards enterprise bargaining; it has nothing to do with a bargaining system at all. It has moved to a system of individual contracts which has nothing to do with an enterprise as such or enterprise bargaining. It has moved simply to a system of individual contracts which is not a bargaining system whatsoever; it is a system under which you take the contract or you take the sack.

The honourable member for Bennelong was telling us that he would have an enterprise bargaining system in place. Enterprise bargaining means that people who work in the enterprise come together. They sit down and talk about the enterprise with the managers and together they each come to understand how they could operate the business in a way which improves their income and improves profitability. In other words, they bargain together; they change together; they enterprise bargain. That has gone. What the honourable member for Bennelong wants to give people has nothing to do with enterprise bargaining but a single contract system. Because the only rights you have are common law rights under the master and servant approach, you take the contract or you take the sack.
In the Liberal Party there is now great heartburning about the Victorian Liberals having let the cat out of the bag on all of this. It is reported that in the party room at least one backbencher:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . has openly expressed concern that voter backlash against the tough Kennett reforms will impede the coalition's push for power. Senator Noel Crichton-Browne had used the party room to go on and make these points . . .
Then we had another report which stated:

Senior Opposition front benchers yesterday came under fire in the coalition party room for distancing themselves from the Kennett Government's radical industrial relations policies. Mr Tuckey said he was concerned Mr Kennett was not being given enough support. Those who spoke out in favour of Kennett were Tuckey, Ken Aldred, Michael Ronaldson and Shirley Walters.

On 1 December 1991 he said, `We will be producing a Bill well before the next election'. That is about as far as you can go in filling out the detail. The drafting has been completed and the Industrial Relations Amendment (Voluntary Enterprise Agreements) Bill is being checked with eminent lawyers around the country, a process which will take some weeks. Then, says the Opposition industrial relations spokesman John Howard, the Bill will be made public.

This is a Bill which has a name, which has been drafted and completed, and which has been shown around the law firms for them to check it out. But today we find that, in a debate in Queensland with Mr Dawson Petie, the honourable member for Bennelong said:
Well, we've put out a detailed policy.
Mr Petie said:
The details of the legislation . . .
Mr Howard said:
Look, with great respect, Dawson, when did any government in waiting—when did any Opposition—have the resources or the capacity to produce the actual Bills and the pieces of legislation?
Petie, pretty quick on the uptake, said:
But you've been saying for months that your Bill is in process.
Mr Howard said:

That's right, it's been drafted. And we will not be releasing the Bill, for the very simple reason that without the resources of Parliamentary Counsel to finally advise us on the form and shape, we could easily get something wrong—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is right. That is dead right.

PARA.TAB: Government members—Ooh!

TALK.START.PARA: —that is for sure—

ANSWER.PARA: and then that would become the whole focus of debate rather than the policies.

What we have on the other side of the House is total confusion on industrial relations. Following a promise to give us a Bill that has actually been written and drawn and shown around to eminent counsel to get views about its structure and its force, what do we now find? At the point when the Opposition would logically be displaying its wares if it believed in this policy, it would give us the Bill. `No', says the honourable member for Bennelong, `we will not be releasing the Bill'. We have to ask: `John, why not? What do you have to hide? Are you going to do a Jeff Kennett on us? Are you going to get into the election campaign and promise one thing but, should you ever, unhappily, be a Minister again, promise us something for which you did not have a mandate, for which you had kept secret a more draconian policy?.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that there is only one way that Australia is going to advance, and that is through cooperation. That is the only way. We have come so far, cooperatively, in 10 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, one million unemployed.
—Order!

—The greatest structural change in this economy in a decade is the changed attitude of Australian workers and unionists in a policy of cooperation. I should have thought that the Liberal Party and its front bench would have been part of that change in structure. But no; what do we have? You may think it sounds entertaining, but is it not a sad fact that while they are introducing Bills in the dead of night, without a mandate, to knock off people's penalty rates and holiday leave loadings and to push people onto individual contracts, while they are turning their backs totally on industrial cooperation, they are, in their silliness, getting back into tails, getting out the silver service and paying themselves more money? The Speaker is putting on the wig.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that you are still locked in the early post-war years. You are still locked in the Menzian era. You are still locked in all the old mores of the past. Industrial Australia has moved on. Commercial Australia has moved on. The economy of Australia has moved on.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—But where are you? You are like a bunch of obscurantists wanting to drift back down the time tunnel to the 1950s and the 1960s to these sorts of policies. You say, hairy-chestedly, that you will show us the details of the legislation and you will draw the Bills; you draw the Bills, you complete them and show them to counsel; and now, in your snide trickiness, you will not show the public what is in them. I can only say that the Opposition in this country will lead us down the same path as the Victorian Government, and that is into a policy of deceit, and a policy which will lead to a fracturing of the historic cooperation which has changed the Australian economy as no single event has changed it in the postwar years.

—My question is directed to the Treasurer. In light of the fact that since last Tuesday there has not been one single question without notice on the issue of national unemployment, will the Treasurer assure the Australian people that full employment, rather than zero inflation and technical management of the economy, is the prime objective of the Government? If so, and given the expectation, contrary to Treasury predictions, that unemployment is likely to rise above 11 per cent, what specific initiatives has the Treasurer considered to achieve full employment? Finally, how does the Treasurer respond to the growing number of critics who argue that the globalisation of capital and a reliance on so-called free trade continues to undermine the basis for economic renewal?
—I thank the honourable member for his question. I refer him to a Budget document that was produced at the time of the Budget—
—Can we believe that document?
—Order!

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—which spelt out in very detailed terms what the Government's approach was to maximising employment in Australia. Employment is always the central objective for the Labor Party and for this Government. Employment and maximising employment for Australians are what governments should be about.
—Order! The honourable member for Bradfield!
—This is in sharp distinction with our opponents on the other side who think that the primary objective of government is to get engaged in a $40 billion tax switch—
—Oh, yeah!
—Order!

—which they somehow think is going to be of some benefit to Australia. But as Australia moves into what is inevitably a more competitive world—a world in which I do not think anyone will be given a free ride—it has to concentrate on what are the major issues which are going to set Australians up to be able to compete effectively in the world. Our natural advantages of commodity production, whether it be in agriculture or in mining, are going to be a central part of our continued economic structure. We need to ensure that more of those raw materials are processed here in Australia. You will have heard my colleague the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy talking about this on many occasions.
—Don't talk about him! He doesn't know.
—Order! The honourable member for Bruce will cease interjecting.

—Just in your own State, the decision to provide support for the wool processing industry is just one of many examples which we will see in the years ahead where these high quality, efficiently produced raw materials will be converted with Australian know-how and Australian labour into products which command a higher price on the world stage.

PARA.TAB: The other point where Australia is developing a very distinct advantage is in the skill level of the Australian work force. We have always had a highly skilled work force, but now it is becoming even more highly skilled. We realise that, as the demands of industry become greater, it is crucial that our workers should not only have the opportunity of training when they enter the work force but also should have the opportunity to retrain during their working life. In fact, some American experience suggests that a worker entering the work force now may well expect to change his career or his occupation perhaps seven times during his working life. This means that on every occasion there must be an opportunity for retraining. Of course, it is this policy which the Opposition totally rejects.
It is interesting that one of many ideas that President-elect Clinton has picked up from Australia is the idea that Australian businesses—
Opposition members—Ha, ha!

—You can laugh.

—Order! The House will come to order.

—Last week the Americans conclusively turned their backs on the kinds of policies which you are now putting forward for Australia. You were the ones who were finally caught up with the fashion of the 1980s, just at the time that the rest of the world was rejecting it.
—They voted for change. They voted for change!
—Order! The honourable member for Dundas!

—President-elect Clinton is saying that all American businesses must spend 1 1/2 per cent of their payroll on training. Does that strike a familiar chord? In many other ways, he is recognising what we have recognised: the importance of the investment in education and training and the importance of the investment in science and technology so that we can compete. I just say to the honourable member, because on this issue I disagree with him about whether or not Australia can shield itself from the competitive forces of the world: we need to be able to compete in those areas where we do best, and there are many of them.

PARA.TAB: However, there are people, particularly on the other side, who will run down the character and quality of Australian business and the ability of Australian workers and say that we can never compete, to quote the Leader of the Opposition, or say that we are hopeless, as he says so many times. We are not hopeless. We can compete. We are demonstrating that we can compete, and Australia can be one of those countries that can benefit from the expansion of world trade in a way in which we did not in the 1950s and 1960s. But we have been benefiting in the last decade, as the level of our exports and imports has been going up, as we have been becoming a more fully fledged exporting trading nation; one which can successfully compete with the nations around us, whether in our region or further afield. These are things we need to address in order to maximise our employment opportunities—and these matters are, front and centre, the primary focus of this Government and this Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister confirm that Australia is amongst the lowest taxed countries in the OECD? Why will the Government not introduce a GST so that we can be like everyone else?

—Mr Speaker, an unlikely advocate! It is true that the most recent OECD data for 1990 shows that Australia had the third lowest ratio of taxes to GDP. This is a very lightly taxed country in world terms. It is a record of which this Labor Government is proud because in the context—

PARA.TAB: Mr Anderson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Gwydir!

—of a relatively small public sector we have delivered important advances in this country to social policy to produce a social democratic society which has a first-rate health system, very effective and well targeted social security payments, and a greatly enhanced education system.
—Not nearly enough.
—Order! The honourable member for Goldstein!

—All of these things have come from a small public sector. As well as that, to go with it we have a relatively small public debt. In 1983, public sector debt was 24 per cent of GDP. It had fallen to 13 per cent by 1990, the lowest in the OECD. It has risen at the moment because of the fiscal stimulus provided from the Budget and the impact upon State Budgets. But, again, it is well below the 24 per cent—it is at about 18—which obtained when you were last in office. It has been done not by increasing taxes but by cutting spending. That of course is the quality way, and has been the quality way—not only targeting the system better but also reducing the size of government so as to reduce debt without needing to increase taxes. We do not want to emulate other OECD countries with a higher tax to GDP ratio, but the Opposition does. It wants to increase the tax to GDP level of Australians. Tax to GDP in Australia is 30.8 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Mr Carlton interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Mackellar will cease interjecting.

—For the OECD average as a whole it is 38.8 per cent; 8 percentage points of GDP larger. Most of these countries have consumption taxes. I notice that one of the Liberal Party advertisements reads, `GST. It hasn't worked overseas'; `Yes, it has', says Dr Hewson. `It does work. Look at Germany, Japan. Look at the way New Zealand is bursting out of recession'. Listen to this, it is instructive, `21 of the OECD countries—
—That is right. They are stealing our jobs.
—Order! If the honourable member for Dundas interjects again, I will name him.
—have a successful GST'. Yes, and they have 8 per cent of GDP extra tax. We have 30.8; they have on average 38.8. Twenty-one of them have—
—Look at your White Paper. Nothing of this was in it.
—Order! The honourable member for Bennelong!
—a higher level of tax to GDP as a result of the consumption tax.

PARA.TAB: Dr Kemp interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If the honourable member for Goldstein interjects again, I will name him.

—Of the five lowest taxing countries, Turkey, the United States, Australia, Japan and Switzerland—if we look past the 20-odd and go down to the bottom five; the top one is Sweden at 56.9 and we get down to the bottom five, Switzerland, Japan, Australia, the US and Turkey—three of these countries, Australia, the US and Switzerland, have no value added taxes—none. The only one that has is Japan, which has a modest rate of 4 1/2 per cent. Therefore, one could, I think, reasonably conclude that the 21 successful countries pointed out by Dr Hewson in his GST pamphlet are eight percentage points of GDP more heavily taxed by virtue of the fact that they have a consumption tax—and, of the bottom four, three have no taxes, and we are one of them.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought that was pretty conclusive evidence that the Opposition in this country wants to push us up the OECD tax league table by introducing a consumption tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish! Fightback is about less tax.
—I might add, Mr Speaker—
—You should not dissemble on it.
—I name the honourable member for Dundas.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Beazley) proposed:
That the honourable member for Dundas be suspended from the service of the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Dundas was called upon a number of times to cease interjecting.
—What about the blokes on your side?
—Order! The House will come to order!
—We could not hear. What about the people over there? This is a shambles.
—Order! The House will come to order!
—It is pretty tough.

—Order! The House will come to order. The honourable member for Kooyong will cease interjecting. The honourable member for Dundas has been a member here for a long while and should know, when he is warned like that, that he should not continue to offend. But, because the honourable member for Dundas is not as continual an offender as some of his colleagues, if he wants to apologise, I will withdraw the naming.
—With respect only to the Chair, I withdraw.
—No. We will go through it properly or we will continue. Does the honourable member for Dundas wish to apologise to the Chair for the continual interjections? Is the member wishing to apologise?
—Not at all.
—The question is that the motion be agreed to.
—He has withdrawn.
—Is the member apologising or not?

PARA.TAB: Question put.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Dundas is suspended from the service of the House for 24 hours.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Shame!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call on the Prime Minister to complete his answer, I say to honourable members on both sides—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Oh, both sides!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members on my left will cease interjecting. I say to honourable members on both sides that the rule that has applied here for a long while is that when an honourable member is warned—
—There is no rule.
—Not for that side.

—Order! The honourable member for Corinella will cease interjecting. Honourable members on both sides know that when an honourable member is warned the next step is that the honourable member will be named. Yesterday, the honourable member for Moore was named and was given the opportunity to withdraw, which he did. The honourable member for Dundas was just given that opportunity, which he decided not to take.
—He did withdraw.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to honourable members on both sides that they will ignore a warning at their peril. I call the Prime Minister.

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —We will have order, and we will have it now.

—I was just about to make the point at the time of the honourable member's interjection that, of the 13 countries that introduced a value added tax before the middle 1980s, 10 have increased their rates. Some of these are Austria, which has gone from initial rates of 8 and 16 per cent to 10, 20 and 32 per cent now; Denmark, which has gone from an initial rate of 10 per cent to 22 per cent; Germany, which initially had 5 and 10 per cent and has gone to 7 and 14 per cent; the Netherlands, which originally had 4 and 12 per cent and is now at 6 and 18 1/2 per cent; New Zealand, which has had a GST only since 1986 and has already increased it from 10 to 12.5 per cent; and, of course, the United Kingdom, which initially was at 10 per cent and is now at 17.5 per cent. These statistics prove that the bulk of the countries which have consumption taxes have a tax to GDP ratio eight percentage points of GDP higher than those which do not.

PARA.TAB: In seeking to emulate those countries, as the Leader of the Opposition seeks to do in this pamphlet of his, he is in my view about increasing the rate of tax. In this pamphlet he says that New Zealand is bursting its way out of recession. I just make this final point: the fact is that it is five years since New Zealand introduced a GST, and over that period employment has fallen by almost 6 per cent. I make this point: this country does not need Dr Hewson's goods and services tax, this country does not want Dr Hewson's goods and services tax, and I am quite sure this country will not get Dr Hewson's goods and services tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister. You said yesterday that the next election would be a referendum on the GST. We would, of course, be happy to fight you on tax reform anywhere, any day.

PARA.TAB: Government members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order. Honourable members on my right will cease interjecting.
—Name them! Name them!
—Order! The House will come to order. I warn the honourable member for Gippsland.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Members of the Opposition will cease interjecting.

—I ask the Prime Minister: why should the Australian people not also treat the next election as a referendum on the worst recession in 60 years, a referendum on one million unemployed, a referendum on record bankruptcies, a referendum on record debt, a referendum on one in four families without anyone in work, and a referendum on a collapsing health and education system?

PARA.TAB: Opposition members—Hear, hear!
Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise.
—It is very interesting to watch the Leader of the Opposition run away from the policy he says Australia most needs.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—It is very interesting to hear him say, as he was saying so cockily a year ago, `This is the policy Australia needs, this is the policy Australia will have, and I am proud to be proposing it'. He is now offlaying it. Like a bookie offlaying a bet, he is offlaying the punt on his policy and now wants to have every matter brought under scrutiny other than the policies which he is proposing. I do not wonder that the Leader of the Opposition is now trying to lay off his policy on everybody else—

PARA.TAB: Mrs Bailey interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for McEwen!
—because he does not have the courage to stand by the thing he says will change Australia forever.
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: it might be nice if the Prime Minister addressed the question.
—Order! That is not a point of order. The honourable member for La Trobe will resume his seat.

—I noticed that the Leader of the Opposition said in his preface that he would stand against us on tax reform. Well, you were not too sharp when you were around, were you? When you and the honourable member for Bennelong were running the system, what did you have? The Taxation Commissioner—poor old Bill O'Reilly—wrote you the famous telephone book of letters saying, `Treasurer, will you please do something about the criminal haemorrhaging of the tax system'.
—Answer the question.
—Order!

—There was letter after letter for years until you were finally exposed by the McCabe-Lafranchi report which was set up as basically a scam into the Ship Painters and Dockers Union. They went to the ship painters and dockers and found that basically the real scam was the criminal haemorrhaging of the tax system committed under the honourable member for Bennelong while he was the principal economic adviser for the Government. And you are going to go us on tax reform! In a country which has now the third lowest tax in the OECD—

PARA.TAB: Mr Carlton interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Mackellar will cease interjecting.
—which has amongst the lowest government debt to GDP ratio in the OECD—

PARA.TAB: Mr Howard interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Bennelong will cease interjecting.

—and which has a government which has put a suture on capital gains taxation, which has taxed fringe benefits, which has taken away the tax rorts, which has reduced the top marginal rate from 60 under the honourable member for Bennelong to 47 under Labor, which has reduced the corporate rate from 49 to 39 per cent and introduced full dividend imputations, which has reduced the rate of tax on distributed income for companies from 78c in the dollar to 47c or an undistributed income from 78c to 39c—half—you are going to give us a run on tax reform? We have made a range of other changes to make the tax system work properly. We have done it, of course, with the support of an ambitious tax administration and a courageous Tax Commissioner, who for his trouble has been berated as the Government's poodle by the honourable member for Bennelong. He has been attacked in the Senate. After a lifetime of dedicated service and lifting the tax administration of Australia to one of the best in the Western world, he is attacked as though he is now sanctioning government policy in support of personal benefits for himself. This is where you are on taxation and taxation policy.

PARA.TAB: The other little lark I noticed in the honourable member's preface was about the one million unemployed. He forgets the 600,000 he left us in 1983. He has conveniently forgotten the 600,000 he lumped on our back as we had to carry it through the 1980s, in which we brought down unemployment to around 6 per cent, to find it has now risen by about 400,000 people, unfortunately.

Which party is doing the most to restore growth in employment in the economy? The Government. Which party is advocating a $7 billion cut to the Budget deficit? The Opposition. Which party is running against the international trend in cooperation, stimulating the economy and economic growth? The Australian Opposition. They are the people doing that. This is the only side of the House which will do something about unemployment.
Opposition members—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—You have to have some front, have you not? You were a principal macro-economic adviser to the Treasurer from 1976 to 1983. If we compare those seven years with the first seven years under Labor, we had five times as much employment growth as the Leader of the Opposition was able to manage with Treasurer Howard in their seven years in office. That is their record on employment. In 1983 Australia had a labour market of six million people. Today it has a labour market of nearly eight million people—it is nearly 25 per cent larger. In New Zealand, which you keep telling us about, they have fewer people in work today than they had in 1983.

PARA.TAB: If the Leader of the Opposition wants to tell us that the GST is the policy that Australia needs—it is the policy which requires a tough guy like him to put into place—that is fine; let him tell us that. Then this election will be brought down to that central fact. We want it to be a referendum on the GST. A vote for Hewson will be a vote for a GST; a vote for me and the Labor Party will be a vote never to see a GST introduced into this country. That is the hard central fact of politics in Australia at this moment and the Leader of the Opposition is squirming at the choice.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation: Rural Research

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy aware of an article in today's Australian newspaper headed `Crean may dump CSIRO in rural policy'? Will he inform the House whether this is correct? If it is not, what is the Government's approach to rural research?

—I have seen the report in the Australian today and it is not correct. I have no intention of dumping the CSIRO from rural policy, nor of excluding the CSIRO from the most senior decision making bodies in so far as it affects agricultural policy in this country. The report itself is based on a paper which has been circulated by officials to Ministers in the Commonwealth as a result of my combining three ministerial councils into one to try to get more strategic and integrated management so far as our natural resource base is concerned. That paper asks Ministers to do no more than consider a range of options.

PARA.TAB: But so far as my position is concerned, my intention is to involve the CSIRO as fully as possible in policy formulation. The real task for the new structure coming forward is how best to achieve that. That is not just my commitment; it is also my track record. I remind the House—and in particular the honourable member for Fraser—that when I had the previous portfolio of science and technology I argued successfully that the CSIRO should be involved in the policy formulation aspect of our response to ESD.

So far as the Government's commitment to rural research and development is concerned, I remind the House that we reaffirmed that commitment in the last Budget whereby we maintained the expenditures in terms of rural research and development despite the speculation that was running around at the time. We, as a government, did have to face up to some tough economic decisions, but one thing we did not cut was rural research and development because we saw it as an investment in the future not as something which had to be cut to try to get the figures right.

At the time there was a lot of outcry from the other side when there were suggestions that we were going to cut this rural research and development. One interesting comment came from the honourable member for Lowan, in the Victorian Parliament, Mr Bill McGrath. He slammed what he said was the `Federal Government's preparedness to slash rural research and development'. Who is Bill McGrath today? He is the Minister for Agriculture in the Victorian Government, and he has that headline against him in a Herald and Weekly Times publication last week. That is the Victorian Government's position. It is prepared to criticise us over a speculation of slashing research and development, but it is into the cutting of research and development up to its neck.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is irrelevant.
—It is not irrelevant.
—Yes, it is.
—Order!
—Well, that is the truth.
—Order! The honourable member for MacKellar!
—You shut up.
—Order! The Minister will withdraw that remark.
—I withdraw. But I get a bit annoyed when people assert irrelevance—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Earlier you ruled that the honourable member for Dundas should withdraw and apologise. Why do you not make the honourable member for Hotham apologise?
—The Minister withdrew.
—Why do you not apply the same rule to the other side as you apply to this side?
—Resume your seat. The Minister was asked to withdraw and the Minister withdrew.

PARA.TAB: Mr Carlton interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Mackellar has already been warned once. He will not interject again.

—For the benefit of the honourable member who interjected, the relevance of this is that we have heard today from members of the Government here that the Liberal Government in Victoria promised that it would not do things in the lead-up to the election, yet before the ink was dry in terms of swearing in its members, it was about reversing that policy. I simply say this: what the people of this country have to recognise and vote on is the track record and the performance. They cannot rely on the promises of those opposite because their promises will not be delivered.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order under standing order 145. The Minister was asked whether he intended to exclude the CSIRO from decision-making bodies. He answered that question and went on to totally irrelevant material.
—The Minister was asked about rural policy-making bodies. The Minister will answer the question.

—The second part of the question related to the Governmnt's intention concerning rural research and development. I listen; apparently you do not. Let me go on to say that it is not only the Victorian Government that has reneged on a promise on the continuation of rural research and development; the Tasmanian Government has also reneged on certain things it promised in the lead-up to the election, or at least it led people to believe that it would not be making cuts. It is now being criticised by farm groups all over that State because it has introduced a Budget cutting $2.5m off rural research and development.
—They lied. They lied.
—If the honourable member for Denison interjects again, I will deal with him.

—There were statements from the Deputy Leader of the National Party criticising this Government for speculation that we would cut research and development, but we have not heard a whimper concerning rural research and development in the States, which is complementary to underpinning the future of our rural industries.

PARA.TAB: I make this point in conclusion: our Government is committed to underpinning the future of rural industries in this country. Rural research and development is an important component of that. We will maintain our commitment to it. Whatever they are saying now, those opposite will ditch it, as they have ditched everything else as soon as they get the chance of government. I do not believe they will be given that chance federally, but people ought to be aware of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Does the Minister claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do indeed.
—The Minister may proceed.

—On 5 November, the honourable member for McEwen (Mrs Bailey) made a number of allegations in the grievance debate to the effect that I had failed to investigate complaints about the safety of a certain type of bicycle helmet and was therefore allowing the lives of children to be endangered.
—I raise a point of order. This is not the first opportunity the Minister has had to make a personal explanation. That time has long passed and I ask you to rule accordingly.
—Order! The Minister can make a personal explanation.

—I now table documents—and this is the first opportunity that I have had to do so—that show that not only are these allegations false but also action to investigate the complaints referred to was prompt and thorough.
