INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The consequences for the Australian public generally and the further pain, hardship and economic dislocation being inflicted on the Victorian public in particular today through the irresponsible strike.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those who from day to day may observe the proceedings of this House may well have thought that, on past occasions, the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has reached fairly dizzy heights of hyperbole and exaggeration. But I think even the most studious Keating watchers would have recognised that today, the Prime Minister scaled Himalayan heights of hyperbole and exaggeration with the things that he had to say, not only about taxation, industrial relations, employment and the economic management of this country, but most particularly about the record of the Government of which he has been a major member, and now the Leader, for a period of almost 10 years.

PARA.TAB: I do not think any statement that I have heard from the Prime Minister could quite equal the remarkable claim he made today. He falsely alleged that the Keating-Halfpenny strike which is now hurting a pain afflicted and pain ridden Victoria—and it is a Keating-Halfpenny strike—
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—The honourable member for Bennelong will refer to the Prime Minister by his appropriate title.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am using that term in an adjectival sense. I repeat: it is a strike which the Prime Minister of Australia has aided and abetted.
—Order! The honourable member for Bennelong will resume his seat.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, are you saying that I cannot—
—The honourable member for Bennelong will resume his seat.
—On what basis?
—I warn the honourable member for Bennelong.
—I invite you—
—I warn the honourable member for Bennelong. He will resume his seat or I will name him.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, will you please explain your ruling?
—The honourable member for Bennelong quite well knows that the rule of the Parliament is that honourable members are referred to by their appropriate title.
—There is no such thing as a Keating Government? What about `a Keating Government'?
—The honourable member for Bennelong will accept the ruling and proceed.
—I accept the ruling. I do not want my time wasted.

PARA.TAB: Mr Reith interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member for Flinders will remain silent.

—I will deal with that issue later. I will accept it. There is not the slightest doubt in the eyes of any objective observer of the Australian scene that the Keating Government is aiding and abetting the strike that is now going on in Victoria. If it were not for the benediction and the blessing given by the Prime Minister in Question Time today, a blessing which has been given on earlier occasion, that strike would not be going ahead in Victoria. It is the rankest piece of hypocrisy for anybody, and most particularly the Prime Minister of this country, to dare to say, to have the unbelievable nerve and gall to say, that the mess in which Victoria is now finding itself is the fault of the Liberal Party and the newly elected coalition Government.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister talks about `how far we have come in 10 years'. That has to be the sickest and sorriest joke that anybody has ever tried to play on the long suffering people of Victoria. No State has suffered more under a State Labor government or a State government of any political complexion in Australia at any time this century than the people of Victoria have suffered under the Labor governments of the last 10 years. When the history of Victoria is written and there is a proper accounting with the passage of time of what has really happened in Victoria and in Australia over the last few years, the black marks against State governments will be at their densest and blackest when one examines the records of Victorian governments over the last 10 years.

I have to say, as I have said before, that all of those people who have been associated with what has happened in Victoria, from John Cain through to the present Prime Minister of Australia, be it remembered, counselled and procured the support of Joan Kirner, John Halfpenny and Wally Curran for the Prime Minister to become the Prime Minister of Australia. They stood behind him. They became conspirators with him to undermine Bob Hawke. He did not care about what they were doing to Victoria. He was only interested in what they were prepared to do to Bob Hawke. He did not care about the pain they have inflicted on the people of Victoria; yet he has the gall, the nerve, the hide, the cheek to come into this Parliament, with all the false indignation that only a prime hypocrite can muster, and to say, `Jeff Kennett and the newly elected Victorian Government are declaring war on the people of Victoria'.

The people of Victoria have been subjected to the most heavy aerial bombardment that anyone has ever been subjected to by the Labor Party in Victoria over the last 10 years—I will say it again: anybody who has been associated with what has happened in Victoria over the last 10 years—where the likes of Kirner, Halfpenny, Curran, Cain and all the other friends of the Prime Minister, have literally laid waste to that State systemically and ruthlessly. They have ransacked their public finances; they have decimated the morale of their Public Service; they have destroyed the confidence base of the small business sector; and they have driven the State into the hands of the international pawnbrokers. Yet you characters opposite have got the nerve to try to put the blame for this strike on Jeff Kennett. It is well known that on odd occasions Jeff and I have not always agreed, but on this particular occasion I think Jeff Kennett deserves the 100 per cent support of this Parliament.
Opposition members—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —He deserves it because what he has done is to implement an industrial relations policy for which he has received a mandate. Let me go to this question of mandate. There is a reason why the Prime Minister is lining up with the Labor Party, with the trade unions and with John Halfpenny and Wally Curran in Victoria, and there is a reason why I can properly describe this as a strike that has been blessed, approved and given the benediction of the Prime Minister. The industrial relations Bill of the Kennett Government is not seen by members of the Labor Party as an attack on the living standards of the people of Victoria. The reason they do not like this Bill is pure and simple: this Bill takes away privileges from the trade union bosses of Australia. That is the real reason they do not like this Bill.

PARA.TAB: This Bill does not attack the living standards. The living standards of Victorians have been ravaged for the last 10 years. There is nothing left to attack. Do those opposite not understand that that State is in such bankruptcy that there is absolutely nothing left to destroy; there is nothing left to waste any more? Labor has done the job completely and comprehensively. Yet those opposite still have the nerve to stand up here and indignantly try to shift the blame onto somebody else.

Reasonable men and women opposite know the real reason why they cannot stomach this Bill. It has got nothing to do with the holiday loading—the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) said on the Sunday program that that was trivial—it has got nothing to do with penalty rates because, according to the Victorians, they are now reverting to what was stated before the election. This Bill dismantles legal privileges the trade union movement has that no other section of the Australian community has.

TALK.START.PARA: —Special privileges.

—Special privileges, special perks and special rorts under the legal system that nobody else has. That is the reason why this is sticking in the craw of those opposite. That is the reason why the Prime Minister told the Caucus this morning that the broad labour movement had no alternative but to try to confront what the Government was doing in Victoria.

PARA.TAB: If those opposite had any semblance of appreciation of the national interest, the last thing they would be doing at the moment is counselling and procuring what could turn into a general strike. The reality is that the Prime Minister is delighted that there is a strike in Victoria. He is hoping and praying that, out of the confusion, the chaos, the inevitable pain, the inevitable dislocation and the further economic loss that Victorian families will suffer, he will not get blamed and the Kennett Government and the Federal coalition will get blamed.

Let me say to the Prime Minister: we are alive to that strategy. We know that the Prime Minister does not give a damn about the welfare of the people of Victoria; we know that he has a maximum, vested political interest in chaos and industrial unrest in Victoria. The Prime Minister wants there to be trouble on the streets of Victoria because he thinks that it might repay him a political dividend.

That is the Prime Minister's strategy. He wants the people of Victoria to be further hurt, in the hope that they might believe him when he says that it is Kennett's fault and it is the fault of the Liberals; it is not the fault of the Labor Party. But the Australian people who live in Victoria are not that stupid. They know that before the 1988 election they were lied to by Cain and his crew about the VEDC. They know what Cain has done and what Kirner did to the Victorian economy. They know the mess in which the Victorian economy was left. They know that Victoria has a debt of $62 billion. They know that unemployment is worse in Victoria than it is anywhere else. They know that every household in Victoria will suffer years of pain before things are put right economically.

Government members should not imagine that, out of the industrial chaos and the social disharmony which they hope will overwhelm Victoria, they can gain some political advantage. That, plainly, is the political strategy of the Keating Government. The political strategy of the Keating Government is to hope and pray and do everything it can to provoke the maximum amount of industrial turmoil and industrial unrest in Victoria, and Australia, over the next few months in the hope of saying, `There, it's all the fault of the Liberals'.

What a disgraceful approach for a man who claims to unite and lead a nation in its worst recession in 60 years! What a contemptible attitude for a man who claims to be the leader of a political party that sticks up for the ordinary working men and women of Australia! What care does he have for the ordinary working men and women of Australia that he would actually follow a course of action that could inflict more pain, more damage, more unemployment, more debt, higher taxation, and greater family and human misery on them? That is the measure of the Himalayan hypocrisy of this man who comes in here parading as the leader of a party which is the only side in politics that is doing anything about the unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are doing it all right.

—They are doing it all right. Government members talk about the Great Depression. I say to those opposite: the only thing about the Great Depression which is replicated in Australia today is the level of unemployment that you blokes have produced. The party of the working men and women of Australia has given us the worst unemployment since the years of the Great Depression. The self-proclaimed party of the working men and women of Australia has driven this country into worse debt than it has experienced at any time over the last 60 years.

PARA.TAB: Labor's offshoot and manifestation in Victoria over the last 10 years set about a systematic undermining of the financial institutions of that State. In a decade, the pride of the people of Melbourne was destroyed, attacked and undermined by this Government. Those of us who have visited that city over the years could only lament the terrible fate that had befallen a wonderful city that had enormous civic pride. Labor's hopeless mismanagement wounded and weakened the spirit of those people. But their spirit is not so weakened and wounded, they are not so stupid and so deceived, that they will not be able to see through what Labor is doing and what it has done.

A few weeks ago the people of Victoria voted overwhelmingly to throw out the Labor Party. They voted in full knowledge that the incoming Liberal Government was going to reform the industrial relations system. For five weeks they heard Labor talk about the darkness and industrial debt that would befall Victoria if there were a change of government. They heard all its ranting and misrepresentation, and all its distortion about the slashing of living standards and the breaking down of basic conditions. Having heard all of that, they rejected every single thing that Labor had to say about industrial relations and voted overwhelmingly to install a coalition government in Victoria.

No amount of peripheral argument about a penalty rate here or there, or a holiday loading over there, will alter the fact that what they voted for is what they are now getting. By every application of the principle of a political mandate, the Kennett Government has a right to do what it is now doing. My advice to Government members is that, if they have any sense of self-respect, they should, along with Joan Kirner, Wally Curran and John Halfpenny, go away and hide behind a rock for a couple of years, because by then they might have some right to re-emerge and re-enter the political debate in Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—I call the Minister for Finance.

TALK.START.PARA: —Apologise, Ralph.
—Order! The honourable member for Higgins!
—Apologise for Joan Kirner, Ralph!
—Order! The honourable member for Higgins!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only interesting element in that quarter of an hour speech by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) was that perhaps there was a portent for the future in his speech, in that whilst he was speaking the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) was sitting on the back bench. Maybe there is more portent in that symbolism than in anything he actually said.

PARA.TAB: The speech by the honourable member for Bennelong was just empty rhetoric and absolutely devoid of any substantial analysis of the issues. I understand that today over 100,000 people have massed in Melbourne to protest against the legislation brought in by the Kennett Government—legislation which goes far beyond that which they sought a mandate for during the election campaign and which enormously damages the rights and the conditions of employment of Victorian working people. Let there be no doubt about that.

This is not just a piece of legislation which is an interesting sideline or some minor change in the industrial scene. This is a fundamental attack on the rights and the conditions of employment of working people in Victoria. For the honourable member for Bennelong to say that it is about the special privileges and the rorts of the trade union leaders shows that he knows absolutely nothing about what is in the legislation; either that or he is trying to grossly mislead the House in relation to what is in this legislation.

Let me tell the House what is in fact in this legislation. Firstly, it imperils the basic conditions of employment of Victorian working people by depriving them of award coverage unless the employer agrees. They cannot have an award, after 1 March next year, unless the employer agrees that they can continue in an award. So they are entirely at the mercy of the employer. The legislation removes weekend penalty rates and holiday leave loadings from awards without that having been mentioned prior to the election. The legislation provides for individual contracts that contain lower than award conditions, except for a few basic elements. So it means that an employee can be forced, on the threat of the sack, by an employer into an individual contract, which greatly diminishes the standard of conditions of employment that prevailed under the previous award situation. That is of direct enormous concern to many people.

It will be particularly true of people who are the most in need of protection, the people who are in the weakest bargaining positions, who will tend to be the lower paid. Those people are going to be open to exploitation under this system which is exactly the position that is being pursued by the Opposition at a Federal level. There is also no provision in this legislation for any future review of minimum wages. So although the legislation says, `You can take your award wages into the individual contract', it provides no basis for any adjustment of that award in the future. It is just frozen in time and rots away in real terms.

They are the matters that relate to the basic conditions of employment, but the legislation also gives the employer the whip hand in developing individual contracts. Any system which says that each individual employee has to negotiate with an employer obviously means that the bargaining power is greatly transferred to the employer. What bargaining power does the school leaver have with any employer, even if it is only a milk bar proprietor, let alone some major company—as though there could be some meaningful negotiation? It is an absurdity and an affront to any sort of reasonable conclusion.

Nevertheless, the basic assumption which underlies this legislation is that there can be some sensible bargain, but of course there cannot. But just to make sure that the employees are further disadvantaged, this legislation states that there will be no requirement for employers to recognise an employee's bargaining representative. So an employee might say, `I want this union to represent me'. The employer does not have to recognise that union, let alone bargain with it. The employer does not have to do anything like that. There is no requirement for the employer to recognise or bargain with the employee's nominated representative. There is also no protection for employees against harsh or oppressive contracts, or the procurement of contracts by harsh and oppressive means.

Both of those points are elements of the New Zealand legislation on which this legislation is modelled, but they are not in the Victorian legislation. It means that employees in Victoria can clearly be much more open to exploitation than is the case in New Zealand. Remarkably, it also enables the inclusion in contracts or awards of a provision requiring employees to pay the employer a sum of money if, in the opinion of the employer, the employee's behaviour, attendance or obedience is unsatisfactory. Can honourable members imagine a requirement in legislation that an employer can put into a contract a provision which enables him to fine the employee because he does not like the employee's behaviour or does not like the way the employee reacts in regard to some order he has been given? At his discretion, the employer can have in the contract, which he has obtained under the threat of the sack, some provision to fine the employee. What an extraordinary, outrageous provision! It is one which the honourable member for Bennelong and the Opposition support. They say they are 100 per cent behind Jeff Kennett.

Further, this legislation virtually completely outlaws any industrial action. Any industrial action during the term of an award or collective agreement is unlawful, for starters. Secondly, any industrial action in essential industries is outlawed. The legislation declares that essential industries are such things as transport, power, fuel and so on. Then it says that industrial action is outlawed in vital industries. What is a vital industry? It is any industry that the legislation declares to be a vital industry. It could be the ice cream manufacturing industry. It could be any industry at all which the Victorian Government can declare to be a vital industry, and then there is no right to take any industrial action whatsoever. It is an extraordinary provision.

Then the legislation, in respect of both essential industries and vital industries, where industrial action is outlawed, makes no provision for conciliation or arbitration. So the employees in those industries are, under this legislation, totally and absolutely subject to the whim of the employer. They cannot take industrial action; they cannot go to arbitration. Has anyone ever seen anything more oppressive and undemocratic than this absurd, bloody legislation which the Victorian Government is putting to the people of Victoria? And it is wondering why there are people demonstrating in the streets! It is absolutely extraordinary legislation. Those opposite should be ashamed of themselves for supporting it. This is their hidden agenda too.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order—

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Ronald Edwards)—I will deal with it. I suggest to the Minister that he used an adjective which he probably did not need to use in the context.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw the adjective, Mr Deputy Speaker. Furthermore, if after all that there is some little crack of light, if there is some industry in which people can actually take some industrial action, there is another provision which says that if it causes damage to a third party it is unlawful. Industrial action almost necessarily, if it is effective, does some damage to a third party. But, if it has that effect, then it is unlawful. In effect the Victorian Government is completely wiping out any effective industrial action anywhere. It is saying to the working people of Victoria, `You have no right to take any industrial action in any real circumstance'. That is what this legislation says.

PARA.TAB: If, despite all that, the employees are able to find some area in which they can still take industrial action—it beggars one's imagination wondering where that would be—the legislation says they firstly have to have a secret ballot. The secret ballot can authorise only five days of industrial action within a 28-day period from the close of the ballot. It means that after every five days of industrial action there has to be another ballot, which is obviously very restrictive. The legislation also says that each ballot paper must include the statement—I ask the House to listen to the statement which goes on this ballot paper, and which must be there under the law—`If you take part in a strike or other industrial action, you may be in breach of your contract of employment'. What an incredible, intimidatory provision that is to try to ensure that the ballot comes out against any industrial action. It says, `No comment on or qualification of this statement is permissible'. So people are not allowed to put anything on the ballot paper which might in any way say something about that statement that must be there.

The whole thing is massively loaded against the employees in favour of the employers. It is all about massive power transfer to the employers of the State of Victoria. There are penalties for industrial action. For breach of an employment contract, the court can award a penalty against an individual employee of no more than $5,000. This is not a small amount, but it certainly seems to be open to the interpretation that each day may be a separate breach, so people could get fined $5,000 every day.

There are no limits for breach of an award. There is no protection against contractual action for illegal industrial action following the expiration of a collective industrial agreement. There is no protection against the claims for damages in tort resulting from unlawful industrial action. So people can still have very substantial common law action taken against them.

On top of all of that there are criminal penalties. To take industrial action is a crime—like robbing a bank, pinching a car, and so on. On top of all of the other things, it becomes a crime. A criminal penalty of $1,000 for the first offence, $2,000 for the second and $3,000 for third and subsequent offences applies. This is for individuals and, of course, for unions the penalty is $50,000. That can apply not just to an individual who takes industrial action, but to anyone who aids, counsels, or attempts to induce an employee into unlawful industrial action.

What an extraordinary provision; one which goes totally against our international obligations as much as the rest of this legislation does. This legislation is an extraordinarily savage attack on the rights and conditions of employment of Victoria's employees. It is utterly without rationale given Victoria's industrial dispute record. In the period of the Fraser Government, Victoria had a level of industrial disputation above that of Australia—about 16 per cent above it. Since then industrial action across Australia has come down by 61 per cent. In Victoria it has come down by 74 per cent. The level of industrial disputation in Victoria is the second lowest of any State.

People would think that it was some sort of industrial madhouse in which people were running riot and causing the whole Victorian economy to crack up by crazy industrial action. That is anything but the case. The whole nation has gone through an industrial relations transformation, but Victoria even more so than the rest, except for South Australia. Yet Victoria is being treated as though it was an industrial relations madhouse, and as though the unions had to be belted into submission when, in fact, they have been behaving on the whole with an unprecedented degree of reasonableness compared with historical behaviour.

This legislation is considerably more repressive than the New Zealand legislation on which it is clearly based. I will not go into the details of that but, on a whole variety of fronts, it is much more repressive than the New Zealand legislation. It is in blatant breach of ILO conventions—conventions 87 and 98—to which Australia is a signatory. The Opposition and the honourable member for Bennelong apparently do not give a damn about breaking our obligations to the ILO. They would say, `Let us go along, ratify these treaties and sign them all. It does not mean anything—it is just some place in Geneva. It does not mean anything at all'. But we would be in blatant breach on a host of fronts with this legislation. Victoria would put the nation in breach of our ILO conventions.

We are seeing Victoria being turned into some kind of an industrial police state. It is a disgrace that any member of the Opposition can stand up in this place and support this kind of extraordinary action by the Victorian Government. And the Opposition is in full support of it; let there be no doubt about that.

The Victorian Government has admitted that it broke its pre-election pledge. Mr Gude was reported in the Herald-Sun on 2 November as saying that there was `no question' that the State Government had broken its promise. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: That is the case, and I don't walk away from it at all.
The honourable member for Bennelong was quoted in the same article as saying:
What is my observation is what is in the bill on penalty rates and holiday loadings is not the same as what they said before the election.

He said that he agrees that there is no mandate for some of this stuff anyway. Yet he still gets up and says, `Well, they have got a mandate. Let us support it'. A week ago he was saying that the Victorian Government did not have a mandate. The honourable member for Bennelong should make up his mind about what he really believes. He is really saying to this country, `This is our agenda. This is what we believe'. That is what he said at the weekend. An article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 7 November stated:

PARA.TAB: Mr Howard strongly reiterated his support for the "main thrust" of the Victorian industrial relations reforms, saying they were largely in line with his own.

SPEECH.PARA: He said he had no criticisms of any area of the Victorian legislation— (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say to honourable members in the House, to the people in the gallery and to those listening over prime time radio that that was an absolutely incomprehensible diatribe by an ex-Minister for Industrial Relations, the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis). He now supposedly heads Finance for this once great nation. Honest to goodness, if that is the best we can do it is no wonder we will have a change of government whenever this failed Prime Minister (Mr Keating) decides to call the election.

PARA.TAB: We are here today to talk about a matter of immense public importance; that is, the unconscionable strike in the now devastated State of Victoria. This is a political strike. It is not an industrial strike. It is not a strike about matters of wages or conditions of employment. It is not a go-slow. It is not a black ban. It is not any kind of industrial action taken because safety laws have been violated. It is well and truly a political strike organised by the head of the Victorian Trades Hall Council, John Halfpenny, who is a mate and supporter of our Prime Minister. It is also supported by Mr Wally Curran, also a mate of our Prime Minister. It seems to me that this political strike is a pay-off for the ACTU Secretary, Mr Bill Kelty. Mr Kelty was a confidante of the Prime Minister and assisted him to get rid of the then honourable member for Wills.

The current honourable member for Wills (Mr Cleary), who is in the House today, comes in for a bit of chop too. I saw a picture of him in the paper this week. He was standing in front of a public rally in the State of Victoria encouraging the citizens to rise against the just elected Victorian Government, elected with a mandate to rule. He says, `Rise up; throw off the shackles—class war, my friends'. That is the new honourable member for Wills, who replaced our ex-Prime Minister, who in turn was replaced by the current Prime Minister. Now Bill Kelty is getting his pay-off.

The hardworking decent men and women in Victoria are the ones who are being used by John Halfpenny, Bill Deller and Jennie George of the ACTU. They are being used for the ends of their political masters, who are the union movement. This strike is about monopoly union power. I remind honourable members that we have no monopoly rights when it comes to goods and services in this country. We do everything possible to make sure that companies are not in a monopoly position. We do not have price fixing; we have never had successful price fixing, except in the industrial arena where we allow the unions to represent employees. Whether or not employees wish to be represented, whether or not they are members of unions, we allow the unions total control over the fixing of the price of wages and over the conditions of employment for everyone in this country.

The Kennett Government, under Phil Gude, has brought down its legislation in the State of Victoria over the last few days. It received a mandate from the Victorian people on 3 October. We in Victoria live in a truly decimated State. We have over 300,000 unemployed, yet these union leaders have the audacity to call honest working men and women to strike against their government and their honest employers. A release in the last few minutes by Mr David Edwards, of the Victorian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, says:

SPEECH.PARA: "Trades Hall and the State Opposition are deliberately running a campaign of mis-information, but this will create a tremendous backlash on the union movement when employees understand the real contents of the Employee Relations Bill," . . .
He says workers are already beginning to understand that the legislation will not have the impact Trades Hall is predicting.

My understanding is that the turnout in the strike today was abysmal. Lots of public servants hit the street, but public servants feel that they are under attack today. They are in a highly unionised sector. I remind honourable members that, were it not for the high rate of union membership in the public sector, Australia would have an overall union membership of only 30-odd per cent.

PARA.TAB: But the private sector rejected the call of John Halfpenny and it rejected this strike today because it understands that the strike is about power. It is about John Halfpenny trying to continue to have the power he held over Joan Kirner for the past few years—a power which meant that every piece of legislative reform that she knew she had to implement was denied. Halfpenny and all the union officials on the Left pulled the strings to prevent any reform, which today has left us with this massive debt situation.

We can talk about the Victorian loans scandal. We can talk about our Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) trying to hide from that because he was afraid Joan Kirner would lose. I tell this House that we will live with the effects of that for many a long year.

In this Parliament we now have some legislation about endangered species. I reckon that the dinosaurs, the John Halfpennys of this world, are the endangered species because when the Victorian public wakes up to the operation of that industrial relations legislation and the freedom and opportunity it will give individuals to negotiate with their employers for fair working conditions, for good wages and for modern enterprise agreements that will allow work forces to be effective, productive and play a real part in the development of our economy, then the workers will gravitate to enterprise agreements in a great rush.

The Prime Minister tries to make out that we have all the flexibility in the system that anyone could want. And, yes, there are some good agreements being struck today; but they are being struck with the agreement and help of sensible, modern-thinking unions—not the dinosaurs of this world like John Halfpenny and Wally Curran, and not the Jennie Georges of this world. I remind honourable members that last night on Lateline Jennie George talked of the award system as a safety net. It is not a safety net; it is a security blanket.

The award system which we have lived with for almost 90 years has left us in the position where our productivity is the laughing stock of the world. We talk of our competitiveness but this year, as I recall, Australia rated 16th out of 17 nations, according to the OECD—and our competitiveness is going down; it is certainly not increasing. We need flexibility. Even the Prime Minister and the Minister for Finance, who gave such an incomprehensible speech earlier, have talked about needing increased productivity, and they have said that their system will give it to us.

The system has not given it to us: we have over one million unemployed in this country and over 300,000 unemployed in the State of Victoria. Talk about flexibility! We are talking about a dinosaurian system that has constrained businesses and enterprises, which has closed down those people who would be innovative and would build things, and those people who would try to provide new industry to provide new jobs for those Victorians out of work.

Instead we have the John Halfpennys trying to hang onto their jobs and their power. They know they will not be able to control Jeff Kennett or Phil Gude the way they controlled Joan Kirner. There is no possibility that they will control Jeff Kennett. That is why the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) supported Jeff Kennett and Phil Gude, and that is why we support this legislation. It is absolutely the positive direction we need to take in this country to give working men and women a chance to enjoy higher wages and better conditions of employment and a chance to have some flexibility in the work place so that industry can be competitive.

In that respect there is no question that on 3 October the Victorian people gave a mandate to the coalition in Victoria. Yet this Prime Minister denies the mandate, as does the Minister for Finance. They reckon there was no mandate for change. Yet broadly the industrial relations policy was spelled out. We indicated we would give individuals the right to strike agreements with their employers outside the purview of the Industrial Relations Commission, and thank goodness for that. We indicated that we would guarantee that individuals did not have to belong to a union, nor that employers would have to belong to employer organisations.

That is true freedom of association, and it is long overdue. I can tell honourable members that compulsory union membership before 3 October was still alive and well in my devastated State of Victoria. The award system in this country, with its union generals, is like a boa constrictor—constricting the growth of a dynamic, forward-looking Australian economy. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Holding The Hon A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think anybody doubts that tough economic measures will have to be adopted to meet Victoria's economic problems. However, the tougher the measures, the greater the need for consultation, cooperation and genuine sharing of economic burdens.

PARA.TAB: If there is one group in the Victorian community that cannot be blamed for Victoria's economic difficulties it is the average worker, the average public servant; the average citizens out there on the street today who are basically defending their living standards and conditions. It is somewhat sad that honourable members opposite spend their time deprecating trade union leaders, yet at the same time believe and argue that over 100,000 Victorian citizens were on the street today simply at the demand of some trade union leaders.

The fact of the matter is that if there is to be sacrifice, if we are to meet economic demands, then the first thing any Victorian government must do is ensure that those demands and those sacrifices are shared equitably. But what did we get in Victoria? We got a situation where the Victorian Government brought in legislation that is truly macabre. The details have been dealt with by the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis). Let me say this: at the same time as the Government there is putting on regressive taxes and attacking the living standards of the average Victorian citizen, in the same breath, Government members gave themselves salary increases.

The Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Gude, when asked on television, `What is the average wage of the average Victorian worker?', did not know. But he knew that he was about to get an increase. `Oh, yes', says the Victorian Premier, `we made a mistake in giving ourselves all those increases'. But his apology is a bit like the bank robber who says, `Look, I am sorry that I robbed the bank but I am going to keep the dough'. If there is to be any sacrifice, if there is to be any sharing of burdens, then the example has to come from the top. The example has not been set by the Victorian Parliament. The kind of political sleaze that was bandied around this House today by honourable members opposite has indicated that, whatever reservations they initially had about Mr Kennett's actions, they have now embraced them.

In the short time available I want to deal with this question of political mandate. Casting one's mind back to the Victorian election, the Labor Party and Mrs Kirner ran a series of advertisements in which they said, `Look, one of the things that Victorians have to worry about is the New Zealand model, the New Zealand example. That kind of industrial relations attitude will be introduced into Victoria'. What was the response of Mr Kennett and the Liberal Party on this issue? They produced a pamphlet, widely circulated, headed:

SPEECH.PARA: The Real Truth About Your Job.
It attacked what they described as `the Big Labor scare'. I will quote the slogan from it:
What you have now, you keep.

The brochure said that under the coalition no person in employment would suffer any loss of award wages or conditions. And this is from a government that within a month banned holiday loadings and penalties in State awards, which will operate as the minimum safety net where there is no agreed employment contract. Mr Kennett was asked on radio on 25 September about his policy. I will quote from this man whom the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) now claims has a mandate:
Where they—
that is, the employees—

don't enter into an agreement on the contract, then their current conditions, all your shift work, all your penalty rates forms the basis for the new contract and therefore what you get today you keep, it's as simple as that.

If we are to believe this man, then how can he now say that he has a mandate for the political actions which he is adopting? How can the honourable member for Bennelong stand up in this House, act like a performing political prostitute and say, as he did today, that there was a mandate? The very same member, when he heard about it, immediately moved to distance himself from it. In the Age of 30 October, the honourable member for Bennelong said:
The federal coalition's policy was to put the loading with weekend penalties and other conditions up for negotiation, "not to take it away unilaterally".

Let me repeat that: `not to take it away unilaterally'. On 30 October that was the position of the honourable member for Bennelong. He was supported in that to no little extent by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson). Yet they were in here today having changed that position. Why? Because it was discussed in the Liberal Party and they were under attack.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought that any prudent employer—and there were employers protesting today—would understand and know that the one thing you cannot do is take industrial relations into the area of the criminal jurisdiction. Who is the employer—and I have been an employer—who wants to have the legal capacity to fine an employee up to $1,000 if he is late for work? It is a monstrous concept.

These other concepts could have been the subject of negotiation, discussion and consultation, but they were not. They were the subject of discussion amongst the employers. A private firm of solicitors who had prepared this legislation for Mr Kennett as early as 25 August was running seminars at $300 an hour to tell employers what was going to be in the legislation. Having put itself in that privileged position—after all, I suppose it had to make some money because it had performed the job of drafting the legislation free for the Liberal Party—it felt that it was only proper that any person in the corporate sector who could afford to pay could get advance knowledge of what the Government had in mind. But there was no such advance knowledge for the trade union movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or the people.

—At the time Mr Kennett made his statement that there would be no loss of existing conditions, he knew what was in his draft legislation. Where is the mandate in that? Where is the honour in that? Where is the principle in that? At the end of the day, the people of Victoria as a community are capable of making economic sacrifice. They are capable of taking on existing and greater economic burdens, but they are not going to accept double standards, and this whole exercise is riddled with double standards.

PARA.TAB: What we have from the Opposition in this House today is a full endorsement not only of the legislation but of the dishonesty that was manifestly part of it—the breadth of any argument that there was some kind of mandate, a refusal to talk in a sensible and sensitive way with the working people of this community through their trade union leaders. The kind of venom and hatred which was shown in this House today to people who have been elected to office through their trade union leaders is a warning to the people of Australia. For all the glib talk of the honourable member for Bennelong, for all the attitudes shown by the Leader of the Opposition, the Liberal Party is a party of pain and penalty for the average working Australian and a party of privilege for its mates.

That is the record in Victoria. Mr Kennett could not wait to get into the Parliament to give the working people of Victoria pains and penalties, while his Government members got out the silver service, the linen tablecloths and gave themselves a nice big wage increase. If that is the morality of the Victorian Government, it is a pity that it has now been clearly adopted as the current morality of this Opposition.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. G.G.D. Scholes)—The time for the debate has expired.

—by leave—I present a summary of evidence presented to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities on the draft Corporate Law Reform Bill 1992.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to introduce amendments to the Pig Industry Act 1986, the Primary Industry Councils Act 1991—

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether the Prime Minister will be speaking on this one.

—I should be introducing the chook Bill, if that is the retort of the honourable member for Bruce. There is a constant cackle coming from him, but very little constructive contribution. The Bill also seeks to introduce amendments to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977 and the Meat Research Corporation Act 1985.

PARA.TAB: The pig industry amendments are designed to improve the effectiveness of the pig industry's statutory policy body in providing advice to Government and industry on issues affecting all sectors of the industry. Other minor amendments to the Primary Industry Councils Act, of an operational nature, are also proposed. The amendments to the Meat and Live-stock Corporation and Meat Research Corporation Acts enable levy motions put to annual general meetings of industry stakeholders to be passed on a simple majority on each of the appropriate registers, and no confidence motions passed by two-thirds of total votes cast with a minimum of 50 per cent of the votes cast on the two producer registers and 50 per cent of the votes cast on the processors register.

This Bill will establish the Australian Pig Industry Council under the Primary Industry Councils Act 1991 to replace the Australian Pig Industry Policy Council, which was established in 1987 under the Pig Industry Act 1986. This change gives the new Council enhanced powers and operational functions so that it can more effectively perform its role of coordinating and formulating industry policy. Also it will allow for funding of the Council by the Commonwealth Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are we doing this for?
—We are doing it because industry wants it and because we are listening to industry and think it makes sense. I would have thought that that was what good government was about.
—That is why I asked.

—Why does the honourable member not listen? Under the Primary Industry Councils Act 1991, industry councils are required to review and report on the strategic direction of the industry; to inquire into and report to the Minister on matters affecting the pig industry that the Council or the Minister consider warrant investigation or action; to convene industry review conferences; and to convene regular meetings of chairpersons of the other relevant statutory bodies in the industry.The passage of the Primary Industry Councils Act 1991 provided the catalyst for the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to review the Australian Pig Industry Policy Council, with the object of improving its effectiveness.

PARA.TAB: The review found that there was a need to clarify the Council's role and functions. It found a need to improve communication of the Council's work. It suggested that the Council needed to be financially independent and that it should be staffed full time and located in Canberra. It recommended that there should be a minor adjustment to membership to better represent those with a direct investment in the industry, with associated interest groups being accommodated through working groups.

The review also concluded that the industry needed to take a more strategic approach to securing its future. At the moment only about one per cent of domestic production is exported. Clearly, the future for the pig industry lies in developing an export orientation. The level of investment in technology in the industry needs to be increased, and greater efficiency and rationalisation in the processing sector achieved.

The review concluded that the Council would be in a better position to address these matters if it was brought under the Primary Industry Councils Act 1991. Under this Act provision is made for the establishment of a Council and the specification of its membership by amending the schedule to the Act. This Bill adds the Australian Pig Industry Council to the schedule and it is proposed that the new Council will begin its operations on 1 January 1993 or as soon as possible after that date.

Besides the Chairperson, membership will include three persons nominated by the Pork Council of Australia, one person nominated from each of the Meat and Allied Trades Federation of Australia and the National Processors Association, and the chairpersons of each of the Australian Pork Corporation and the Pig Research and Development Corporation.

The anticipated operating costs of the Australian Pig Industry Council, which will be met by the Government, will be about $205,000 in a full year. The present Council is funded by industry levies paid to the Australian Pork Corporation. This arrangement is inconsistent with the principle of separating industry policy development from statutory marketing authority arrangements. Government funding will remove this dependency and will bring it into line with other industry council funding arrangements.

The Bill also provides for the termination of the Australian Pig Industry Policy Council and establishes transition arrangements for the orderly transfer to the Australian Pig Industry Council. These arrangements ensure that all outstanding liabilities at the date of commencement will be met by the Australian Pork Corporation. There is also a provision for the old Council to continue beyond the date of commencement for the sole purpose of preparing and submitting a final annual report to parliament.

The Bill also amends the Pig Industry Act 1986 to recognise the Pork Council of Australia as the eligible representative producer body for the purposes of Australian Pork Corporation accountability and membership of the Australian Pork Corporation Selection Committee. The industry formed the Pork Council of Australia in March 1992 to supersede the Australian Pork Producers Federation as the sole nationally representative body of pig producers.

The other amendment to the Primary Industry Councils Act provides for representation of the Food Committee of the Grocery Manufacturers of Australia Ltd on the Grains Industry Council. At present the Grocery Manufacturers of Australia Ltd is represented on the Grains Industry Council by its Chairman, as provided for in part 1 of the schedule to the Primary Industry Councils Act 1991. After introduction of that legislation the Grocery Manufacturers of Australia Ltd established a Food Committee, the membership of which includes major producers of grain based food products. It is more appropriate for this Committee, rather than manufacturers of grocery products generally, to be represented on the Grains Industry Council.

The amendments to the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation Act 1977 and the Meat Research Corporation Act 1985 will change the requirements for passing motions at annual general meetings. Levy motions will now be passed on a simple majority on each of the appropriate registers. Currently it requires 75 per cent vote against a levy motion put by a corporation for it to be overturned. No-confidence motions will be passed by two-thirds of total votes cast. Additionally, at least 50 per cent of the votes cast on the two producer registers and 50 per cent of the votes cast on the processors register must be in favour of the motion.

The amendments will give effect to the Government's decision that levy motions at AGMs should be passed on a simple majority. This also has the support of the meat and livestock industry organisations. The new arrangements will ensure that any successful no-confidence motion, which represents a very serious step for the industry to take, is based on strong industry support.

In conclusion, this Bill will create an Australian Pig Industry Council that is responsive to the policy needs of the pig industry and is effective in coordinating policy input from all industry sectors to deliver an overall strategic policy direction for the benefit of the whole industry. In the case of the meat and livestock industry, AGM requirements give effect to both the Government and industry's desire to make voting requirements more democratic. I commend the Bill to honourable members and I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.
