DEBATE.TITLE: HEALTH INSURANCE (QUALITY ASSURANCE CONFIDENTIALITY) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 4 November, on motion by Mr Howe:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Health Insurance (Quality Assurance Confidentiality) Amendment Bill 1992 relates to the process of monitoring and improving of the quality of medical services provided. In essence what the Bill does is provide legislative protection from prosecution for those people undertaking QA activities—as they are called—and also to national projects and studies by medical colleges and suchlike which cover a number of States and Territories and, therefore, are outside the bounds of various current State legislation. It also provides statutory protection by making QA information confidential and grants immunity to quality assurance activities and committees which are declared to fall within that definition by the Minister.

PARA.TAB: Let me say up-front that I am very disappointed about the amount of time that has been available for scrutinising the legislation since it was tabled in the House last week. Here we are, the following Tuesday, with a guillotine on, having an abbreviated debate. Obviously there has not been time for the general public or the interested organisations to scrutinise the legislation in its final form. This is ramrodding a piece of legislation, which is not without significance, through this House.

Although we have some concerns, in essence we support the thrust of what the Bill tries to do—and that is, to improve the quality of care in Australia. However, we have some reservations about the way in which this is done. There are some unanswered questions about the Bill as it stands and also about regulations which might accompany the Bill in future.

The Bill provides, basically, that quality assurance activity is an assessment or a valuation of the quality of a health service, or a study of the incidence of causes of conditions or circumstances which may affect the quality of health services. There are a range of services which are identified as falling within the auspices of that definition. It can be declared a QA—quality assurance—activity because of the person doing it, because of the nature of the activity, or indeed because of the circumstances in which the activity is done.

Under this Bill, information that comes to light as a result of these activities will be given statutory confidentiality. To fall under the auspices it must be in the public interest for the activity to receive statutory confidentiality and immunity protection, and a Minister must be satisfied that the person who is to engage in the activity is authorised by law—an educational, health professional or research institution or other prescribed body that may conduct the activity.

To offer the health professionals who are subjected to the QA activities some protection, the Bill prohibits the disclosure to anyone of any information collected as a result of those QA activities and prohibits the disclosure of that information, or relevant documents, to a court of law in general. There are some exceptions to that.

One of the concerns which have been raised in the brief time which people have had to peruse the Bill has come from some members of the medical profession. I have a lot of sympathy for their concerns, because if this is not legislated for correctly, this could turn into a potential star chamber. Some of their concerns do have some validity. Some have been dealt with adequately. There have been a number of drafts of this legislation in the past, although the Minister responsible has not had the courtesy to allow the Opposition to see them. I gather that as the drafts have come on some of the questions which have been raised have been addressed.

One concern relates to immunity from suit—that is, that doctors will not have the right to sue. This is seen as a potential problem. However, the fact is that as long as the activity is entered into in good faith and there is no malice, those two requirements will address the problem raised by the doctors. There is immunity only if the laws of natural justice are followed, and it would seem that on this basis the potential for a star chamber-type approach may have been minimised. There are, therefore, excluding those definitions, many situations where suing can still take place, and indeed that is entirely appropriate.

Another concern has been the question of public information disclosures. In essence, the public information is not disclosable to anybody or to any court but, as I said earlier, there are some exceptions. The Minister has discretion in some situations, in particular for serious offences. As I understand it, `serious offences' are defined as those offences which would carry a term of imprisonment of a year or more. There are going to be some regulations in terms of circumstances where the discretion of the Minister will be allowed to override some of these cases. Of course, as is always the case, those regulations are not available for us. I signal now that we will obviously scrutinise those regulations and, if they allow the Minister inappropriate powers, we will make sure they are disallowed. I am sure that we would have support for that in the other House.

As far as we can tell, the Bill will have no impact on torts—cases where negligence is concerned, for example. I think it is fair to say that medical records, which are often the basis for cases in that category, do not fall under the auspices of this Bill since they were in existence prior to whatever the QA process might have been. Therefore, the concerns that these might be used inappropriately in this regard have been addressed, as far as we can tell.

There are some other issues from the States and I hope that some of these can be fixed during the passage of the Bill. Most of the States have expressed some concern to us that at present the quality assurance processes need approval by both the Commonwealth and the States. It would seem sensible for there to be some system of mutual recognition, rather than to duplicate, which is what will happen in many cases, that recognition process.

There is another problem which I think needs to be addressed, and that is that there does seem to be a lack of appeal in terms of the peer review process. The peer review process, of course, does carry immunity. I think, therefore, that although there are some checks—the right of reply and natural justice need to be incorporated. In the short time available to us to scrutinise the Bill, we have not been able to satisfy ourselves that, in fact, there is an appropriate appeal mechanism. That is something which I hope the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) will address in his reply.

There are some other points which I think are worth making. One is the question of precedence. There are some precedents for this type of immunity. I understand that providing there is absence of malice, liquidators enjoy a qualified privilege in the performance of their duties, as do members of the Australian Broadcasting Authority and, of course, the Commonwealth, a Minister or any person acting with the authority of the ABA. I think it is also true to say that provisions within the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission Act mirror the provisions in this Bill even more closely by providing immunity to members of the Commission, provided their activities are in good faith, and prohibiting the disclosure of information obtained.

As I said, the Opposition has concerns about the regulations, which are at present unseen, so although we will not oppose the Bill, we do reserve the right, in the first place, to look at those regulations when they are introduced. If they give the Minister inappropriate powers, we will move to disallow those. As I said, I believe we would have the support of the Australian Democrats in that regard.

One of the things that clearly needs to be signalled is that we will review this after the election. We will review the process and see whether it is working in the way in which it is intended to work. If it is, in fact, being utilised to create star chamber type approaches or inappropriate persecution of anybody, doctors or others, and it is not working to improve the overall standards of health care and medical services which are offered, then we will move to redress that particular problem and to ensure that the Act is either repealed or amended, as would be appropriate, depending on the situation.

The bottom line for us is that there needs to be a balance. We support the thrust of encouraging quality assurance. It is a relatively new approach in many areas. It is covered by State legislation in the majority of States and there is therefore an element of duplication, but it is, of course, covered in terms of some of the activities which fall outside those particular pieces of State legislation.

As I said, the bottom line is a balance between ensuring that there is a good quality of care, that quality assurance monitoring procedures are carried out in hospitals and other areas, and making sure that this is not used as a way of inappropriately pursuing, if you like, in particular members of the medical profession, but also others involved in offering health care.

In essence, therefore, we accept the Bill as it stands. Now that the Minister is actually at the table, I express our sadness that we were not allowed a sensible time to peruse the Bill; nor were we given access to the original draft legislation. It is typical of this Minister that he does not seek cooperative approaches in health issues. He has not been helpful in respect of this or any other Bill in terms of giving us access to it at an early time; nor in giving us access to the Department of Health and the officials and people who prepared the Bill. It is, of course, historically true that this has always been the case with this Minister and I think it is very sad that he is not able to pursue these matters in a constructive and cooperative way, but always seeks to try to induce confrontation and perhaps not necessarily constructive debate in these issues.

The bottom line is that the Opposition will not divide on this particular Bill, but we will express reservations and concerns that it may not work in the way in which it is intended. I indicate therefore that we will review the legislation after the election when we are in government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like the member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods), I am very pleased to see the Health Insurance (Quality Assurance Confidentiality) Amend-ment Bill introduced into the House, albeit without his reservations. I think that the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) and the people in his Department who have reached agreement in respect of this Bill have done a very good job. Quality assurance in the health area is an important aspect of consumer protection of people receiving assistance through the health system.

PARA.TAB: The Bill tries to balance three competing areas of interest. One is protection for professionals involved in quality assurance activities. The second is the protection of those people wishing to credential professionals and therefore leaving themselves open, without this sort of quality assurance and protection, to suits from their counterparts. The third is the question of the consumer right to information where, in fact, some negligence has occurred. It is therefore an area which needs very careful handling and I believe that the Bill has handled it carefully.

The ministerial discretion available in certain circumstances is necessary to achieve that public protection which we believe is required in situations where there has been blatant criminal negligence or other very serious risks to public health. As well, the confidentiality provisions contained in the Bill are necessary to secure the quite essential involvement of the professionals who, for the most part, want to see this sort of quality assurance legislation introduced. So it is a balance between ensuring quality of health care for the public good and protecting those professionals who wish to be involved in this area.

The Bill promotes the undertaking of a range of quality assurance activities by providing statutory protection in the form of confidentiality of quality assurance information and immunity to quality assurance activities and committees which are declared by the Minister. It provides the enabling statutory framework to complement State and Territory legislation, where it exists—and it does not exist in all States.

When we ask the question, what is quality assurance, it ought to be answered in the context that it is a formal and systematic exercise of identifying problems in health care delivery, designing activities to overcome the problems, and carrying out follow-up monitoring to ensure that no new problems have been introduced and that corrective steps have been effective. As honourable members will understand, doctors and other health care professionals within the health system would be unlikely to wish to expose their activities to such scrutiny without the substantive protection of the confidentiality provisions.

That is not to say that people have been negligent but, rather, that an error has been made. The information provided by health care professionals will assist patients within the health care system to achieve better treatment in the future; therefore reducing costs to the community and to the country in personal terms, health terms and dollar terms.

The Bill encourages rigorous clinical audits and mortality and morbidity reviews necessary to gain a true understanding of the factors which contribute to adverse patient outcomes. To participate in these activities, health officials must be confident that the information obtained in such processes will not later be misconstrued and used against them. The Bill assists these processes by making information obtained solely as a consequence of the quality assurance activity confidential. Of course, it will still be possible for consumers of health care services to access other sources of information, but they will not be able to access information revealed in the context of the quality assurance committee meetings.

The Bill also facilitates other quality assurance activities, such as credentialling. The purpose of credentialling is to ensure that the treatments, procedures and surgery undertaken by individual health care professionals are only those that they are competent to perform. For instance, in the United States of America, credentialling is almost universal in hospitals, but in Australia it has been stymied by the fear of those who sit on credentialling committees that they will be sued by those who do not accept the outcome of the committee's deliberations. This is a very real problem in the Australian context, where we wish to have that sort of peer review, if you like, of a person's capabilities to operate within the area of health care that they are involved in. There may be a number of reasons why their peers may consider them not competent any longer to deal in those areas.

The Royal Australasian College of Surgeons is to be congratulated on its recent determination that surgical credentialling ought to be happening in all hospitals. This Bill will facilitate the implementation of that particular recommendation. There is widespread support amongst medical practitioners and consumers alike for open, positive and voluntary participation in quality assurance activities to prevent adverse patient outcomes and raise the quality of health care delivery.

Quality assurance has become a major concern of the Australian health care sector over the last two decades. Although by world standards the quality of Australian health care is extremely high, it is generally understood that health care consumers can suffer adverse outcomes from health services. Some of these are known and accepted risks of certain procedures and treatments, even when these procedures and treatments are expertly performed. The key to this legislation is that in the main we are dealing with situations where there may be problems occurring in a procedure which doctors and surgeons may wish to acquaint their colleagues with, but would be afraid to do without this sort of confidentiality being provided because it would leave them open to some sort of action by the consumer.

On the basis of Australian hospital separation data, it is estimated that between 95,000 and 150,000 avoidable adverse patient outcomes occurred in 1991. This represents between 3.3 and 5.3 per cent of all hospital separations. The cost of the extra duration of stay in hospital, even if it is only five days, is between $143m and $225m. It is certainly not a small amount of money that is involved. The House would be well advised to consider the personal cost to consumers in terms of their future health and security as well as their confidence in the health system. Given the obviously huge costs of adverse patient outcomes to both the health system as a whole and the individuals concerned, prevention should be given the highest priority, and that is what this Bill does.

There was some concern in the Caucus committee about this matter. For instance, I think the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) has a view on this Bill which is now resolved. He was concerned about the question of consumer sovereignty and the ability of consumers to pursue an action against those people who had negligently performed their duty as health professionals. He has since been convinced that the Minister's intentions are correct and that the quality assurance legislation is necessary in the quest to improve our health care system and to open it to some scrutiny.

The scrutiny that we need to open it to in the first instance is definitely that of other professionals to allow them to learn from the mistakes of their colleagues. The whole question of quality assurance in Australia is one that definitely needs undertaking. I congratulate the Minister and the people in his Department who have brought this legislation to the House today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER; HEALTH, HOUSING AND COMMUNITY SERVICES

TALKER.NAME: Mr HOWE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods) and the honourable member for Cowan (Mrs Jakobsen) for their contributions to this debate on the Health Insurance (Quality Assurance Confidentiality) Amendment Bill 1992. Essentially the purpose of this legislation is to enable quality assurance activities to have the protection of Commonwealth legislation. It will provide a very important protection or immunity to enable these activities to take place with a recognition of the importance of confidentiality, as the honourable member for Cowan has mentioned.

PARA.TAB: It is extremely important that we are able to develop a process which means that we can investigate the quality of the interventions that take place within the hospital system and within medical situations and that people feel they can participate in those quality assurance activities without feeling some uncertainty about what protection they have. While there is some existing State and Territory legislation, essentially the Commonwealth has taken the advice of a number of the professional groups that we ought to act at the Commonwealth level. There has been considerable support from the profession and from the colleges for the Commonwealth to act and to become involved in terms of this legislation.

One reason for that involvement is that, at least in some States, adequate legislation is not in place. This is an area in which it is important that we have a national approach. We have been able to learn some lessons from those States where effective legislation has been in place, such as in Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland. When the States adopted their legislation they were delving into uncharted waters and were unable to predict events which occurred after the legislation became operative. One weakness in the legislation of these States is that it does not allow for the disclosure of aggregated and non-identifying information. For example, if the quality assurance committee in a large teaching hospital amasses considerable data about standards of care, it cannot be released even in a non-identifying form.

By comparison, the Commonwealth Bill has been drafted to make confidential only that information which would directly or indirectly identify either the health care provider or the patient. Consequently, activities authorised under the Commonwealth Bill will permit the disclosure of data which can then be used in a very public sense to improve the quality of health care. This area goes to issues of records and issues of information. This is important not only because of the individuals who might be involved but also because of the value that can be obtained from aggregate data.

Another reason why Commonwealth legislation is appropriate is a concern that State legislation cannot prevent the disclosure of confidential information in the Federal Court. This has been an issue of concern for St Vincents Hospital in Sydney. In considering having its quality assurance committee authorised by the New South Wales legislation, St Vincents Hospital sought legal advice as to the capacity of the New South Wales legislation to protect information in Federal Court proceedings. The advice provided was that only Commonwealth legislation can prevent the disclosure of confidential information under subpoenas issued in the Federal Court.

The final reason why Commonwealth legislation is appropriate is the change in attitudes within the health sector to credentialling. Credentialling is the process by which the clinical privileges of individual health care providers are determined. The purpose of credentialling is to make sure that only those who are appropriately qualified can carry out particular procedures or surgery. In particular, the credentialling of surgeons in hospitals is highly desirable. Credentialling of surgeons is in fact widespread in North America, but it is only just starting to happen in Australia.

One reason why credentialling is not common in Australian hospitals is the fear that health care professionals who participate on credentialling committees may be personally liable if an individual professional chooses to sue the committee for its decisions. The Royal Australasian College of Surgeons recently resolved its position on surgical standards in hospitals. A key element of that position is the statement that credentialling should occur in all surgical departments. This Bill will provide a framework within which health professionals, particularly the medical profession, can develop effective credentialling. The Bill will provide immunity to health professionals who participate in credentialling committees in certain circumstances.

Concerns have been expressed that credentialling will result in witch-hunts and arbitrary and unfair decisions which restrict the clinical privileges of individual practitioners. The Commonwealth is not attempting to impose credentialling on health professionals, nor is it attempting to mandate how credentialling should occur. These matters are for the professions themselves to resolve. However, the Bill will protect professionals who participate in credentialling in good faith when the process adopted is a fair one. The effect of the Bill is that protections will not be available unless those professionals who have been credentialled have been provided with procedural fairness. Procedural fairness is a lawyers' term of art, but it translates roughly into the right to know the substance of any concerns, the right to respond to those concerns and the right to a fair and unbiased hearing.

It is possible to put in place appeal requirements for credentialling activities. As one of our criteria for ensuring that the granting of protection is in the public interest, the medical profession and State governments are to be consulted on this and other regulations. The concern of the honourable member for Lowe in this area can be addressed. In the process of regulations, there will be, as there has been in the preparation of this Bill, quite wide consultation.

I think the Bill has the support that it has from the colleges and the medical profession generally because they understand that these measures are part of a process of providing greater protection to the profession from unnecessary litigation. The Government has in mind that we should carry out a very extensive process to see, ultimately, whether we can deal with litigation, which has become an extremely important issue in this country. What occurs in this country is relatively insubstantial compared with the massive costs associated with litigation in countries such as the United States.

This Bill is part of a process of reform that is built on very substantial investigation, research and inquiry. Publications have already come out of that process which indicate the options for continuing reform. There will be further development of strategy papers. Those papers will be public and there will be the opportunity for further consultation. One cannot achieve reform in this area without there being effective consultation and very substantial processes of research and investigation. I think people generally will welcome our commitment to reform in this area and, implicit within it, the development of national approaches.

In Australia we operate within a federation. This obviously has its strengths, but, in areas where there is uncertainty, to be able to pass complementary legislation as part of the Commonwealth to provide an overall framework does have substantial benefits. This Bill is important, but I stress that it is a stage in an ongoing process of reform and one that we hope will have widespread consensus within the medical profession.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Howe) read a third time.
Debate resumed from 4 November, on motion by Mr Howe:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods Dr R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Medicare Agreements Bill, a very important Bill and one of the foundations of our whole health system, has been available for the coalition and other interested parties to peruse for only a few days. This is the sort of Bill that should be on the table for weeks, if not months, to be debated at length, to be discussed and to be evaluated by people of all walks of life, from all parties, with all interest groups.

PARA.TAB: It is a national disgrace that a Bill as important as this, which will form the foundation of our health system for the next five years, should be skimmed through under the guillotine, with no debate—particularly when there is no need to do so. There is no deadline; the current Medicare legislation does not need to be renewed until July next year. We have plenty of time to leave this Bill on the table, to evaluate it carefully over the next few months, and then to debate it formally, perhaps in March or April next year, still leaving plenty of time for any complementary legislation which might need to be put in place. That would mean that the Bill would be superfluous, because I presume that by then there will have been an election and the whole Bill will be irrelevant anyway. I am sure that has not escaped the attention of the Government.

There has been very little debate and discussion on the principles of the Bill. We were presented with this Bill with only a few days notice. It is a fairly comprehensive Bill, involving important matters of principle, and there has not even been an attempt at a bipartisan approach. I have to agree, as I am sure the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) will point out, that the likelihood of agreement on many of the issues in a bipartisan fashion was not that good, but at least in some of the issues we could have attempted to reach some understanding and improve the legislation.

According to the Government, the motivation for this Bill is to ensure national policy consistency in the delivery of health services in Australia. Effectively, it sets out the legislative framework under which the individual State Medicare agreements will be negotiated and moneys appropriated. It enshrines the so-called Medicare principles and commitments about public hospital service delivery which the States must agree to before they receive financial assistance from the Commonwealth. States must also pass complementary legislation and agree to the development of a public patients hospital charter. Ostensibly, the principles and commitments are to improve public patient access to hospital services.

This Bill supports the negotiations which are occurring with each of the States at present by which the Commonwealth enters into Medicare agreements with those States for a five-year period commencing on 1 July next year. The agreement must satisfy the points detailed in `Heads of Agreements' at schedule 2A to the Bill, which states that the funding will be used, amongst other things, to provide for public hospital services; to encourage more effective provision of health services; to provide for the States to give Commonwealth statistical information; and to provide for the States to establish a public patients hospital charter. That charter should be distributed to the public.

The Bill also provides that financial assistance will not be payable unless an agreement has been signed. The five components of the financial assistance payable will be a base funding hospital grant, a hospital bonus payment, a hospital incentive package, a mental health incentive package and other health services funding. Financial assistance will not be payable unless the States give effect, or make reasonable attempts to give effect, to a series of Medicare principles and commitments.

Those commitments and principles include the choice to receive public hospital services free of charge and access to public hospitals on the basis of clinical need. To the maximum practical extent, the States will ensure the provision of public hospital services to all persons, regardless of geographical location. We have no problem with the principles of some of those. We believe very strongly that eligible people should be given the choice to receive public hospital services free of charge as public patients. We have always stated that access to a public hospital should be on the basis of clinical need. We believe that sorting out the geographical problems that many people have is a major initiative which the Government should undertake.

One of the commitments associated with the legislation is that information must be made available on public hospital services which eligible patients can expect to receive. I believe that refers to the development of the public patients hospital charter. The second commitment is that both the Commonwealth and the States are committed to making improvements in the efficiency, effectiveness and quality of health services delivery. I understand that that focuses on the provision of public hospital services to eligible persons and operates in an environment in which those people have the right to choose private health care in public and private hospitals, supported by private health insurance. That is the only mention of the private health sector. This is one of the problems. I will come back to that a little later.

There is a requirement that there should be an independent complaints body. Most of the States already meet that criterion. The agreements may be varied with the consent of both parties. If it is a significant variation, it must be approved by both Houses of parliament. This clause was clearly included in anticipation of a government defeat at the next election, in an attempt to make life difficult for us should the Democrats start to be bloody minded about some of these issues. They have indicated that they may have some differing views from those of the coalition in these regards. However, we will get around that as we have to face it.

This Bill relates to the negotiations between the Commonwealth and States about the new Medicare agreements which, as I am sure most honourable members are aware, have basically been a complete failure. The only State that I am aware of which has signed to date is Western Australia. Even Western Australia has only signed under duress because it has an election coming up in February. It has been pushed into signing this Bill, even though on many occasions Minister Keith Wilson, the State Labor Minister in Western Australia, has said how disastrously bad the Medicare system is in its current running. He said that there would be `dire consequences'. He also said:

SPEECH.PARA: The truth is that Hospital Medicare is not the fair and just system that it promised to be and has not been since its inception . . . It is quite outrageous of the Commonwealth to make a song and dance about hospital efficiency when it is perpetrating the most inefficient and ramshackle funding system one could imagine.
Elsewhere he suggested that the Minister might face up to the realities. He said:
Medicare is meant to provide the least well off access to good care, yet there are long waiting lists.

This includes pensioners desperate for hip replacements. He also said that Medicare is not working and the main reason is that the Commonwealth is refusing to fund it adequately. The important question, following on from those sorts of comments, and there are many more, is: does this Bill and the associated agreements fix up the problem of funding? As I will come to later on, not only does it not fix it up; it makes it a lot worse than it is at present, and that is bad enough.

PARA.TAB: A $1.6 billion so-called incentives package was announced in the Budget, which the Minister claimed would reform State public hospitals. That package is partly funded by the increase in the Medicare levy, from 1.25 per cent to 1.4 per cent as of 1 July. The other major features of that package included $70m over two years for a hospital access program to reduce public hospital waiting lists. I have pointed out elsewhere that if the Minister really wanted to get rid of waiting lists and treated them on the current costings available, he would have to have about a quarter of a billion dollars put into public hospitals to get rid of them. Whichever way we do it, either by increasing resources in public hospitals or by transferring those patients into the private system, $70m over two years—that is, $35m a year—is a drop in the ocean.

There is also a $1.2 billion bonus incentive package over five years for State hospitals to increase the proportion of public patients. It effectively states that a higher proportion of those public patients will receive greater funding. If we reduce that to the per annum amount allocated, it is somewhere over $200m per year. As I will indicate in a moment, each of the major States—Victoria and New South Wales, in the first place—indicates that just to maintain the status quo they need $200m-plus. For New South Wales the figure is closer to $300m. Yet, here we have $200m-plus being given to the whole country each year. Clearly that is not going to address any of the problems.

The allocation formula used is such that it will mean that a sizeable proportion of the population will face even worse difficulties than they are facing at present. Let us make no bones about it, the waiting list at present is approximately 90,000, as far as we can determine. There are between 75,000 and 100,000 people on the waiting lists, mainly for elective surgery. That is almost entirely related to the lack of funding from the Commonwealth. These waiting lists have increased dramatically since the advent of Medicare. Waiting lists were never mentioned as a major problem prior to the advent of Medicare, and it is a question of the funding restrictions which this Government has imposed upon the public hospitals. If that is the problem the Government has for funding constraints, and it is using Medicare as a way of capping costs—clearly that is what happens because the Minister boasts so often when travelling around the country that the total costs of Medicare are kept at 8 per cent or 8.1 per cent of GDP—then, effectively, it is a rationing system. The price we pay for that rationing system is waiting lists. Waiting lists are a deliberate ploy of this Government.

If that is the problem, we have two ways of fixing it. There is a third way, of course, which is to improve the efficiency and, although the Government claims to be doing that, there is very little evidence that that is in fact occurring. Apart from improvements in efficiency there are two ways of addressing the difficulties of funding: either by increasing taxes, which is what the Government has chosen to do by bumping up the Medicare levy, or by encouraging people to put their own money into health. Encouraging people to put their own money into health is a more efficient way of allocating resources. It is something which will be more acceptable to the population. Clearly, we need to give people incentives to take out private health insurance.

I do not want to go through a whole list of quotes again. Let me simply say that Keith Wilson, Maureen Lister and Carmen Lawrence have all indicated that the balance between the public and private sectors is inappropriate. The honourable member for Grey (Mr O'Neil), as I am sure the Minister is aware, urged the Minister to reconsider his approach to private health insurance and to adopt the coalition policy in this regard, which is to give financial incentives to take out private health insurance, something which I somehow suspect the Minister will not adopt.

The bottom line in giving incentives is that major financial inputs can be put into the system. Every now and then the Minister complains that we are putting money into the pockets of rich private insurers, implying somehow that they just pocket the money and it does not get through into the health system where, by and large, all health insurers do is pay people who are insured when they go into hospital. Clearly the money goes into both public and private hospitals.

The coalition policy will be to move, conservatively, a million people into the private health insurance arena. If we assume, in round and conservative terms, that they are each spending about $1,000, then we are looking at putting $1 billion into health without raising taxes, of which something like 50 per cent goes to the public hospital system.

Some of the Minister's colleagues are telling a few fibs about us and saying that we are reducing the funding to public hospitals. They put in a few qualifications and choose their words very carefully, but, in essence, they wander around the country saying that we are going to cut public hospital funding. The consequence of that, which they sometimes go on to mention—the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) is particularly guilty in this regard of spreading these pieces of information—is that hospital beds will close and jobs will be lost. The fact is, of course, that we are absolutely increasing the funding.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on! When are you going to be honest?
—Was the Minister just listening to my argument?

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. G.G.D. Scholes)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —Five per cent off fags.
—Were you just listening to the argument?
—The argument is that $1 billion will go into health. Are you putting $1 billion into health?
—Order! The Minister will have his opportunity—
—Can the Minister put $1 billion into health? He just cannot do it. The Government is actually putting $200m per year into health.
—Order! The honourable member will address his remarks through the Chair and the Minister will wait his opportunity to speak, if the guillotine allows it.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I point out again that all the Government is doing is putting in $200m per year, which is not enough to address each of the States' requirements—
—Order!

—let alone the increase which is needed to maintain the status quo. We are putting an extra $1 billion into health. All the Minister can do is wander around the country spreading what it is polite to say are porky pies in regard to this issue.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—You can ask for a withdrawal. There is no point of order.
—I will rephrase it. I ask for a withdrawal. The honourable member at the table knows that—
—Order! The Minister cannot debate the question. The remark `porky pies' was a play on words.
—In fairness—
—Order! The Minister will resume his seat. He will have to wait his turn to make a speech.
—I certainly think I can have it withdrawn.
—I have asked for the withdrawal, but the Minister should resume his seat first.

—I am happy to withdraw the term `porky pies', and the implications. I point out, however, that it is a misrepresentation of the coalition health policy. The Minister knows that. If he had any of the accuracy, which I am sure he would like to have, he knows he cannot do it.
—The Minister knows full well that that is another of those misrepresentations.
—That is not true.
—Order!

—They are absolute misrepresentations. We are putting $1 billion into health. So to suggest that we are cutting by any percentage is entirely inappropriate. That is the information which is available to the public, the public has assessed it, and all reputable assessments have indicated that the amount going to public and private hospitals will increase by about half a billion dollars each. Yet the Minister still wanders around the country spreading misrepresentations and exaggerations about the coalition health policy, after every reputable health economist has said that this will lead to a resurrection of public hospitals. The States are clamouring for us to do just that. They are clamouring for the Minister to do it, and he has turned them down. His own State of Western Australia and the State of Victoria prior to the election were saying this. Every State in the country is saying, `Please encourage people to take out private health insurance'.

PARA.TAB: The Minister has an ideological block about private health insurance. In this agreement the Minister cannot even accept the amendment put forward by some of the States, just to acknowledge that private health insurance, the private sector, has a role to play. He mentioned this in the preamble; that is all. A statement is needed to ensure that people have a right to utilise private health insurance in public hospitals. Is the Minister somehow suggesting that private patients should not be allowed in public hospitals? That seems to be the implication.

If that is the case, is the Government going to fund the shortfall? Clearly it is not. It is talking about something like the same sorts of amounts of money raised into the hospital system by private patients as the Medicare levy, so the sequitur from that is presumably that the Government is going to double the Medicare levy. If that is the Government's secret plan, then let us have a look at it: put it on the table and we will examine it. If that is the case, then clearly we need to know about it so that we can debate it openly and in the public arena. What the Government is clearly doing is putting some little gesture—$200m—into the bonus incentive package over 5 years. Two hundred million dollars is not going to address the current problems let alone the future problems. Even if that were distributed in a fair and equitable way there would still be major problems with waiting lists and public hospitals.

Clearly the Government's agenda seems to be to run down public hospitals even more, because if that were not the case it would be either allocating money via private health insurance or it would be allocating money by bumping up the Medicare levy. It looks like the Government's secret agenda is to increase the levy even more. The Minister's predecessor gave an undertaking that the levy would not be increased, but here we are in this Bill, and in the next Bill, looking at just that. The Government has got around it slightly by saying, `We will leave it to July and that will be after this Parliament'. The good thing, of course, is that that will be after the election so it will never come in. As those opposite know, we have given an undertaking that that increase in the levy will not be implemented—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a five-year agreement.

—It is a five-year agreement starting from 1 July. What is the rush? We have had this Bill here for three or four days. Why is there a rush? What is the Government trying to hide? Why can the Government not allow this to be scrutinised properly? It knows there is no 5 per cent reduction. It knows it is just a fib made up by Labor Party politicians—

—Absolutely. It is quite the opposite. It is a $5 billion increase. The Minister has criticised me elsewhere for actually increasing the expenditure on health. On the one hand he is saying that we propose a 5 per cent cut; on the other hand, he goes to public forums and says, `But you are going to allow the GDP percentage to increase'. The Minister cannot have it both ways. He must have either one thing or the other. He cannot accuse me of cutting down on public health funding on the one hand, which is what he is now saying by interjection—he is saying it will be cut down—and, on the other hand, say, `Yes, the Opposition is going to increase the amount of GDP spent'. That is currently 8.1 per cent. He cannot have it both ways, but he is doing both. It is a case of having one's cake and eating it twice over. The Minister really has to maintain some integrity with his arguments.

—Oh, the Minister does not disagree that we are going to have health. Is the Minister saying that he does not think that the private insurance goes through to the public hospital system? He thinks, as he has claimed elsewhere, that it sits in the pockets of private health insurers.
—Order! The Minister will remain silent. He is chattering away. I suggest that the honourable member for Lowe, rather than carrying on a conversation with the Minister, address the Chair.

—It is the only time I get to talk to the Minister. He is scared to debate me. We have asked to debate him many times. He refuses to go to the same forum as me. He will not actually address me and he will not allow me to speak to his staff. He will not allow me to have meetings with the Department of Health unless his staff are there as policemen. It is the only chance I have to have a conversation with him.
—Order! All of which does not alter the fact that you will address the Chair.

—I am very happy to address my remarks through the Chair, but it is a pleasant opportunity to be able to get some direct information from the Minister, unshackled by his departmental minders. The view of many of the States, and two of the major States in particular, which together account for 60 per cent of the public hospitals and public hospital patients in Australia—New South Wales and Victoria—is, as the public is well aware, entirely opposed to the legislation in principle and, in particular, to the haste in which this legislation is being rushed through. They believe that the debate should, in the first place, be adjourned, but, failing that, should at least be deferred until next year to allow appropriate discussion and debate of these issues. They have advised the Commonwealth of that.

PARA.TAB: They have also advised the Commonwealth that they would not plan to pass complementary legislation in terms of the commitments and principles of the Bill, and they want a formal recognition in the Bill of the role of private health insurance. Ministers who claim that there is no role for private health insurance, or refuse to acknowledge it, are surely burying their head in the sand. I know that some Ministers are famous for this, and I would not want to make this accusation about the Minister at the table: he can make his own judgment; the public already has made its own judgment.

The fact is that private health insurance and the private health sector have a major role and, in any sensible government, always will. The Government is planning to abolish private health insurance and to introduce a single, national insurer, and on that basis of course—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Madam Deputy Speaker. I ask for a withdrawal. There has been a miscellaneous collection of lies, mistruths and accusations with absolutely no basis—

PARA.TAB: Madam DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mrs Sullivan)—Order!

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the honourable member refer to the Bill?
—Order! The Minister will withdraw the word `lies'.
—I have some difficulty.
—Will you withdraw?
—I have some difficulty.
—It is unparliamentary. The Minister knows it is unparliamentary. He will withdraw it.
—I withdraw it as it is unparliamentary. But I ask the honourable member to read the Bill.
—Are you raising a point of relevance?
—I am raising a point of absolute misrepresentation. We have got a Bill in front of us which talks about people's rights to health care and private health insurance—
—Order! The Minister will resume his seat. He has the opportunity to reply at the end of the debate.
—The amendment which is required, and which the Minister has turned down, is this:

SPEECH.PARA: Eligible persons have the right to choose health care in public and private hospitals supported by private health insurance.

The Minister refused to allow that to be part of the legislation. Indeed, he has refused to allow it to be part of the individual agreements with the States. I do not understand what the Minister is complaining about. I often do not understand what he is complaining about, and neither do a lot of other people in this place or, indeed, in his own Department.

PARA.TAB: There are a number of issues which we really need to address. If the Minister would just keep quiet for a few minutes and allow me to address them in a sensible fashion, I would be happy to look at them to see what we can do to resolve them. Another concern with the proposed legislation is that it enables the enshrining of principles of Medicare agreements on the eve of seeking to implement a third Medicare agreement in isolation from other aspects of Medicare and other Commonwealth health programs. It contains a proposal for a public patient's hospital charter but has no reference to the other services available to the people of Australia under Medicare, including their right to retain the doctor of their choice if they elect to be a private patient.

It fundamentally changes the whole basis on which financial assistance is provided to the States. This makes financial assistance to the States contingent upon complementary State legislation. The Commonwealth requirement for complementary legislation in many cases includes areas already covered in some States; for example, the independent complaints mechanism. It is really inappropriate for the Commonwealth to dictate to the States on many of those issues.

The legislation does not make any commitment to the development of a joint Commonwealth-State national health policy, as suggested by the States and Territories in Adelaide, which the Minister has conveniently ignored. It seems to be another attempt by the Federal Government to dismiss the very real concerns of States and Territories that the current delivery of health services in Australia occurs in a policy vacuum—despite the findings of the national health strategy.

Financial assistance to the States is divided into those five separate components which I mentioned earlier. Each one of those requires separate administration and separate reporting requirements. It is contrary to the stated intent of all governments at previous fora to reduce the number of separately identified payment and reporting systems. It is contrary to the intent of the broad banding proposals contained in the proposed draft Medicare proposal.

It also includes a mental health incentives package despite the Australian Health Ministers Council having adopted a national mental health policy and agreeing in principle to an implementation plan subject to an appropriate allocation of Commonwealth funding. It introduces for the very first time the notion of some hospital services being funded directly by the Commonwealth, and extends beyond hospital services to other health services. There are a number of major issues in the legislation which really do need to be debated in detail not only in this place but in the other fora around the country by people who have an interest in the health area. This is the foundation stone for what the Government wants to do.

Let me at this point signal that we will oppose the Bill and we will, if appropriate, before the third reading if because of this terrible guillotine we do not have a committee stage—and obviously depending upon the result of the opposition to the Bill—have the amendments circulated in my name incorporated in Hansard. They fix up at least some of the problems in this Bill, although it is second best to wiping out the whole Bill and starting again.

One of the issues we really have to address is the question of the money. I have already indicated in general terms that the bonus payments offered are a nonsense in terms of improving the quality of services offered in the public system.

Let us look at Victoria. The current problem in Victoria relates to reduced Commonwealth assistance, increasing costs and declining numbers of privately insured people due to the barriers put in the way of private health insurance by the ideologues in the current Labor Government, of whom the Minister clearly is one. There are close to 30,000 Victorians on waiting lists. Each year 65,000 Victorians fall out of private health insurance. That means that an extra 4,500 patients move into the state system every week, and they cost an extra $207m over the period in question. Eight years ago the Commonwealth contributed 55 per cent of State public hospital funding. Last year it was down to 42 per cent. The Minister cannot possibly challenge those figures. Clearly, the Commonwealth's share of hospital funding is falling; that is also true in New South Wales and, I understand, in most other States too.

This legislation discriminates clearly against both Victoria and New South Wales. If we look at the effects of the allocation formula for the bonus payments described in this Bill, which on the face of it might seem quite attractive, we can see that the two major States, New South Wales and Victoria, are seriously adversely affected. As a result of the increase in the Medicare levy, New South Wales will raise somewhat over $100m. Penalties associated with the sources of income represent some $21m. About $288m is going into the bonus pool, and the incentives package takes some $78m. But, when we look at the way that is distributed, because of the ratio of public to private patients in New South Wales and Victoria, New South Wales and Victoria will actually finish up worse off than they are at present.

The distribution on the basis of the agreements as they stand at present means that New South Wales will lose $104m each year and Victoria will lose $127m each year. South Australia will lose $9m and the ACT will lose $3m. The winners are Western Australia—which is one of the reasons why it has signed the package, of course—Queensland, which gains $69m, Tasmania with $18m and the Northern Territory with $37m. An amount of $87m remains in the penalty pool; the Commonwealth has $15m and unallocated is $14m.

When we put these figures into the broader context of the five-year package, they are horrifying because it means that public hospitals in New South Wales and Victoria—60 per cent of the health system—will be severely penalised. Over the five years New South Wales will lose $544m. Victoria will do even worse; it will lose $711m. These are figures from the Department of Health in New South Wales. There is no doubt that they are accurate.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are absolute rubbish.
—Well, I am happy to table this document, and seek leave to do so.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bottom line therefore is that public hospitals in New South Wales and Victoria will be grossly penalised—hospitals that are already run down and which have waiting lists as long as your arm—while patients suffer because of the pain and agony that this Government is putting on them. Every single State around the Commonwealth is telling the Minister exactly what is happening and he chooses to ignore it. He has this ideological tunnel; he has the vision at the end of the tunnel and the little light at the end of the tunnel. The only trouble is that the light at the end of the tunnel is the express train rushing towards him as the election gets closer.

PARA.TAB: Thank goodness we will be able to rescue the health system in Australia before these things are implemented because they will not be implemented prior to the election. The only good thing about this Bill is the starting date, which would be 1 July. I indicate here our complete opposition to these terrible proposals. I criticise the Government in the strongest possible terms for not allowing appropriate and adequate debate inside this House and outside this House and for trying to rush this through.

I am delighted to see that the Democrats have indicated that they will seek to postpone consideration of this by a motion to send it to the appropriate committee, allowing a minimum of one month for the various States to produce their documentation. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is little wonder that the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods) has filled his presentation this evening with such fabrications and misrepresentations about the Government's agenda in this Medicare Agreements Bill. He has been pedalling backwards at 1,000 miles an hour away from his own policies. I am not surprised because, in his travels around this country pursuing his own policies, he has found that the vast majority of Australians reject the Opposition's package. They are rejecting it soundly, and they will reject it at the next Federal election.

PARA.TAB: Health will be a very important issue at the next Federal election. That is because the Australian people overwhelmingly support the Government's Medicare policies and programs, overwhelmingly support the retention of Medicare, and overwhelmingly reject what the Opposition has to offer.

I will deal with a couple of the fabrications and the misrepresentations that were in the presentation from the honourable member for Lowe. He tried to reject the fact that his own Party's Fightback policy clearly espouses an intention to slash 5 per cent across the board from all State allocations. Health is a very important part of the allocation of moneys to the States. Those opposite should understand the fact that, if they were to slash 5 per cent across the board, that would have a major impact on States' capacities to fund their public hospital systems. No matter how much the honourable member for Lowe tries to back-pedal on that, it is clear in black print in Fightback!. Everybody has read it and everybody knows it. The State governments know it, and they do not want a bar of Fightback because they know exactly what would happen to them if we ever had the unfortunate situation of having those opposite elected to government.

The other important issue is about the amount of money that will be allocated to the public hospital system. The honourable member for Lowe also failed to outline the fact that there is an $8 billion difference between what this Government is prepared to provide to public hospitals and to health care over the next five years and what the coalition is providing in Fightback. That $8 billion difference would have a major impact on all of the issues that the honourable member for Lowe has been outlining as issues of concern. He was pouring out crocodile tears, worrying about waiting lists. Not one step and not one element of the coalition's Fightback policy will have any positive impact on waiting lists.

If we look at the legislation that we have in the package of proposals that was outlined in the Federal Budget, we see that this Government has a real commitment to dealing with the waiting lists. Additional funds are being provided to each State government to tackle that issue.

The fact is that the coalition's policies, as espoused by the honourable member for Lowe, will lead to a direct transference of money out of the public hospital system and into the pockets of those people in this country who can afford private health insurance, which is only about 40 per cent of the population, and a direct transference of about half a billion dollars into private health insurance funds. That transference of money into the pockets of those people who can afford private health insurance and to the private health funds will not do one single thing to reduce waiting lists in public hospitals. It will do not one thing to improve the efficiency of public hospitals. It will not do one thing to provide one extra bed or one piece of equipment to public hospitals.

This Government has a very strong commitment to the public hospital system, and that is emphasised by this legislation. The provision of health care services to all Australians under Medicare is the single most important feature of our health system. It forms a fundamental part of this Government's commitment to social justice. Medicare was established in 1984 so that all people, regardless of their location, age or health status, and particularly regardless of their financial status, could enter the health care system as equals.

Medicare is based on the five principles of universality, access, equity, efficiency and simplicity. It has proved to be an outstanding success—and I think that is the thing that galls the honourable member for Lowe the most—in keeping expenditure on health at a level that Australians can afford without compromising these fundamental principles. The Medicare agreements to be established under this Bill introduce reforms to our hospital system that will build on the foundations of Medicare to make it more flexible and responsive, to focus on consumers and to sustain the Australian health care system into the next century.

The Medicare Agreements Bill before the House seeks to achieve four main objectives. They are: firstly, to provide a funding guarantee to the States and Territories for the life of the agreement by a special appropriation; secondly, to enshrine the principles and commitments of Medicare in Commonwealth legislation, and to require steps towards complementary legislation by States and Territories; thirdly, to establish some minimum conditions for payment to States and Territories under the Medicare agreements, including signing an agreement, developing a public patients hospital charter and agreeing to adopt, or to make attempts to adopt, the principles and commitments in complementary legislation; and, finally, to establish the structure and framework of the new Medicare agreements for the five-year period 1993-94 to 1997-98.

The Medicare principles and commitments are a statement of the fundamental elements of an effective and equitable health care system. The Medicare principles and commitments set the framework for the agreements and the operation of the bonus and incentive payments. They are designed to be adopted as guidelines for the delivery of public hospital services to public patients.

The principles and commitments have been developed in consultation with the States, and the wording reflects State suggestions. While the principles focus on the provision of public hospital services to eligible persons, it is acknowledged that they operate in an environment where eligible people have the right to choose private health care in public and private hospitals supported by private health insurance.

That brings me to the proposed amendments of the honourable member for Lowe. He suggests in one of his amendments that we should include as a fourth principle eligible persons having the right to choose health care in public and private hospitals supported by private health insurance. That is already outlined in the preamble to the Bill. But the honourable member for Lowe seems to ignore the fact that this is a Bill about funding public hospitals, about the distribution of public funds to support public hospitals in this country. It is not appropriate to espouse a commitment to private health insurance or private hospitals in the principles about Medicare and the public hospital system, and that is why this particular amendment by the honourable member for Lowe will be rejected.

It should also be noted that, although the honourable member for Lowe tried to indicate that there is some poor attempt here by the Government to steamroll States and Territories in this matter, in fact this suggestion to include this part in the preamble was made by the Northern Territory Minister for Health, Daryl Manzie. It was his suggestion, and it was supported by the other States, that it be included in the preamble. It was not supported that it should be included as another principle.

If one actually looks at what is happening with the negotiations, despite the comments by the honourable member for Lowe that certain States have been placed under duress and all sorts of threats are occurring, in fact very successful negotiations are occurring with six of the eight States and Territories. The fact that two of the States are posturing for their own personal political purposes does not mean that they will not eventually come to the party, because they recognise that what this Government is offering in this Bill is a far better deal than what those opposite will be offering. That is why they will be prepared to sign this agreement and get the flow of funds from the Commonwealth through to the States and into the public hospital system: they know they will get a far better deal from a Labor government than from any coalition government about public hospitals and public health care.

Let us deal with the bipartisan question. The fact is that Liberal governments in this country—State Liberal governments and State Liberal-National Party governments—are supporting the Medicare agreements. Honourable members will find that by the end of this year all State and Territory governments will be supportive of this because they know they will get a much better deal from it.

Let us look at the three principles which are important to this Bill. The first principle is that eligible persons must be given the choice to receive public hospital services free of charge as public patients. The second principle in this Bill is that access to public hospital services is to be on the basis of clinical need. Of course, that is not disputed by the Opposition. The third principle is that to the maximum practicable extent a State will ensure the provision of public hospital services equitably to all eligible persons, regardless of their geographical location.

These are three very important principles. They articulate the concepts of choice, equity and access in public hospital service delivery. They give expression to the security that every Australian resident is looking for in our public hospital system, and they are the reason that our health system is so much better than that of other nations.

That is also a very important point. It is in fact to the Australian health system that President-elect Clinton is looking to see whether he can adopt our important principles into the Medicare system for the United States, because the Australian health system under Medicare is recognised around the world as one of the best health systems that can be provided. It will be interesting to see the coalition's response when the United States starts to adopt some of our policies.

The Bill also outlines the broad conditions for funding that will apply to the Medicare agreements. The most fundamental of these is that receipt of funds is conditional upon signature of the Medicare agreements. These conditions include taking steps towards passage of State and Territory legislation that is complementary to the Commonwealth Bill and will enshrine the Medicare principles and commitments. Under the Medicare agreement both levels of government will undertake to implement the principles and commitments.

The Commonwealth does not expect the States to implement the principles and commitments alone, but to recognise that both levels of government have an interest and duty to maintain our public hospital services and to ensure that public patients get the most comprehensive and fairest health service possible.

Part of this provision involves the delivery of information to eligible public patients. This is reflected in the first commitment, which requires the joint Commonwealth and State development of a public patients hospital charter. The Commonwealth's vision for such a charter is that it will be a plain English guide to what Australian residents can reasonably expect as public hospital patients.

The Commonwealth does recognise that immediate passage of complementary State and Territory legislation may not be possible in some States despite the best endeavours of governments. It is for this reason that the Bill allows some scope for definition in the agreements of what constitutes reasonable efforts towards adoption of the principles and commitments in the legislation. But most State and Territory governments, including the New South Wales Government, do agree with the public patients charter.

The second commitment encompasses efficiency and quality in public hospital service delivery. This is one of the priorities of the Bill and Medicare agreements and will be supported by the incentive package reforms. These reforms include continuing the development and implementation of Casemix systems in hospital service delivery, ensuring elective surgery for public patients is organised efficiently and fairly, and investigating with the States and Territories better ways of developing capital strategic plans for hospitals and providing hospital services that meet local needs.

This is particularly important for me as the member for Moreton because within my electorate I have three hospitals, with a fourth major public hospital very close by. So the provision of public hospital services is very important to my constituency, and I certainly welcome this agreement because I know that for the residents of my electorate and the residents of Queensland the additional financial support provided in this Bill to the Queensland Government will very largely improve its capacity to provide top quality public health care to all residents of Queensland.

We will not achieve this level of reform without the States and Territories. Improvement in our public hospital services involves Commonwealth, State and Territory commitment of effort and money. I also know that the Queensland Government has already indicated its intention to commit additional funds through the establishment of the additional tobacco levy. A lot of those moneys will be provided to the public hospital sector in Queensland and will complement the additional funds being provided by the Commonwealth.

The Commonwealth is providing a funding increase of approximately 7 per cent over the base hospital funding grants to make our public hospital services more efficient and effective. This legislation will demonstrate to the Australian public that both levels of government are committed to excellence in health care. Indeed, since 1984 the Labor Government has developed a model of equitable and technologically advanced public hospital care. From 1993 this Government intends to build upon this solid achievement and remain responsive to the future health needs of Australians.

I conclude by reinforcing the point I made at the beginning: this Bill is an important Bill for public health in this country. It complements our previous work in Medicare. It goes a long way towards ensuring that Medicare stays a permanent feature of Australia's public health system. This is very strongly supported by the vast majority of Australians. Australians recognise that through Medicare since 1984 they have had a fair, equitable service available to all Australians regardless of income level. They recognise that Medicare is a very important part of the Labor Government's social justice policies.

Australians will reject totally the coalition's policies on health. They are already doing so. That is why the honourable member for Lowe, as the shadow health spokesman, is back-pedalling so rapidly, avoiding discussion about his own policies, avoiding concentration on some of the features of Fightback and their adverse impacts on health care.

We must realise that in Australia the Labor Government, and the next Labor Government, will continue to fund health care to the tune of $8 billion more than the coalition offers. I think all Australians need to be aware of that figure. The coalition is offering an $8 billion slash over the next five years to public health care in this country. This Government is committed to increasing the provision of health care over the next five years to the tune of $1.3 billion more than it currently provides. I believe that this Bill is worthy of support, and that this Government is worthy of re-election for its health policies alone.

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous speaker, the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson), shows abysmal ignorance. Even when he quotes the amount of money that he claims Labor will spend after the next election on health care generally, he illustrates this inane argument so often put up by people on the other side that, by throwing money at a problem, it can be solved. In direct contrast to that, we have a policy which has been articulated all around the country by my colleague the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods). He has not ducked the question, as the previous speaker seems to have suggested.
