PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 3 November, on motion by Mr Baldwin:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) pointed out in debate yesterday that it is not our wish that the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) 1992 and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 be debated cognately, but the Government has ruthlessly applied the guillotine. To get even a cursory examination of what it proposes, we have had to go along with it. It is just another example of the executive imperialism we find under Labor in Canberra these days.

PARA.TAB: Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) makes a number of changes to those provisions of the tax law dealing with occupational clothing, dividend streaming arrangements, the taxation of limited partnerships and the prescribed payments system. Amendments are also made to the gift provisions and the exemption from income tax of the family payment advance.

The Bills seek to deny the deductibility of expenses incurred in the purchase of certain corporate uniforms or wardrobes that are non-compulsory in nature. Under these proposed amendments, employees will only be able to deduct expenses incurred in purchasing and maintaining uniforms or corporate wardrobes where the wearing of this clothing is expressly required by the employer as a condition of employment. The Bills signal the intention of the Labor Government to tighten up the extent of the deductibility available for corporate wardrobes and uniforms.

Although deductibility will still be available for non-compulsory uniforms and wardrobes, the Australian Taxation Office is in the process of developing strict guidelines to establish whether tax deductions will be allowed in particular cases. These guidelines will, however, be published after this Bill receives royal assent, once again conferring discretion on the Commissioner rather than on this Parliament, the legislature of the country.

The Government will be moving an amendment to the Bill in the committee stage to give effect to its proposal. In other words, the Bill before us is hot off the press and already the Government is proposing an amendment. The amendment and amended amendment reflect the considerable pressure the Government has been under from certain manufacturers and textile, clothing and footwear council members, which saw the original legislation as a major threat to the profitability of some. In addition, the commencement of these measures is to be pushed back from the originally intended date until 1 July 1993.

The amendments proposed pose a number of problems in the context of the self-assessment of income tax, even if one supports the Government's policy objectives in this matter. These problems arise from the fact that, while it is the employee who is denied the relevant deductions in the circumstances set out in the Bill, it is the employer who must satisfy the relevant criteria for the existence of either compulsory or non-compulsory uniform or corporate wardrobe in the workplace.

A self-assessing taxpayer may have great difficulty in establishing whether his employer has satisfied all the necessary conditions to be laid down. The circumstances in which an employee may be entitled to a deduction for the cost of a compulsory uniform or corporate wardrobe must be ascertained from an interpretation of the definition of `non-compulsory uniform/wardrobe' in the Bill. This poses problems because it is difficult for both employers and employees to determine at any given time when there is a relevant policy preventing an employee from substituting items of the uniform or corporate wardrobe `except in special circumstances' as provided for in the Bill. There is also a practical difficulty in establishing whether the employer has in fact been enforcing such policies where they are held to exist for the purpose of the proposed law.

In many cases, this change to the law may well be unenforceable and, therefore, will be inequitable in its application. This is just one of the many cases in which the tax law is out of step with the requirements of our partial self-assessment system. While it is common for the existing law to be out of step with the new requirements of self-assessment, it is less common for the Government to introduce new measures that come into this place which are also out of step with self-assessment.

Unfortunately, while the Tax Office bombards us with all the rhetoric of self-assessment, we see very little of the reality of self-assessment in the design of new tax legislation. This is something which I urge the Tax Office to give more attention to and to which the ATO will give more consideration under a coalition government and our proposed reforms for the system of tax administration in this country.

The Bill also seeks to amend the dividend streaming provisions to ensure that they work as intended in the case of international dividend streaming arrangements. Under these amendments, resident companies will be able to preserve a portion of their available franking credits to be offset against the franking debit that arises under the dividend streaming provisions when a non-resident associate pays a related dividend under the streaming arrangement. These provisions will apply to franked dividends paid by resident companies on or after the date that the Bill receives royal assent.

This is a measure that is essentially unobjectionable and will not have a significant impact on the revenue, given the small number of companies affected. The Bill also gives effect to the Budget announcement that limited partnerships formed on or after 19 August 1992 will be subject to the same taxation provisions as those that apply to companies. The basis for these provisions is the Tax Office view that limited partnerships have more in common with companies than with partnerships generally, and so should be taxed accordingly. Limited partnerships formed prior to 19 August 1992 will be subject to the same tax provisions as companies from the 1995-96 income year. If they do not continue to carry on the same business, or if their ownership changes to a significant extent, then they will be treated like companies for the year of income in which they change their circumstances and in all later years.

Those limited partnerships that are subject to the new arrangements will be known as corporate limited partnerships in future, according to the second reading speech of the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin). We are told that these measures are designed to deal with a number of actual and potential tax avoidance schemes that take advantage of the existing limited partnership provisions. The existing provisions allow limited partnerships to pass losses through directly to investors and to make tax free distributions to resident and non-resident investors. There is considerable debate as to the merits of the existing tax provisions for limited partnerships, with many people arguing that they provide an appropriate mechanism for small businesses to avoid the complexity of the corporations law, without the risks of full personal liability found in ordinary partnerships.

The problem with this legislation, as proposed, is that it adopts a blanket approach to a problem that might conceivably have been addressed with amendments more narrow in scope and directed at specific schemes that the Government wishes to counter. Instead of adopting a more narrow approach it might be preferable to deal with any tax avoidance schemes that take advantage of the existing limited partnership arrangements through the use of the general anti-avoidance provisions of part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act rather than use the blanket approach adopted in this legislation.

The Taxation Institute of Australia has pointed out that, if it is Labor's policy to deny the benefit of losses in the early years of a project to participants in all infrastructure projects, the amendments proposed simply do not achieve that goal. For example, the Taxation Institute cites the fact that the amendments do not preclude the use of a partnership or joint venture arrangement under which losses incurred in the early years of the project may be effectively passed on to the participants. Furthermore, the Taxation Institute has said of these proposed amendments:

SPEECH.PARA: It would appear that the amendments have been hastily prepared and contain a number of serious drafting errors.

According to the Institute, some of those errors result in parts of the legislation being rendered nonsensical. Labor clearly needs to give more thought to what it is trying to achieve in these arrangements. The danger Labor faces in taking the approach that it has with this legislation is that some genuine limited partnerships may suffer in the attempt to crack down on a variety of tax avoidance schemes. This approach is inconsistent with the goal of promoting business activity and economic growth—something which limited partnerships may facilitate in many cases. Unfortunately, the needs of business are often forgotten by Labor in the design of its tax legislation.

PARA.TAB: The Bill also amends the prescribed payments system as announced on 1 July 1992. These amendments are designed to reduce the compliance burden of the prescribed payments system by replacing current monthly reporting arrangements with annual reporting. Amendments are also made to those provisions dealing with deduction variations and exemption certificates and approvals to quote reporting exemption numbers. Once again, these amendments are unobjectionable from the point of view of the coalition. The coalition has said that when it is in office it will review the prescribed payments system to ensure that the withholding rate is commensurate with its proposed new income tax scales.

In 1992-93 it is estimated that the prescribed payments system will collect in advance some $1.3 billion. That will be an increase of 10.3 per cent on the figure for 1991-92. The Bill also amends the income tax law to exempt the family payment advance from income tax. As the law currently stands, regular instalments of family payment are exempt from income tax. These amendments will extend this exemption to the lump sum payments of up to six months in advance. This will begin to operate from 1 January 1993.

We are also considering cognately the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992. This Bill will increase the rate of the Medicare levy by 0.15 per cent to 1.4 per cent from 1 July 1993. This measure is expected to raise an additional $300m in revenue in 1993-94. This is on top of the amount the Medicare levy already raises which is expected to amount to $2.5 billion in the financial year 1992-93.

As I had occasion to remark last week in this place, the Medicare levy is one of the more fraudulent of the Labor Party's range of taxes. It promotes a fiscal illusion whereby people are led to believe that they receive subsidised health care in return for what looks like a small levy on their income. In reality, the Medicare levy does not even begin to cover the costs of Medicare and the difference is made up with other tax collections through the rest of the tax system. The Medicare levy pays for barely one-eighth of the combined expenditure of Commonwealth, State and local governments on health.

The Medicare levy does not even pay for the Commonwealth's medical benefits payments, much less all the other categories of health expenditure. In 1990-91 the revenue the Commonwealth collected by way of the Medicare levy represented less than 60 per cent of Commonwealth medical benefits payments and only 27 per cent of Commonwealth payments for all medical and hospital services, not to mention the health services provided by other levels of government.

The reality is that the Medicare levy is just another kick in the teeth for taxpayers which bears no relation whatsoever to the funding of the health system. If we were to inject some honesty into Labor's Medicare levy concept and levy it at a rate that reflected the real costs of Medicare, while reducing other taxes by a similar amount, then we would need a levy of around 5 per cent just to cover the Commonwealth's health expenditures. In order to fund the approximately $20 billion in total government expenditure on health in Australia each year we would need a Medicare levy somewhere approaching 10 per cent. Australians would then appreciate, I suggest, the true costs of our grossly expensive health system and take an appropriately dim view of Medicare and the income tax burden it thrusts upon those same taxpayers.

The increase in the Medicare levy provided for in the Budget is just another tax hike that will be levied at a flat rate across all incomes, excluding only low income earners exempted by the provisions of the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill which was debated only last week. The low income exemption still leaves large numbers of low income earners having to foot the Medicare levy each year on top of their income tax.

Labor is not just guilty of misrepresenting the costs of Medicare to taxpayers. It is also guilty of a serious distortion in what it says about the impact of the Medicare levy on Defence Force personnel under a coalition government. The Government's Poles apart document claims that Defence Force personnel earning more than $45,000 would have to take out private health insurance or pay a surcharge on the Medicare levy. That is a scurrilous lie.

The coalition has clearly stated that Defence Force personnel will be exempt from the coalition's Medicare levy surcharge if they are currently exempt from the Medicare levy. Defence Force personnel with dependants who have a pro rata liability for the Medicare levy will also have a pro rata liability for the Medicare levy surcharge, but only if their family income exceeds $50,000 and they have failed to take out private health insurance which, under the coalition, will be rewarded by a generous tax credit. Labor's claims about the Medicare levy and Defence Force personnel are just another example of the outright lies and misrepresentations contained in its Poles apart document. The coalition will be opposing this increase in the Medicare levy and with any luck at all will be in office before this increase in the levy comes into effect on 1 July 1993.

The coalition has given an undertaking not to increase the Medicare levy above its current 1.25 per cent, unlike Labor, which seems determined to implement a steady increase in the levy over time, partly to pay for the blow-out in health care costs that its health policies have generated. The coalition has pointed to a number of difficulties with Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) as introduced by Labor. While we still will not be opposing that Bill, we will be encouraging its referral to a Senate committee to iron out some of the difficulties which the coalition has identified. Unfortunately, the use of the guillotine in the debate in this chamber appears to have ruled out detailed consideration of this legislation at the committee stage, so once again it is left to the Senate to exercise the prerogatives which were once also the purview of this House, but which have long since been usurped by the Executive under Labor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear Mr G.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been pointed out, the Bills before the House—the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 6) and the Medicare Levy Amendment Bill (No. 2)—increase the Medicare levy from 1.25 to 1.4 per cent, and there is good reason for that. The mix of private and public patients has undergone a fairly rapid transformation since Medicare was introduced. At the time of its introduction in 1984, about 60 per cent of Australians were covered by private health insurance. I do not have the tables that go back that far, but in September 1986, 48.6 per cent of Australians were covered by private health insurance. That figure has now plummeted to 40.7 per cent. So you can see that, given a choice, Australians are getting out of private health insurance and relying more and more on the Medicare system. What the people of Australia are telling us is that they like Medicare, that there is a fairness about it which appeals to them. The basic unfairness of private health insurance is driving more and more people out of it.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) ran the old line about the fact that the Medicare levy does not pay all the health bills. It was never intended to. All the levy was supposed to do was make up for the shortfall that would exist from the introduction of Medicare and the provision of health care for public patients that went into the system. If the honourable member says that the levy should rise to 5 per cent, or even 10 per cent, to cover the costs of health care, maybe it is illustrative to look at what private health insurance costs would have to rise to to cover the total cost of health care in Australia. If we had a totally private system, it would cost each family $250 per week to take out private health insurance. So if you want a direct comparison, that is it.

Medicare has its advantages, one of which is in the Bill before us today. The Bill raises the threshold under which no Medicare levy is payable at all. For individuals the threshold will rise from $11,745 to $11,887. For married couples it will rise from $19,674 to $20,070. One of the advantages of Medicare is that low income people do not have to pay the levy but they are still afforded all the benefits that it provides. It is very important for people on low incomes, such as pensioners, not to have to pay the Medicare levy.

But there are other advantages. Medicare is based on people's ability to pay, so people on high incomes do pay more. It is a very progressive way of funding that part of the health bill for which the Medicare levy has the responsibility. Medicare is also convenient for people. If for some reason people are late in paying their private health insurance and are unlucky enough to have an accident, they are left stranded. With Medicare that does not happen. Payments are made automatically and that is much more convenient. The other advantage is that it is a universal system; everybody is covered. That was not the case with private health insurance. Under the Opposition's proposals, Medicare is the only thing that will make sure there are people out there with private health insurance. Its proposals on private health insurance do nothing for universality.

The one area in which Medicare has never lived up to its ambitions is that of giving equal access. We have never had equal access, and I do not think we ever will. But that is certainly not helped by private health cover which allows people to buy access. I noticed at the weekend in Perth, and I think in other capitals around Australia, that television advertisements run by private health insurance companies portrayed a person needing medical treatment. The first question asked was, `Do you have private health insurance?'. The answer was, `No, I'm a Medicare patient'. The response was, `Well, you can wait 12 months'. However, if the answer was, `Yes, I do', the person could have treatment straight away.

The question that is raised by such television advertising is whether medical services are being delivered on the basis of need, on the basis of ability to pay, or on the basis of classification. As I said before, it seems to me that Australians are waking up to the unfairness of private health insurance. People pay the Medicare levy plus private health insurance. Then, when they go into hospital—usually it is a private hospital, but it does not have to be—as a privately insured patient, they get large bills on top. The basic unfairness of all this is that this area is unlike any other area of people taking out insurance cover. When people take out more insurance they expect to pay less when they claim whatever they are insuring themselves for. This is one area where people take out more insurance so they can pay more money.

The basic unfairness of this is being recognised by the Australian people and more and more are getting out of private health insurance. It costs about $35 a week to take out top private health insurance cover. There are not many families in Australia, I would venture to say, that could afford that. Certainly there are many pensioners who are going without many of what we would call the necessities of life—not luxuries—so they can take it out, but the only advantage is that it buys access. There is another advantage, to the extent that people can exercise it, which is that people can choose their own doctor.

I noticed in the debate leading up to the Bills being placed before the House today that the Opposition spokesman on health matters, the honourable member for Lowe (Dr Bob Woods), spoke about waiting lists. Part of the money raised by the Bill will go towards assisting in reducing waiting lists. I have before me an article from the West Australian of 4 July stating that the Federal Government gave $8m to the State Government of Western Australia to reduce waiting lists. The article states :
Mr Brennan—

SPEECH.PARA: the Health Commissioner in Western Australia—
confirmed that not one private hospital had tendered for the $8 million put up by the State Government last year to allow extra elective surgery to be performed on public patients.

What he was talking about there was a scheme whereby the Federal Government, through the State Government, gave $8m to reduce public waiting lists, but they were going to use private hospitals to do it. The article continued:

PARA.TAB: AMA President Mick O'Halloran said it was unacceptable to treat public patients in private hospitals, where they would be lying next to people who had paid $1500 a year for private health insurance.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr O'Halloran's sums are a bit wrong: it is a lot more than that. The article went on to say:

PARA.TAB: The scheme would remove one of the main remaining incentives to take out insurance, he said.

SPEECH.PARA: So, it is more than just a battle about money; it is a battle about ideology. The fact is that, according to the AMA, you cannot treat a public patient in a private hospital. Yet it is the AMA that raises the issue of waiting lists. The Federal Government, through the West Australian Government, is saying, `We will give you money to reduce the waiting list`, but the AMA says, `No, you can't do that. Because they are public patients, they can't be treated in private hospitals'.

PARA.TAB: My view is that the Australian people are trying to tell us something. They are getting out of private health insurance, and we should recognise that. The Government has recognised that, because of the mix of private and public patients—that is, 60 per cent private down to 40 per cent and falling—it has to raise the Medicare levy. There are more patients to treat in public hospitals. There has to come a day when we get rid of this distinction between private and public; when we have Australian patients. We must break down the barriers that stop people from getting into a hospital to get treatment. That is what the present system does. It does it for no good reason at all.

The only reason I can ascertain, from taking an interest in this area, is that privately insured patients, of course, are worth more to doctors. The doctors can charge them virtually what they like. I suppose the other area that may help explain it is that some of the medical professional bodies do not like being reliant on one insurer.

I take a fundamental view about the role of health insurance. I think it is there for the patient, more than the doctor. I think it should be there to suit the man in the street. The man in the street is not getting full value out of the current arrangements. A significant number of people in my electorate are waiting for what are relatively minor operations. There are empty hospital beds in Western Australia, but people cannot get the treatment because they are public patients.

As Dr O'Halloran said, when we gave the AMA $8m to reduce the waiting lists, it would not accept it; would not use it; would not put public patients in private hospitals. He says it is unfair. I think it is unfair to make people wait longer than they should for these operations. This can seriously impair a person's quality of life.

The Opposition's policy on private health insurance is to go backwards and not forwards. It is not to listen to what the people of Australia are saying about private health insurance. People are voluntarily leaving private health insurance, and not always because of cost. Any honourable members who speaks to their constituents would know that. The basic unfairness about which I spoke earlier is one reason why many people get out of it. The other reason, of course, is that a lot of people do not see why they should be in it. They do not see the need. There is no need to be in it if you are young and healthy, so why pay an extra $35 a week, or up to $35 a week that could be used somewhere else?

Of course, the Opposition wants to go backwards and try to resuscitate the old private health insurance industry. It is very interesting to look at the way in which it intends to put more money into hospitals. The Opposition's proposals would raise from the Australian public an extra $2,113m. Of that, $1,591m will go straight to the doctors. An amount of $200m will go towards the increased utilisation of waiting lists. So, less than $1 in $10 of all the money collected will go to hospitals. In fact, more will go to the private health insurers to be soaked up in administrative costs. The Opposition proposes to provide $274m for administrative costs; $200m to the hospitals and $1,600m to the doctors.

Some of the increases are quite dramatic. A dermatologist, for instance, will get an increase of $132,000 a year under Fightback. That is $132,000 a year on top of the $279,000 he is already getting, making a grand total of $411,000. Honourable members might like to compare that with the nurse who may be working alongside that doctor in Victoria. That nurse has just lost the 17 1/2 per cent leave loading and the penalty rates. There is a basic unfairness about all of this which I think the people of Australia are recognising.

I support the legislation to increase the Medicare levy. As I say, I do not think it will be the last increase. I think the people of Australia are embracing Medicare more, and as we get more Medicare patients and less private patients, then I think the future is entirely predictable.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a great pleasure to have such a substantial audience of Government members present. We are discussing here tonight a very significant piece of legislation, the Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill 1992. This legislation seeks to implement many of the proposals which were announced by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) on 30 June last in his statement Security in retirement. Many of these proposals are fundamental to the Government's approach to retirement income policy and were built around the superannuation guarantee charge.

PARA.TAB: There are a number of initiatives which are of some significance. I should place it on record that the Opposition does not oppose all of them, although we believe that our retirement income policy is a significantly more viable document than that proposed by the Government following significant reforms dating back to 1983. In fact, there has been almost a decade of constant change in superannuation policy, which I regret to say has had a major impact on people's confidence in long term investment as a viable means of assuring them of retirement income.

One of the major initiatives relates to the question of limits on deductions for superannuation contributions. Currently employers can contribute unlimited amounts on a tax deductible basis. The self-employed can obtain tax deductions for contributions of $3,000 plus 75 per cent of any amount exceeding $3,000 up to the maximum of their reasonable benefit limits, otherwise known as RBLs. These arrangements for the self-employed have been remarkably generous in the past. They have led to some instances of high income earning professionals taking advantage of the system as an effective tax haven in which to deposit contributions of many hundreds of thousands of dollars, resulting in substantial pay-outs on their retirement.

However, the proposed changes go too far the other way. The amendment will impose an age-based limit on employer and self-employed contributions. For example, an employee under 35 years may have only up to $9,000 a year; between 35 and 49 years, $25,000 a year; and aged 50 and over $62,000 a year. These, of course, will be indexed to average weekly ordinary time earnings. A formula applies for those years in which an employee has a birth date at which the deduction limit applies and in which contributions are made.

If employers do not want to use these age based limits, they may elect to use a standard contribution limit for all employees. If the employer has 10 or more employees for whom the employer makes superannuation contributions and if the employer elects to adopt this method, the standard contribution limit will be determined by the number of full year employee positions multiplied by the indexed amount; namely, $25,000 a year. The new arrangement is clearly generous, particularly when compared to the new regime for wage and salary earners, which I will come back to later. On a lifetime basis this would mean that a person taking maximum advantage of these limits between ages 20 and 65 would be able to contribute approximately $1.5m on a tax concessional basis, compared with a maximum of $300,000 for individuals and $600,000 for couples under the Fightback proposals.

However, the reality is that Labor's generosity to the high-flying professionals—do not forget it is only the wealthy who really benefit from these Labor proposals, not the ordinary workers—is in stark contrast to its treatment of ordinary wage and salary earners. People on average weekly earnings or less, which represents some 70 per cent of all taxpayers, will be able to claim a maximum rebate—this is the most horrifying part of this reform—of $100 a year compared with an average of $33,000 a year for somebody who has significant resources to invest and who is self-employed. If Government members regard that as an equitable proposition, I do not and the Opposition certainly does not. The Government claims that it is going to achieve savings of some $20m in 1994-95 from this proposal, together with the other changes also proposed in the package.

I turn now to the question of deductions and rebates for personal superannuation contributions. Currently there is a range of different taxation concessions for wage and salary earners in the various categories. For example, those with no superannuation cover can claim tax deductions on the same basis as the self-employed; that is, $3,000 a year plus 75 per cent of the excess contributions up to their RBL limits. Those with award superannuation only are entitled to a deduction of $3,000 a year. Those with incomes of less than $25,000 a year, tapering off at $31,000, and with modest levels of employer support—say $1,600 a year—are entitled to a rebate of up to 25 per cent or a maximum of $750.

This amendment will effectively replace those different levels of tax concessions with a uniform rebate at a token level, as I said, of a mere $100 a year, being 10 per cent on a maximum contribution of $1,000. Even this will be fully available only to those with incomes less than $27,000 and will phase out at $31,000 a year. Effectively, these changes will dramatically and adversely affect an estimated 1.3 million people who are currently contributing to superannuation plans and particularly personal plans.

They involve a contractual arrangement using a set period of at least five years. These people will suddenly be confronted with the obligation of effectively contributing a higher net amount or be found to have breached the contract. One can appreciate that the Opposition has received a considerable number of complaints and expressions of concern from many contributors to superannuation funds because of these proposals.

The giving of less than 24 hours notice is in stark contrast to the other provisions of the Bill, which involve two years. This is a matter which I hope that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security (Mr Sciacca), who is at the table, will explain to us in some detail, as no doubt he is an expert in this field. There has been widespread speculation as to the Government's motives, but it would seem quite consistent with its view that employers should bear the full responsibility for superannuation contributions and that employees should be effectively discouraged from making their own arrangements. This, of course, is in direct contrast with the whole principles for superannuation under the Fightback proposals.

Consequently, this is a totally unacceptable situation, as a current generation of employees will receive nothing like an adequate level of retirement income under the SGC proposals. On the Government's own calculations, for an individual on average weekly earnings to receive 40 per cent of AWE, there would need to be 12 per cent contributions made over a 40-year period. Most workers will not be in the work force for anything like that period, and they would be fortunate to be employed at present at all, as a result of the failures of this Government's economic policy. Consequently, the majority of the work force are currently aged over 30 years and are still being effectively encouraged to retire at age 55. Women also tend to work 10 years less on a full time basis than men.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to dinner I was talking about the Government's proposals in relation to deductions and rebates for personal superannuation contributions. I made the point that the Opposition regards it as a totally unacceptable situation that the current proposals for retirement income in terms of the SGC timetable will not be achieved.

PARA.TAB: The overwhelming majority of the current generation of the work force will also not have the benefit of anything like 12 per cent of contributions, whatever length of time they are in the work force. Some 850,000 employees are not covered by awards at present and, therefore, have not been receiving the first 3 per cent award superannuation. A further 600,000 award employees have not received their entitlements as a result of employer non-compliance. It is estimated that there must be an additional 100,000 public sector employees who have not been receiving award superannuation.

As the SGC is to be phased in over a 10-year period, it follows that even those already receiving the first round of 3 per cent will not reach 9 per cent until the year 2002. Goodness knows when they will reach the 12 per cent advocated by the Government. Consequently, in those circumstances, we believe it is ridiculous for the Government to remove any top-up incentive which is currently in the law, and such incentive will be removed by this legislation.

I move onto another issue in relation to superannuation—pensions and roll-over annuities. Currently there is a 15 per cent tax rebate payable on the post-1983 portion of a superannuation pension paid from taxed superannuation funds and annuities purchased wholly with roll-over eligible termination payments—ETPs. The rebate is paid only on those pensions and annuities which become payable after 1 July 1988 to a person aged 55 or more. It was originally introduced as a quid pro quo for the introduction of a tax on a fund's earnings.

The rebate is paid on the income component of pension or annuity payments, and the capital component is therefore free of income tax. The income component is determined by dividing the undeducted purchase price by the term of the pension or annuity and then subtracting it from the annual pension or annuity payable. This consists of that part of the purchase price of the annuity or pension prior to 1 July 1983 for which the taxpayer did not get a tax deduction or rebate plus that part made after that date for which a tax deduction was not claimed.

Proposed changes in this Bill will introduce a new 15 per cent rebate on superannuation pensions paid from taxed superannuation funds and on annuities purchased wholly with roll-over ETPs to replace those existing rebate arrangements. Consequently, the rebate will apply to all such superannuation pensions and roll-over annuities payable to taxpayers who are aged 55 or more, irrespective of when the pension or annuity commenced to be payable.

The Bill also seeks to amend the definition of ETPs so that rebatable superannuation pensions and rebatable ETP annuities will be limited to post-June 1993 undeducted contributions. In many respects, the Opposition believes that this new rebate is simpler than existing arrangements, as it does not differentiate between annuities and pensions which were payable prior to 1988 or prior to the individual reaching age 55.

For those with a high pre-1983 component, the new rebate will provide a greater incentive to take a pension or annuity over lump sums than before. On the current tax scales, the rebate will mean that no income tax will be paid on any rebatable superannuation pension or roll-over annuity under approximately $17,300. Overall, these measures are supported by the Opposition and are broadly in line with our approach to superannuation, in that they represent a simplification of current arrangements and encourage the choice of annuity or pension over the taking of lump sums.

I turn now to the election to roll over eligible termination payments. Certain primary lump sum payments from superannuation funds are taxed as ETPs. For taxation purposes they are broken into various components which are taxed at different rates. A typical example is the splitting of an ETP into pre- and post-1 July 1983 components. Currently, individuals wishing to withdraw less than the full amount can elect which components of an ETP are to be rolled over and thereby minimise the amount of tax that is immediately payable. This Bill will prevent individuals electing which part of an ETP will be rolled over and, subsequently, provide formulae for determining the components of the retained amount and the roll-over amount for the purposes of calculating tax liabilities.

In many respects, the amendments do nothing to reduce the complexities associated with the maintenance of the pre- and the post-1983 regime. They will also operate retrospectively. Seen in a context of Labor's unsatisfactory approach to superannuation, surely this initiative in itself is therefore unsatisfactory. In comparison with the Fightback proposal, the superannuation policy allows for the abolition of the pre- and post-regime, as well as lump sum taxes, which would render the changes foreshadowed here unnecessary when we come to government. But it does demonstrate yet again that the Fightback proposals for superannuation are infinitely more simple and straightforward than the complex arrangement that we have had to live with since 1988.

The 90-day roll-over period is also worth referring to. Currently, a roll-over must generally be made within 90 days of the ETP becoming eligible to be received; otherwise the individual will become liable for taxation on it. The 90-day roll-over period is currently being abused, in that the ETP is received and invested for 90 days and then rolled over. It has been suggested, for example, that there are cases in which people could take the money and put it into a risky investment. They could lose their entire ETP in such a situation, and therefore get no benefit at the end of it and be required to go on the age pension. There is a lot to be said for reform in this area. Therefore, we support the proposals contained in this legislation.

The Bill also makes some reforms in regard to taxation of redundancy, early retirement and invalidity pensions. In addition to superannuation payouts, there are other payments which are currently given concessional treatment as ETPs; for example, a bona fide redundancy payment, an approved early retirement scheme payment or an invalidity payment. The current taxation of these payments is on a concessional basis, in that they are treated as if they were pre-1983 components of an ETP. Consequently, 5 per cent of their value is included in assessable income, with their taxation being able to be deferred if the amount is rolled over. Currently, there is no limit on the size of these contributions, although the amount is not being counted against a recipient's RBL.

The proposed change in the legislation places a limit on redundancy payments of $4,000 indexed, plus $2,000 indexed for each whole year of service with the employer concerned. These amounts will then be tax free. For amounts in excess of the tax-free element, taxation will be on an ordinary ETP basis—that is, the amount will be split into its pre- and post-1983 components and taxed accordingly. The tax treatment of invalidity payments will stay broadly the same; however, the post-June 1984 component will be tax free and not assessable against the individual's RBL.

These new arrangements would appear to represent a warranted tightening up of the system, especially in so far as golden handshakes are concerned, as these have often been used as a way of circumventing the reasonable benefit limits. The coalition is yet to fully address how it will treat the taxation of these elements of invalidity payments. Strictly, they are not to be seen as superannuation payments, but they are currently treated as such for taxation purposes.

Finally, I want to make some observations about the commencement arrangements and their financial impact. Exemptions from tax of the post-1984 invalidity components of those amounts which are within the limits will cost $20m in 1995-96. Other costs at this stage are insignificant. There are, however, some significant changes in relation to reasonable benefit limits involving the maximum amount of benefit a person is entitled to receive on a concessionally taxed basis.

The RBLs are currently calculated as a multiple of a person's highest average salary in any three consecutive years. They vary as follows: for example, up to $42,980 the lump sum RBL is 7; the pension RBL is 0.75. These vary up to over $79,810, where the lump sum RBL is 3 and the pension RBL is 0.35. Consequently, a minimum RBL also operates. The base lump sum for an RBL is $188,180 and the base pension is $302,420.

Under this legislation the Bill proposes to introduce a flat dollar RBL amount, which is a significant improvement in the system—it is certainly less complex—and the limit on lump sums will therefore be $400,000 indexed, with a total RBL of $800,000 indexed. Excess benefits will be taxed at the individual's marginal tax rate, as is currently the case. People who have already accrued benefits that are within their existing RBLs, but in excess of the new limits, will be allowed to retain those entitlements as their new RBL.

The Bill also transfers the administration of the RBLs from the Insurance and Superannuation Commission to the Australian Taxation Office, which is probably a step in the right direction, in view of the massive complexities and difficulties which many people who have retired over the last two years have found in their dealings with the Superannuation Commission over their entitlements.

The flat dollar RBLs represent a very significant simplification of the system—as I outlined—and a substantial clamp down on the level of subsidy provided to individuals' retirement incomes. Nevertheless, the lump sum RBL is still very generous and will do little to address the problem of double-dipping for the vast majority of workers.

The coalition's retirement income policy in fact abolishes the RBL regime altogether. We have replaced it with the first $60,000 indexed of an accrued benefit to be taken as a lump sum, and 50 per cent of the remaining benefit thereafter subject to a maximum lump sum of $300,000 indexed. Unlike Labor's proposed regime, there will be no maximum on accrued benefits.

The transitional arrangements proposed by the Government are much tougher than those proposed by the coalition, especially for high net worth individuals. For example, an individual with an accrued benefit of $400,000 as at 1 July 1994 will face a maximum lump sum limit of $400,000 after that date under Labor, but a maximum lump sum limit of $700,000 under the coalition. Furthermore, an individual with an accrued benefit of $800,000 on 1 July 1994, who experiences growth in that amount, will be liable to pay tax at the maximum marginal rate on that real growth when the benefit is received, but under the coalition will only pay a maximum of 5 to 10 per cent tax.

It is also important to confirm that senior executives who are currently under arrangements which may have been in place for some years will be fully protected under the coalition's proposals. In fact they will be better off than under some of these proposals outlined by the Government.

The fundamental proposal contained in the coalition's policy is directed at the need to give everybody in the work force, whether permanent or part time employed, whether male or female, adequate access to superannuation. One would have to say that after nearly 10 years of constant reform, that outcome has still not been achieved by the present Government. I will give a small example of this: a female in the work force who may be covered by superannuation—and she would still be the minority of females in the work force, I should hasten to add—who leaves the work force, say, for family reasons, is only able to continue to remain in what I describe as mainline superannuation for up to two years.

The coalition's approach to females in the work force in relation to superannuation is far more liberal. We have effectively said that, whereas the lump sum contribution benefit is limited to $300,000 for an individual, it is in fact $600,000 for a couple. We really do not mind how that second payment is made. For example, if a woman leaves the work force, either on a part time or temporary basis or permanently leaves the work force, and her husband wishes to continue to make some contributions towards her superannuation, he may continue to do so and his wife will benefit, therefore, from having her own private superannuation upon retirement.

Under the current rules, the woman who leaves the work force may only remain in superannuation for a maximum of two years. This has raised a number of very important related issues, that is, whether or not there are in place sufficient bridges to assist women who may have broken periods of service in the work force. As a direct means of assisting those women, especially the majority who are in part-time or temporary less than permanent occupations, many of whom at the present time have no superannuation coverage, we have introduced a new concept called retirement savings accounts. They are effectively like bank accounts. They are managed like a bank account. Money is put into the account; it gains interest; the interest will be under the very generous tax arrangements under Fightback, which effectively provides a 25 per cent rebate. At the end of a period of being out of the work force, or if a person transfers to an employment opportunity where there is access to a normal mainline superannuation scheme, he could transfer the resources in the retirement savings account into that fund. Alternatively, it could be the other way around: a woman may have an RBL which she is particularly happy with and be prepared to continue with that arrangement, which her employer would be able to fund directly into her retirement savings account if she so wished.

We are aiming for a fair and equitable system of superannuation which covers and gives opportunities to everyone in the work force. We believe it is absolutely unacceptable to persevere with a system where the average worker gets a benefit after tax and superannuation of less than 16c in the dollar, whereas the high income earner has a benefit in excess of 33c in the dollar. Under the proposals which we have introduced—the rebate system of 25 per cent on contributions—all income earners will be effectively put on a similar taxation base, and surely that is what it should be.

For far too long in the Australian superannuation system we have had a case of the haves and the have nots. The haves have tended to be people in the higher income brackets with access to superannuation as a normal component of their salary packages. Regrettably, this has not been the case for the vast majority of workers for far too long. While we support the extension of superannuation into the whole work force, as has been the objective of government policy over recent years, we do not support the belief that it should be compulsory up to 12 per cent contributions by employers as is proposed by the Government legislation. Quite the contrary. The point has been made, both by industry and by members of the Government, that, under current circumstances in particular, additional add on labour costs mean people's jobs. Various estimates of between 60,000 and 80,000 lost jobs will be the direct outcome of having a compulsory superannuation system covered in this Bill tonight. This means that the employer will make the major, if not the total, contribution. A pathetic level of compensation in terms of taxation is provided to lower income earners under this legislation and simply guarantees that, unless the employer makes the contribution, it will not be worth while for the employee to do so.

Perhaps that is the most fundamental point on which the Government and the Opposition part ways in this critical area of social policy. We believe that people should have access to tax rebates on an equal footing, irrespective of the level of their income. That is something the Government has fundamentally denied in this legislation.

So the changes in this legislation are important. Some of these changes are welcomed by the Opposition; others we regard as retrograde steps. But fundamentally we believe that, while we are accepting that the current level of compulsory contribution will remain in place as at the next election, after that date continuing increases in superannuation should essentially be the subject of negotiation between employers and employees. Side by side with that, we believe that the ideal system of superannuation is one where the employer and the employee agree to make a contribution, both towards their ultimate retirement income support.

The sad result of the legislation we have before us tonight is this: for the vast majority of low income workers, even under the proposals in this Bill, based as they are on the presumption of being in the work force for up to 40 years, it simply means that while the Government says the objective of its proposal is to take people out of the welfare system, so they will not be required to receive pensions, most of those people will still get pensions, because many of them have broken periods of service in the work force. They have not been offered proposals such as retirement savings accounts to act as bridges for those periods out of the work force.

Consequently, in many respects we believe that this legislation is not truthful to its purpose. It is not genuinely saying to the Australian people: these are the facts, and this is what your contribution should be; this is the level of benefits you should accept. We believe, under current circumstances especially, that to place in the hands of the employer virtually the total responsibility for providing superannuation must ultimately mean a lowering of standards of living and a lowering of take-home pay for workers. Employers cannot extend and expand the base of superannuation contribution, especially up to 12 per cent, and at the same time talk about increasing wages unless there is a substantial increase in basic national productivity and productivity in the individual workplace to make that attainable. One would have to say that, on the record of the last decade or so, the level of productivity in this country leaves much to be desired.

While this legislation does contain some advances in this very complex area of national policy, we regret that the Government has not been ambitious enough to take and face the realities facing both the work force and employers for the benefit of a retirement income for all Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Taxation Laws Amendment (Superannuation) Bill is yet another chapter in this Government's proud record of reform in the area of superannuation policy, as it has been in a number of areas where the social justice elements have been at the forefront. The Keating Government believes in enabling lower income workers to live better in retirement through a mixture of the pensions. Superannuation is one of the fundamental social justice issues facing Australia today. On 30 June the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) released a statement, Security in retirement—planning for tomorrow today, which outlines a coordinated and comprehensive framework for retirement income policy in this country well into the next century.

PARA.TAB: There are now three clearly defined ways in which people will have income in their retirement provided for. The first way is through the age pension and a social security system. Although those opposite have always been quick to characterise people in receipt of social security payments as parasites and undeserving, they should recognise that in the past, due to the neglect of previous conservative governments, superannuation was simply not an option for many Australians. The proposals that they have in their so-called Fightback package do nothing at all to improve the opportunities of Australians to live a better life in their retirement and to provide for their retirement—in particular, when one considers the voluntary aspect that the Opposition wishes to bring to superannuation.

Until this Government came to power, superannuation benefits were restricted to those in upper and middle income areas and workers generally in the Public Service or some white collar areas. Very few blue collar workers had superannuation available to them. While the reforms introduced by this Government have meant that most Australian workers will be able to provide adequately for their own retirement, this Government will not walk away from helping those unable to secure such a nest egg for their retirement. In addition to this part of the retirement incomes policy, the other two tiers of the policy are the compulsory and voluntary superannuation arrangements. This Bill introduces the measures announced in the Treasurer's statement on superannuation in June that will introduce changes to the voluntary and compulsory superannuation systems.

The first area of change is in relation to rebate and deduction arrangements for personal superannuation contributions. The changes to rebates of superannuation contributions will provide greater support to low to middle income employees who receive support from their employers for superannuation contributions. The new rebate will be 10 per cent of personal superannuation contributions up to $1,000, with this maximum gradually being phased out once the employee's income is greater than $27,000. A rebate is no longer available once a person's income is more than $31,000. This new rebate regime is simpler and more equitable than the one which existed previously, with a person's eligibility for tax concessions no longer depending upon the support received from the employer for the provision for that person's retirement.

It is true that some people will receive reduced tax concessions on their contributions. These people should keep it in mind that they will receive other tax concessions in the area of superannuation. The introduction of a superannuation guarantee charge has seen the extension of superannuation to many workers not previously covered. While the reduction of tax concessions will save the Federal Government around $230m, the introduction of the SGC will cost the Federal Government around $400m in revenue in the next financial year. The Government is continuing to invest in a strong superannuation system as a cornerstone of its retirement incomes policy.

The existing taxation deduction arrangements will continue for people who do not receive employer superannuation support, and for the self-employed. These amendments to rebates and deductibility will come into effect from the beginning of this financial year. Another important feature of this Bill is that it will introduce limits on deductions allowed for superannuation contributions allowed to employers and the self-employed. From 1 July 1994, the amount of deductions available to an employer will be $9,000 for employees under the age of 35, $25,000 for an employee between the ages of 35 and 49, and $62,000 for people over 50 years. If an employer employs 10 or more people, an employer will be able to use a standard contribution limit, to be an amount calculated by multiplying $25,000 by the lowest number of employees employed during the year. These measures, along with the changes to the reasonable benefit limits, will increase revenues by $20m in 1995-96.

Also contained in this legislation are changes to the rolling over of eligible termination payments, better known as ETPs. At present, employees can elect the amount of each component of the termination payment that they want to roll over. This in effect enables people who began contributing before 1983 to avoid a large of amount of the tax on the post-June 1983 parts of their eligible termination payments. The changes contained in this Bill will close this particular loophole. People will still be able to roll over their undeducted contributions and concessional payments, but they will have to take a number of steps to identify the extent to which the roll-over amount is made up of their components.

This legislation also includes measures that will increase the attractiveness of pensions and annuities as a form of taking superannuation. Annuities provide a stable source of retirement income for many Australians, ensuring that they have enough to live on comfortably for the rest of their lives. It is often considered that most Australians just wish to take a lump sum and become some sort of investment people themselves. But many Australians who worked in a nine to five or seven to four job, or whatever the hours may have been over their working life, and who have been used to getting a weekly, fortnightly or monthly pay cheque, when they retire and get this huge lump sum in many cases finish up with extensive worries about how they are going to invest that money. What people want in retirement is a simple retirement and a regular income, as they have been used to all their life, so they can get on with enjoying their retirement.

We often consider things are wrong in our society when people just want to take that lump sum. From my own experience with people I have encountered in this areas, I do not believe that they want that at all. They would rather have a simple retirement, as long as their retirement income is guaranteed, and that is the important part. This Government's commitment to superannuation will ensure that, as distinct from the policies of those opposite.

This Bill simplifies what has until now been a complex taxation law surrounding pensions and annuities through the introduction of a flat 15 per cent rebate on superannuation pensions that are paid from tax superannuation funds and on annuities that are paid for through rolled over determination payments. This change means that no tax will be payable on rebatable superannuation pensions and annuities under $17,300 in today's terms. This new rebate will be introduced from 1 July 1994. By encouraging people to take their superannuation pay-out in the form of a pension or annuity, the Government is not only helping people to provide for a decent lifestyle in retirement but is also reducing the cost of pensions and other social security payments in the future. In effect, people who are able to benefit from superannuation in retirement will have a better lifestyle through having a guaranteed payment, and they will be able to get a better income than they would from social security benefits. (Quorum formed)

I thank my colleagues for coming in here. This is the most disgraceful display that I have ever seen from the Opposition, particularly coming from the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) who before dinner showed that he had no interest in superannuation for the people of this country. He had to call a quorum to get himself in here. He turned around tonight and called this lousy stunt. We did not interrupt his speech tonight, yet he turned around and pulled this rotten stunt. It just goes to show how little concern the honourable member for Bradfield has for the people of this country and for providing for a decent retirement for them. All he wants to do is to drive them away, and that is what he has done here tonight. It is an absolute disgrace.

The honourable member for Bradfield tries to hold up the Fightback package as some sort of lovely display. But he does not want to provide any sort of retirement income for Australians. He wants to go back to the bad old days where people were denied income in their retirement. People have been denied superannuation because of the lousy tory governments under Menzies and the like, who failed to respond to the need and failed to do anything about providing for a decent retirement for Australians. I am talking about the mothers and fathers of those opposite. That shows what a lousy lot they are on that side of the Parliament. They have no concern at all for people.

It is an absolute disgrace and an outrage that the honourable member for Bradfield has pulled this stunt here tonight. It is about time that he realised that we are talking about a very serious matter here—about Australia's future and the future of Australian people in their retirement. The honourable member for Bradfield had the audacity to leave the chamber and then come back in and pull this stunt because he did not want to stay here and listen to what we had to say.

I realise that I have only about half a minute left because of the lousy stunt pulled by the honourable member opposite who pretends to care for the Australian people. He, like the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), has no care for people whatsoever. We have only to look at what happened in Victoria today to see where this lot will be going. Today 100,000 people in Victoria told their mate down there, Kennett, just what they thought of him—and that is what they will do with this lot opposite when we come to face them at the next election. People will reject all the nasty policies that this lot have put forward—what they want to do to workers in their retirement and with their lousy industrial relations policies, which will be rejected, like those of Kennett have been today. Clearly, the 100,000 people down there today have got stuck into this lot. It is an outrage that this lot would pull this stunt here tonight to stifle debate on the very important issue of superannuation for the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have probably cooled down after that outrage before from the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly). I thought that he might like to jump up and explain a few of his actions as well. The amendments proposed by the Government are very important and form a very integral part of the legislation before us tonight. The amendments extend measures in the Bill that allow superannuation contributions based on earnings of a `standard employee' to be acceptable when calculating for the superannuation guarantee charge to apply to all employers that made contributions under industrial awards in place before 21 August 1991. These amendments increase the effectiveness of the operation of the superannuation guarantee charge and increase its fairness.

PARA.TAB: Employers that have been making adequate provisions for their employees' retirement will not be penalised. That is important to note, too, because there are a lot of employers who do the right thing by their employees and provide for their retirement, and have been doing so for some time. They will not be affected in the main by the superannuation guarantee charge, because they have already had very strong commitments to their employees. Not all employers are like the members of the Opposition, who do not care about the average Australian worker—but that is what we have to put up with from these people opposite.

This legislation has already been amended to spread out the introduction of the SGC to take into account the effects of the SGC on small business and employment levels. For retirement incomes policy to be effective, an element of compulsion has to be introduced. It is the compulsion element that is absolutely important, and it is something that the Opposition does not have in its Fightback package. It talks about voluntary contributions. That has failed continually in this country and overseas, and it will always fail. The voluntary aspect of superannuation contributions cannot and will not work. I understand that the Opposition knows that, yet it wants to persist with it. It wants to go back to the bad old days and not have employees guaranteed a benefit for their retirement.

The amendments add to what we have already put forward here tonight. I believe that they are worthy of support, and I am sure the Opposition will support them. The Opposition is talking about supporting most of the legislation put here tonight, because I know that it believes that the amendments that we are putting forward are crucial. Even those who want to support the Fightback package realise the benefit of what we are putting forward here.

A purely voluntary system would have a detrimental economic effect in the long term, which I have already spelt out. We do not penalise businesses that have been looking after their workers, but we are cracking down on businesses that are not looking after their workers' long term interests. That is very important.

These amendments are crucial and add to the milestones in this Government's superannuation policies. We have an outstanding record of looking after people in retirement and we will continue with that. There have had to be major changes to superannuation legislation over recent years. This has had to happen in order to fix up the complex system, or the inadequacies that were in the system, before the Labor Government came to power.
