TALK.START.PARA: —The Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) provides for financial assistance grants to the States and to institutions for higher education purposes. The measures in the Bill that relate to the funding of higher education are, in a number of cases, drawn directly from the Opposition's Fightback program, and I shall identify those. The Opposition is pleased to see that this Government, which has run out of its own ideas, is prepared to accept ideas which have been put forward by the Opposition to improve the higher education system.

PARA.TAB: The Bill, however, also has another purpose: to seek to entrench compulsory student unionism. The provision in this Bill, in clause 66, is quite unacceptable to the Opposition, and in committee we will be moving to delete this clause from the legislation.

The Opposition will be drawing the attention of the House to the fact that the funding framework which is represented in this piece of legislation has been a drastic failure in terms of, and measured against, the need to produce a higher education system of world class standard. We propose an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill. I now move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

"whilst not opposing the passage of this Bill, the House condemns the Government for persisting with its flawed funding framework for universities, a framework which has led to overcrowding, staff shortages, huge unmet demand, and a severe decline in research infrastructure, and for its continuing attack on students' rights to freedom of association".

A number of aspects of this legislation have been taken directly from the Opposition. The Opposition has led debate on reform of the higher education system, particularly on measures which are necessary to retrieve the system from the disaster which fell upon it following the White Paper of 1988 and the so-called Dawkins changes which have done it a great deal of damage.

PARA.TAB: This Bill rolls capital funding into recurrent funding. We believe that this is a measure which should have been taken some time ago. It is a measure which the Opposition has advocated for some years, and it is a measure which has the advantage that it allows institutions to plan their own capital developments without being dependent on political discretion, on the political whims of the day, to decide whether they receive those capital funds. The Opposition has no complaint about the rolling in of capital funding.

The Bill also increases the number of postgraduate research awards by 200. This was advocated by the Opposition in the Fightback package. However, the Government's measures do not go the full distance towards the proposals put forward by the Opposition. They fail in this respect: the Opposition advocated not only that the number of postgraduate research awards should be increased but also that the stipend for these awards should be increased by some $2,000.

In our view this is necessary to attract not merely students into the postgraduate research areas, but to attract the very best students. It is true that there is a big demand for these awards. Unfortunately it is not the case that the best students in all cases can be attracted to apply for these awards because they can be better remunerated elsewhere. Hence, we believe that there should be an increase in the stipend going to students, as well as an increase in the number of awards.

It must be said, however, that one of the reasons this is so essential is that the reforms and changes that the Government has made to higher education since 1988 have had a very demoralising effect on academic staff and have significantly reduced the attractiveness of an academic career, particularly for the very bright young students who find that they can be better rewarded outside the university system or better rewarded internationally. Of course, we are losing many of the brightest of our research graduate students and academic staff to the United States, to Canada and to Great Britain where academic salaries have not declined in the way that they have in Australia relative to international standards. While we welcome the number of postgraduate research awards being increased, the Government has still not adopted a satisfactory approach in this area to address the problems which the upheaval induced by the former Minister for Employment, Education and Training has produced.

The Bill also provides for direct grants to institutions. That is a measure which will be very useful to the Opposition when it comes into government because it will facilitate the introduction of the funding of higher education through the national education awards system or, as it is sometimes called, the voucher proposal. It avoids the bureaucracy of the States and takes away from the States the opportunity which the more financially stretched amongst them have used, particularly the late Victorian Labor Government, to hold onto those funds for a period in order to obtain the benefit of the income from interest on those funds before passing them to institutions.

A further measure in this Bill which was also directly taken from the Fightback package was the decision to increase the discount on the up-front payment of HECS from 15 per cent to 25 per cent. We believe that is a more realistic discount rate, given the cost and the financial implications of paying those fees up front. It is an advantage to the community to encourage the payment of fees up front in that way. We are not surprised to see the Government taking over the Fightback initiative. We might think from this list that the Government has largely run out of creative ideas in this area and that it has come to rely very heavily on the coalition for any good ideas which may come forward to improve the quality of the higher education system.

Another idea of the Government is funded in this Bill which, it is quite clear, the Government does not understand the implication of, but of which I make mention here; that is, the open learning initiative. This is a provision which was described by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) in the Budget as making a university degree available to everybody with a television set and a letterbox. This is an absurd notion. It shows the total lack of grasp the Treasurer has, as exhibited during his time in this portfolio, of what is required to provide a university education.

The Government is aiming at university education on the cheap. Indeed, if it is true that a university education can be obtained through the letterbox and the television screen and that it can be provided as cheaply as the Government apparently believes it can, the higher education system will be in a good deal of anxiety at the prospect of significant further cuts to its own funding to bring the funding for on-campus courses into line with the funding for off-campus courses. There appears to be absolutely no difference in quality, yet the difference in cost is something like $7,000 per student.

It is very obvious to anybody who thinks about this that there is a major hole in the Government's thinking in this area. The hole is that the Government is proposing simply to fund the open learning initiative for several years and then to make it self-funding. Can it be self-funding on the fees which the Government has set for it—fees of the order of the HECS charge—$2,500?

The answer, which everybody in the system knows, is that it cannot be self-funding at that level and that there will have to be a deregulation of fees. That means that the Government is pursuing a policy which inevitably will lead to a deregulation of fees for undergraduate courses. The Government's funding arrangements for higher education—which the Industry Commission described last year, in the most thorough examination which has yet been made of those arrangements, as fundamentally flawed—are breaking down. Those arrangements are not viable. The Government is hoping to keep them afloat until the election and to represent falsely to the public that it has the answers to the problems that its policies have caused. But, if there is one clear message in the open learning initiative, it is that the funding arrangements are on the way out, because the Government has already accepted the principle of fees charged by universities for undergraduate courses.

The Government is also misrepresenting to the public the fact that the open learning initiative will in some way or other make a contribution to the unmet demand. The unmet demand problem is, of course, another of the problems caused by the current funding arrangements, because the Government has taken the stand that it will not allow universities in this country to create additional places for Australian students. It will allow them to do so for overseas students—and there are some 17,000 of these students in the system now for whom the universities have created additional places—but there are 50,000 qualified Australian students, on a conservative estimate, who cannot get places, and the Government will not allow the universities to create places on campus for these students. It is now saying that those students can pay for places off campus for the open university courses, even though it knows that these students will not be able to get a degree through the open learning initiative in the foreseeable future.

A total lie is being told to the community about the implications of the open learning initiative for unmet demand. The Government is not facing up to the problem of unmet demand. It will eventually have to face up to it. Any government would have to face up to it. The coalition has put forward the only proposals which hold out the prospect that Australian students will be able to get additional places.

I cannot leave this point without making the further point to this House that at present many year 12 students in this country are sitting down for their end of year assessments and the pressure on them is enormously increased by the Government's approach to this issue. They know that they face a sudden death cut-off if they do not reach the quite arbitrary cut-off marks for university admission which will have to be imposed by the institutions because of the Government's policies. Under a freeing up of this system, if the Government were to allow universities to create additional places on campus for Australian students, those students would know that there would be no sudden death cut-off. They would have a chance if they did not get a government funded place to get a place if someone would sponsor them or if their family were prepared to make a financial effort. They could get a place and there would be a prospect of them continuing their tertiary education.

At the present time that is not so. These students are suffering very grievously at the present time because of the very rigid policy of regulation of universities, contrary to the wishes of the universities. Quite contrary to the views of the Australian Vice-Chancellor's Committee, these students are suffering because this Government, for ideological reasons, will not shift in this aspect of its policy.

There is an obvious solution to this, and that is the solution that I was very interested to see Professor Peter Karmel, probably the most respected educational administrator in this country, advocating in his recent Robert Menzies oration. He said that there is no doubt whatever in his mind that in terms of the resourcing of the system, in terms of the number of places, in terms of the quality and diversity of the system, the deregulation of the universities and the need to have their traditional freedoms restored to them is absolutely essential. The Government will not do that, but the Opposition will. That is why we are able to commit ourselves to a higher education system which addresses these issues, which has genuine incentives for quality, which will create more places and which will be better resourced.

I want to draw the attention of the House particularly to clause 66 of this legislation. This is a disgraceful attempt to channel taxpayers' money to the Government's mates in the student unions, with the very obvious intention of locking in their support for the Government for the next election campaign, at the taxpayers' expense. This clause states that if a State successfully legislates to give students freedom of association; if a State legislates as, for example, the new Victorian coalition Government might do, to give students the right to join or not to join a student organisation; and if students exercise their right to decline to join and the union loses funds as a result of the fact that it cannot appeal to students when they are free to choose or not to choose to join the union, the Government proposes, through this section of the Act, to make up the shortfall in the union's income with taxpayers' money.

There are two aspects to this provision. One is that the Government has a completely hands-off attitude towards students' rights. It will not act to ensure equal rights for students. If students' rights are infringed upon by institutions, that is okay so far as the Government is concerned. If a university decides that it will deny a student the right to enrol, to get his exam results or to graduate in order to force him to join a union, as far as this Government is concerned that is all right.

The Government defends this on the totally spurious ground that if it were to act to defend the human rights of students it would be infringing on university autonomy. Have we ever heard the Government argue in any other circumstance that the autonomy of an institution, any institution in this society, is more important than the defence of basic human rights? No, we have not. Yet in this case the Government is trying to convince the public that the reason it will not give students equal rights to freedom of association with every other section of the community is that it does not want to infringe on the autonomy of universities.

The universities themselves and the Australian Vice-chancellor's Committee have recognised that there is a very significant issue of principle here, but it is not one which the Government has any interest at all in advancing. Of course, the reason is very obvious. These student unions are generally dominated by the student ALP Left. Remarkably, this is the very faction of the Labor Party of which the present Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services (Mr Baldwin) is a member. Of course, he would not act to defend the rights of students when he believes that from these student unions he will be able to get significant support during the election campaign.

Suppose a State government decides to give students the right to freedom of association. The Minister's view is: even if the students will not join or support the union, the union's income must not be allowed to be diminished. The Government will use the taxpayers' funds to bring the income of that union up to the expected level.

This Bill insists that institutions produce audited accounts to the Government to show that they have given the money to the student union. The Government is brooking no financial hanky-panky in that regard—that money is to flow straight through to the union. Is there any requirement in legislation to audit the union?

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

—As my colleague says, there is absolutely no attempt in this legislation to demonstrate that the Government is interested in the financial probity of these student unions. Indeed, they can spend this money on any purpose they choose.

PARA.TAB: We know what those purposes are; we have seen what they are. Every member of this House knows that student unions fund a very wide variety of causes. Many of them are highly political causes which have little support in the general community. For example, they may choose to give their funds to support a political organisation such as the Palestine Liberation Organisation. They may use them to fund a sexuality festival. They may use them to produce a handbook such as the one produced at the University of Technology in Sydney giving students a guide to the latest drugs that are available. Indeed, $15,000 was spent by the student union at that university on such a handbook. The Minister apparently believes that it is entirely appropriate that taxpayers' funds be used to fund these sorts of activities.

Then there is money for out and out political campaigns. We have seen some of those campaigns recently. We have seen the campaign mounted against Dr Chapman's recent report on the reform of Austudy. A very revealing article by Mark Whittaker appeared in yesterday's Australian which talked about the decline of mass student involvement in the activities of the student unions. In the article, Mr Whittaker made the point:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . what is left of the politicised student body is a small but hardcore fringe which has often used confrontation for maximum impact.

The article discusses the campaign by the National Union of Students against the Chapman report. It notes Dr Chapman's comment that he `faced what he saw as a massive campaign of lies'. The Minister thinks it is entirely appropriate that taxpayers' money be used to fund and support campaigns of this kind.

PARA.TAB: The National Union of Students has a budget of $1.5m, much of which, according to this article, it proposes to use in a campaign against the coalition's Fightback package. In particular, it will be campaigning against the coalition's policy to give students equal rights with the rest of the community with regard to freedom of association. If the Victorian Government, or any other government in this country, were to guarantee students the right to freedom of association and the students decided not to support these campaigns, the Minister believes it is entirely appropriate that taxpayers' funds be provided to the student unions so that they could mount these campaigns.

Let us not overlook the hypocrisy of these unions who campaign against a freeing up of the system while imposing a compulsory up-front fee—which is very regressive in its impact—on all students. The only compulsory up-front fee in the whole system of higher education is imposed by the Minister's mates in these unions. So much for their concern about a policy which allows students to invest in their education. That is impermissible, but it is quite permissible to allow students to invest in the political activities of these student unions. Indeed, it is quite permissible to compel them to invest.

Alongside the National Union of Students there stands an extremist organisation—the International Socialist Organisation. In this article by Mark Whittaker, its Sydney organiser, Dwayne Shulz, is reported to have said:

SPEECH.PARA: One of the basic tenets of the ISO is its belief in the overthrow of the State by people's revolution.

We have seen its violent activities in recent times. I doubt that it will ever be able to overthrow the state, but it will certainly indulge its extremism in violent demonstrations from time to time. Mr Whittaker says:

The ISO has a somewhat symbiotic relationship with the NUS, which is controlled by members of the ALP Left through its domination of most student representative bodies. The NUS provides the mass network, the basic organisation and the funds—
perhaps they will be taxpayers' funds after this legislation is passed—
to mount a decent protest. The ISO provides foot soldiers to put up posters. Both the NUS's and the ISO's people drum up support.

This is the world of extremist political activity which the Minister apparently thinks it is entirely appropriate to have the taxpayer support through section 66 of this legislation. He proposes to give the taxpayers' money to these bodies on a `no questions asked' basis.

PARA.TAB: This is one of the most disgraceful pieces of legislation to be put before this Parliament for a long time. It will be obnoxious to most Australians and it ought to be withdrawn. If it is not, I can tell the Minister that we will pursue this issue throughout the country and tell all those families struggling to make ends meet in the worst recession for 60 years that the Government plans to make them active contributors to the most extreme political nonsense that the Minister's mates in the student unions can devise. That is why we will be moving in committee to delete this clause.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly have pleasure in seconding the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Catley Dr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Higher Education Funding Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 and to oppose the amendment. Despite the speech that has just been given, this Bill is another step on the road to the expansion of the higher education system in this country which has been undertaken since 1983 by this Government. When this Government came to power, higher education was still the preserve of the minority—and a small minority at that—of the population. There was very restricted access to the higher education system even from among those one-third of students who completed year 12 at secondary school.

PARA.TAB: We had a very elitist and hierarchical system of education that moved to a pinnacle in higher education and in the postgraduate sector of the higher education system. I will not say that was solely the fault of the parties opposite. It is quite true that under the Menzies Government the higher education system was expanded in this country. When I first entered an Australian university Sir Robert Menzies was still Prime Minister and he clearly had a commitment to the expansion of that sector—but not to an extent that was consistent with aspirations for Australia to become a modern industrial society.

It is also true that under the Whitlam Government a commitment to higher education was entered into and in an effort, which was largely unsuccessful I must say, to expand access to the tertiary education system the Whitlam Government abolished fees for individual students and took over the funding of the higher education system from the States. However, at that stage the development of the higher education system languished, like the Australian economy, and then entered the Fraser coalition Government during which time there was stagnation and indeed, in some ways, a contraction of the higher education system.

It needs to be pointed out in regard to the amendment that the Opposition is suggesting, which talks about a huge unmet demand, that the condition faced by the higher education system in much of this country when this Government came to power was an inability to meet its quotas for the admission of students. Such was the demand for higher education that many universities were unable to attract enough students to comply with the funding arrangements. The Fraser Government at various stages proposed to close down sectors of higher education, including some engineering faculties, for that reason.

During the last nine years this Government has constructed the equivalent of 12 new universities. It has witnessed the retention rate at year 12 rise to over two-thirds of young people, and this is not due to the present recession since the climb in retention rates was in evidence well before it occurred, during the period of the 1980s boom; it has witnessed a huge increase in the participation rate by women in higher education, who now make up about 53 per cent of all students; and it has successfully implemented an equity and access program for various categories of disadvantaged students, including Aboriginal students. The Aboriginal people of this country now have an educated cadre of tens of thousands of Aboriginal people trained in tertiary education that will stand them in good stead over the next couple of generations as they take their place in the sun, fully in this community; among people of non-English speaking backgrounds, among people with disabilities, among people from remote locations, who are dealt with to some degree by the remote learning processes funded in the Bill, and also among people from lower socioeconomic categories, which is the polite way of talking about working class people in the 1990s.

As against these being the principal objectives of the Bill, I wish to make some remarks about the Opposition's moving of the amendment. I was interested to note that the Opposition claims that it has led the debate about tertiary education in this country, against a background, as I have pointed out, where this Government had to pick out a stagnant, languishing higher education system unable to meet, in many instances, its student quotas, grabbed it by the scruff of the neck and pulled it, with much cooperation from within the sector, into a modern mass higher education system. To say that this Bill steals many of its ideas from Fightback is another instance of one of the members of the front bench of the Opposition walking away from Fightback, and instead of saying, as occurred during the brave new world of 12 months ago, `How different we are; what radical reforms we have proposed', saying, `We have the same ideas as the Government, except it has taken them off us too quickly'. What are we going into—a bipartisan policy on tertiary education? Of course we are not. There are differences. There are differences of size, there are differences of equity and there are differences of access.

I hear people talking about the demoralisation of the staff. It is very difficult to be categorical about the morale of a staff in a sector that consumes about $4 billion of public money. I can find areas of academic staff that are demoralised for a whole variety of reasons. I can also find other areas of academic staff in universities in my seat—and there are two—who are enormously energised by the reforms that this Government has undertaken, particularly women. I had the great privilege of meeting three women professors—almost unheard of in the higher education sector—in one room and presenting them with a research award in order to write a biography of a political woman, Mary Lee, almost unknown by political scientists and historians until this time and to be celebrated as a result of her achievements in political activism 100 years ago.

We hear that the academic career is now no longer as attractive, which would make it very difficult to explain the large number of applications that are received by every academic position that we see advertised. We find that standards in our universities have declined and we find that in the same paragraph of a speech in which it decries the fact that so many of our successful postgraduate students have gone overseas to study in their leading universities where no doubt their substandard academic achievements are recognised at the highest level. I do not want to be flippant about academic standards. It is a very important subject. I note that in the newspaper only today it is reported that Minister Baldwin is addressing this problem, which is a complicated and difficult one to deal with. The advice that he is receiving from the Higher Education Council is to establish a committee for quality assurance for higher education because, left to itself, the record of the higher education system in ensuring its own quality has been something less than perfect. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: A higher education system—
I am quoting from the HEC—
that justly prides itself on its deep analysis of issues of consequence is sometimes strangely reluctant to examine its own process equally publicly and comprehensively . . .

And so we have puzzled as to how to deal with that problem. A special committee comprising persons from all the sectors who have an interest in the maintenance of the higher education system's quality—that is, the Vice-Chancellors Committee; FAUSA; the National Union of Students, so lambasted, and I will return to that; and the Business Council of Australia—will have an input into this process.

PARA.TAB: We find the criticism that there is an arbitrary cut-off point above which you enter universities and below which you do not. Does the Opposition seriously think that there is anything new in this process? Of course there is not. This has always been a characteristic of universities, except for the period 10 years ago when they could not get enough students into some of their courses. But it has typically been a condition of universities that they have to have entrance requirements and these are usually to be found in cut-off scores that are not arbitrary but are determined by the number of places that are available.

The Opposition is now proposing that in order to get around that proposition there be another arbitrary mechanism for entering university. (Quorum formed) The Opposition, in its amendment, says that the cut-off scores that determine entrance into universities and higher education are arbitrary. I have pointed out that it has always been the fashion to determine entrance into universities by intellectual quality which is traditionally, for better or worse, measured by the academic scores achieved at year 12 and matriculation or its equivalent.

The Opposition is now suggesting that we move to a different way of determining who gets in. That is not on the score achieved, accessible to everybody, but on the basis of what you can pay; that is, that the scarce resource provided by $4 billion worth of public funding across a sector that has been hugely expanded, in part to provide access and equity for the people of this country who have not hitherto had access to higher education, be determined not on the basis of intellectual merit and academic achievement, but on the basis of buying your way in.

Are we surprised at this proposition? Of course we are not. It is precisely the same intellectual apparatus and mechanism which arrives at the same conclusion for other sectors of this economy. It is the same conclusion that the Opposition has reached about health: you buy your way in. It is the same conclusion that it has reached about schooling: you buy your way in. It is the same conclusion that it has reached about child-care: you buy your way in. It is the same conclusion as it would reach about housing: you buy your way in. It is the same conclusion as it would reach about public broadcasting of information in this country: cut public provision and funding for access to information and produce it on a solely commercial basis of buying your way in. This is a withdrawal of government and public responsibility for the provision of scarce and important cultural resources and a reversion to market mechanism which for centuries produced an extremely hierarchical elitist and inaccessible system of higher education.

When we talk about traditional freedoms of universities, it must be recognised that this involves not just the capacity of scholars to criticise and critique society and its powerful, including ourselves—a traditional freedom that I would not for one minute seek to withdraw from university scholars—but also includes the traditional freedom of universities not to be accessible, to be elitist and not to be responsible to the public purse. In a situation where the taxpayer is providing over $4 billion worth of funding for universities, some responsibility and responsiveness to national needs must be accorded by the university sector.

It was interesting to note that an Opposition speaker went overboard when discussing these traditional academic freedoms. He suggested that there be full autonomy for one of our universities. Since that university is funded to the tune of almost $200m worth of taxpayers' money every year, I greeted his comments with somewhat bemused surprise—and some of my constituents with great pleasure—believing, wrongly as it turned out, that were this proposition to be carried, $200m would be liberated from that university and distributed proportionately to those universities, including two in my electorate, that were in need. Unfortunately, I found that this was neither the purpose of that proposal, nor did it reach the satisfactory conclusion of being passed by this House.

Before making some general remarks about the purpose of this Bill, I point out that the Opposition spokesman on this subject spent much of his speech—although I did not clock it precisely—possibly 50 per cent, dealing with the issue of student unions. There are problems with respect to student unions. Looked at from different perspectives, these problems manifest themselves in different ways. But the honourable member opposite resolved it in this way: there is Reds under them beds in them student unions! Some of them indeed—how scandalous—seek to overthrow the State. I would be deeply concerned about the condition of intellectual life in Australian universities were there not to—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello Mr P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Corporate Law Reform Bill 1992 deals principally with four areas: directors' duties, related party transactions, corporate insolvency laws and stock exchange settlement procedures. On the whole, the proposed amendments are for the good and for that reason, the Opposition will support the Bill as a whole. But the time allowed for the passage of this legislation is inadequate.

PARA.TAB: The Bill was presented by the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) on Tuesday last week and is being debated today. It is being guillotined through this Parliament with 51 other Bills, with only 40 minutes allowed to debate it. Forty minutes has been allowed in the Parliament of this country to debate a Bill that the Attorney-General has proclaimed—not entirely accurately, may I say—the most significant piece of legislation in terms of Australia's corporate law introduced during the life of this Parliament.

Because of the rush that has been involved, there are numbers of interested parties in Australia who are still seeking to make submissions and changes and amendments to the Act and who will not have the opportunity to do so. Indeed, as late as this afternoon I received submissions on defects in the Bill, defects that will need to be remedied at a later stage. If the Parliament had allowed adequate time to debate this legislation, we would be able to go into committee, move those amendments and have them debated and fixed now. We cannot because of the guillotine, that procedure of the Parliament that says a certain period of time, altogether too short a period of time, will be allowed to debate the Bill with no extension of the debate.

Unfortunately, this continues a sorry pattern in relation to corporations and securities legislation in this Parliament. When the current scheme was first enacted back in November 1990, debate was resumed after a week and the legislation guillotined through the Parliament with 39 other Bills. Eight months later, the Government did exactly the same thing with the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill of 1991. It brought the Bill on for debate a week after its introduction and guillotined it through the Parliament.

The Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) of 1991 and the Corporations (Unlisted Property Trusts) Amendment Bill 1991 fared no better. Those Bills were introduced one week and guillotined through the Parliament the next. Forty-five minutes were allowed to debate the Corporations Legislation Amendment Bill and three minutes for the Bill that froze unlisted property trusts in this country.

There are 215 pages in this Bill which has been allowed a total time for debate of 40 minutes. The Attorney-General cannot complain that this is the responsibility of somebody else. After all, he chairs the legislation subcommittee of the Cabinet. He is in a unique position to ensure, if he so chose, that there could be adequate and full debate in this Parliament, and he has failed to do so. Clearly, this is inadequate.

One of the reasons the Commonwealth took control in this area under the current scheme of Corporations Law was so that it could be said there would be one parliament in this country responsible for Corporations Law. Under the previous cooperative scheme six State parliaments were responsible through the Ministerial Council. One of the great selling points of the new scheme, a scheme which I have supported, was that there would be one parliament responsible and indeed one Minister responsible—the Minister being the Attorney-General who I believe sometimes regrets that he is responsible for the whole of the Corporations Law now as the current scheme operates.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, not the Corporations Law.

—The Minister is quite happy with the Corporations Law; it is just the rest of his portfolio that he is worried about. I now want to outline a few of the most important features of the Bill. The first relates to directors' duties—
—I'll miss you.

—The Minister would miss me. He would miss the fact that I pick up a lot of his errors that have to be corrected. I saw that the Attorney-General, in an attempted put-down of Senator Beahan who has fingered him, has said, `Senator Beahan wouldn't know, if you got him alone without the secretary of his committee and asked him some questions on the Corporations Law, how to answer them'. That is what the Attorney-General was quoted as saying in the Australian earlier this week. I have in my mind's eye getting him alone without his Department and administering the same set of questions to him. I do not think he would do any better than Senator Beahan.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the question of directors' duties. An exposure draft of this Bill was released in February 1992. It proposed some major changes to subsection 232(4) of the Corporations Law which deals with directors' duties of care and diligence. In addition to rewording the subsection, the Government proposed to introduce a shopping list of matters to which a court would be required to have regard in determining whether a director had breached his duty of care and diligence under the subsection. The changes proposed were hotly criticised by the Opposition and by business groups.

There were three main areas of concern: first, the Government intended to introduce an objective standard for that part of the company director's duty of care which relates to skill, in the sense of knowledge, experience and competence. There was a strong implication in the explanatory paper that judges would not be required to consider the director's circumstances when determining whether the director had breached his duty of care and diligence.

Effectively, the Government proposal could have set a uniform objective standard of skill for every director of each of Australia's 900,000 registered companies, which might range from the $2 shelf company to BHP. This, of course, was ludicrous. The diversity of boards of directors, consequent on the diversity of activities of Australia's companies, is inconsistent with a uniform objective standard of skill. It is nonsense to suggest that the same level of skill is expected of every director of every one of Australia's 900,000 companies. Boards, particularly of major companies, should and do include a range of skills and experience.

In fact, a uniform objective standard of care for directors can work both ways. Just as it would be saying that the same skills that are required of a BHP director would be required of a $2 company, which might be an over-requirement, it could also work as an under-requirement because some companies do have specialists—they might be accountants, financial advisers or lawyers. We would expect of those people who have special qualifications that they would bring to account their special expertise in exercising their skill. We would hope, for example, that somebody who is on a board because he or she is a qualified accountant would be expected to show a little more skill in that area than the ordinary lay company director in the ordinary $2 company. An objective uniform standard of directors' duties could require too much from some people and too little from others who have been held out to shareholders, being directors of companies, as having special expertise and of whom shareholders would be expected to use their skill or competence in their particular area.

The second defect with the Government's proposed check list of factors relevant to the duty of care was that it failed to improve the clarity of the content of the duty and arguably imposed new substantive duties on directors. Thirdly, in practical terms, the check list could have led to a situation where directors addressed themselves to the process rather than the substance of their duties—where directors focused on the check list which they went through one by one rather than focusing on the substantive part of their duties.

After a good deal of argument, the Attorney-General came to the conclusion that his original proposal was wrong, at least in respect of the proposed check list. The proposed check list has been discarded, as has the proposal to introduce an objective standard of skill for directors. The decision to discard that proposal was the right one. It means that the Bill as it comes into this Parliament is better than the original proposal.

The Government has come to the position where it does not really intend any change to the law as regards directors' duty of care. While the Bill still proposes to reword subsection 232(4), paragraph 83 of the explanatory memorandum states:
The Government considers that proposed subsection (4) does not change the law, but merely confirms the present position . . .

SPEECH.PARA: That is an interesting position to have—to come to the Parliament with a proposal to change a section of an Act which is explained as not changing the law. In fact, one might really wonder why we are changing the wording of the Act if the intention is not to change the meaning of the law, which is a puzzling question. I suspect the answer lies in the fact that the Government, originally having proposed quite a major change which, as it turned out was a bad idea—in the end it was recognised to be a bad idea by the Government—still felt it had to do something, so it came to the Parliament with a proposal which it explained was not intended to change the law at all; nonetheless, it was a proposal. I think the best explanation of how this particular section came about is that it ought to be seen as a face-saver. However, it is better to be landed with a face-saver than a proposal that was more substantially flawed, as was the Government's original proposal.

PARA.TAB: Regrettably, the Government has not seen fit to include a statutory business judgment rule in the Bill. Whilst the explanatory memorandum and the Attorney-General's second reading speech endorse statements in cases such as Harlowe's Nominees to the effect that a court should not second guess commercial decisions made by directors in good faith and not for irrelevant purposes, the Government should have gone further and introduced a business judgment rule into the statute.

Such a rule was recommended by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs which looked at this matter under the chairmanship of Senator Cooney; it was recommended by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs chaired by the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch); and it was recommended by the Companies and Securities Law Review Committee. There is no good reason why it is not included in the statute—it ought to be. The argument against it, which the Government has used, is that the courts can develop a business judgment doctrine through the case law and, therefore, there is no need to include it in the statute.

In justification of that, the proposition has been put that in the United States it was the courts that developed the business judgment rule. But it overlooks one key difference, and that is that almost all of the law in this country in relation to corporations is now in the statute. Why should we leave one aspect to be developed by the common law when we have chosen to regulate nearly the whole of other corporate regulation in a statute? If the statute is intended to be a code and to codify all the responsibilities, rights and duties of a corporation, it should—if it is believed, as I believe, that a business judgment rule is desirable—include a business judgment rule as well. The fact that the Government's Bill does not include a business judgment rule means that the Bill is lacking.

The second issue I wish to raise is civil penalty provisions. The Bill also decriminalises certain directors' duties by providing that breaches of those provisions are no longer subject to criminal sections unless committed with dishonest intent. When a person contravenes one of those provisions, the court will have the power to make a civil penalty order prohibiting the person from managing a corporation for a specified period, or imposing a pecuniary penalty of not more than $200,000, or both. An application for a civil penalty order will generally be made by the Australian Securities Commission, and the matter will be tried in accordance with the civil standards of proof, the civil rules of evidence, and the civil practice and procedure. The Opposition will support these provisions.

We believe that the statute should draw, throughout the statute—not just in respect of those provisions that are dealt with in this Bill—a clear delineation between conduct that is considered criminal and conduct that is considered civil. In respect of conduct that is considered criminal, which would be conduct that involves an element of moral turpitude of some kind or another, there should be criminal sanctions and criminal procedures. In respect of negligence and the like, which involves a breach of duty but no moral turpitude, there should be civil proceedings and civil sanctions.

The legislation should draw a distinction between civil enforcement and criminal enforcement. Once that clear distinction has been drawn and regulation has been separated, even if it is within one agency, we can avoid the situation which we most recently had of arguments breaking out between the Australian Securities Commission, which would prefer to be a civil regulator, and the Director of Public Prosecutions, which would prefer to see the ASC concentrate more on criminal proceedings, where there was a turf, an ambit or a jurisdictional argument which held back the operation and enforcement of Corporations Law and led to the most unwieldy of solutions in the end—yet another body elevated over the two agencies, the National Steering Committee on Corporate Wrongdoing. If we drew that delineation in the statute and then in the administration, we would avoid those sorts of situations.

I now come to the part sometimes called `related party transactions', which relates to public companies giving financial benefits to related parties. The Government's proposal is to repeal section 234 of the corporations law, which deals with loans to directors, and replace it with 33 new sections dealing with financial benefits to related parties of public companies. Essentially, the provisions prohibit two types of related party transactions: that a public company must not give a financial benefit to a related party and that a child entity of a public company must not give a financial benefit to a related party of the public company. There are some exceptions to these general prohibitions, the most important being that an otherwise prohibited transaction will be permitted if it is submitted to and approved by a general meeting of the shareholders.

The provisions have had a long gestation. In December 1989, the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee produced a discussion paper proposing legislation dealing with loans to related and connected companies, and executive and intra-group remuneration. The paper met with criticism on the ground that it did not provide an adequate justification for sweeping and complex new legislation. Nonetheless, the Committee persisted with the proposals and produced a report in July 1991 with a draft Bill of 55 pages. The report justified the proposals on the ground that dishonest related party transactions were the cause of many corporate collapses in the 1980s.

By February of this year, the Government had a draft Bill; it had 60 pages of legislation on this topic. It ran into hot criticism from business groups and from the Opposition. Reliance had been placed on long and detailed black letter prescription, with the draftsmen attempting to specifically deal with every conceivable situation. The Government did not put forward hard evidence to justify the form in which the legislation stood, and the explanatory paper did not explain the necessity for the particular way in which the proposal was worked.

The Government responded to criticisms, for which I congratulate it, by setting up a part time working party to simplify the proposed provisions. That simplification has led to the proposal which now comes before the Parliament. While the Opposition concedes that the working party has been successful in simplifying it in some respects, we are concerned that there remain serious deficiencies in the provisions. More fundamentally, there is still no clear-cut, hard case example evidence of the kinds of transactions that are sought to be covered by these proposals and no explanation as why the current provisions are unable to cover them.

The explanatory memorandum almost builds a case against the proposal. It acknowledges that the real problem of the 1980s was lack of enforcement of the corporate laws that did exist. One must observe that directors of companies have always had an obligation to exercise their duties with due care and skill. If a company is giving a benefit that is on more generous terms than the market to a related company, the directors have an obligation to ensure that the interests of the giving company are looked after. There are examples in which directors properly discharging their duties brought cases to light. In the Quintex case it was the independent directors who finally belled the cat and blew the whistle on exorbitant remuneration to the management company, which brought an exposure of the affairs of that group.

As I have said before, the public company cannot give a financial benefit unless certain provisions are observed, one of which is that it is an arms length transaction and not giving a benefit that is better than market value; another is that there is a shareholder authorisation of the proposal. These provisions are very wide. The definitions of `child companies', `parent companies', and `related parties', which includes spouses, parents, sons, daughters, directors, parent entities and sibling entities, and the concept of control, which is picked up from the accounting standard, mean that there is a very wide class of transaction that can be brought into the net.

The combined effects of the definition of `indirect financial benefits' and the related party concept will mean that public companies and their subsidiaries will need to scrutinise every proposed transaction to ensure that it does not breach the Act. It will mean that these companies will require a great deal of advice and scrutiny, even where there is no suggestion whatsoever that something was being done for the enrichment of a related party, to ensure that they do not fall foul of the Act. Some less scrupulous companies will try to avoid the shareholder authorisation provisions by getting independent advice to say that this is at arms length, which is an easy way of getting around the whole transaction.

Other companies that will not take that way out will be forced to hold general meetings when they might be straightforward financial transactions between the companies, with all the costs that are associated with that. I believe there are other ways that we could look at to cover these sorts of situations. One of the ways in which it might be possible to cover these sorts of situations would be to empower the shareholders themselves to take action in the name of the company where the suggestion arises that a benefit is being given to a related party at better than market value.That is sometimes known as a statutory derivative action, where a shareholder can bring an action in the name of the company to stop that benefit going ahead.

That proposal has been regularly recommended by parliamentary committees which have looked at the matter. I believe that it is a very strong proposal. It even enjoys support from the business community, or some sections of it. It would empower shareholders themselves to scrutinise activities, and engage in a little bit of private law enforcement, if you like, in this particular area to cover those situations.

I turn now to the insolvency reforms. As a whole, the insolvency reforms proposed by the Bill will significantly improve the law and are welcomed by the Opposition. The new procedure for the administration of insolvent companies is set out in new part 5.3A. Under that part, directors of a company facing solvency difficulties will be able to appoint an administrator, who will have the benefit of a moratorium on actions against the company.

The primary task of the administrator will be to investigate the financial position of the company, with a view to making a recommendation to a meeting of creditors about what should be done in the longer term. I believe that this will be welcomed by business, and small business in particular, as currently where a company is going down it gets into this situation: if it trades on a director could be personally liable; if it is decided to stop trading the company will go down. A company will reach a certain stage where it cannot go on and cannot go back. Many of these companies go down, particularly in small business. It is a good proposal to give another alternative. I welcome the work in relation to this issue by Mr Harmer of the Australian Law Reform Commission, which was the genesis of this proposal to give the directors another option, to call in an administrator and try to do something to keep the company going.

But proposed section 436E would require an administrator to hold, within five days of his appointment, an initial meeting of creditors to possibly appoint a committee of creditors and/or to remove and replace the administrator. We are concerned that this provision will add unnecessarily to the cost and distract from the efficiency and the essential purpose of the administration. In the case of a large company placed under administration, it will be almost impossible for the administrator to hold a meeting of creditors within five days.

We are also concerned about other aspects, such as the personal liability of the administrator. The exposure draft made an administrator responsible only for debts incurred by the administrator during the administration period, but proposed section 443A now extends that liability to `liabilities and obligations . . . whether arising under an agreement, in tort, under a written or unwritten law or otherwise'.

The extension of personal liability of an administrator, including the extension of liability in tort, could seriously jeopardise the whole of the administration procedure. Few good insolvency practitioners will be prepared to take on administration where they may be liable under product liability laws—the same product liability laws which the Government is ill-advisedly still trying to extend, to the eternal risk of Australian manufacturers—for product liability, environmental damage and so on. The Opposition considers that it would be best to return to the provisions in the exposure draft.

I also note that there is no provision in part 5.3A to avoid provisions in agreements which provide for termination or modification upon a company being placed in administration. If the object of the new administration scheme is to assist in saving the business of a company, or to otherwise provide for a better result than if the company were immediately wound up, it seems to me it would be highly desirable for companies to be protected against provisions in contracts that operate to terminate or materially modify those contracts simply because the company has volunteered itself to administration.

Finally, I would like to say something about proposed section 588G, which will alter the circumstances in which a director may incur liability for insolvent trading. This is the problem I spoke about before. People can be personally liable if they allow the company to trade on when they have reasonable grounds to expect that it will be unable to pay its debts. They get into a situation where they cannot trade on and, of course, if they stop trading the company goes down anyway. The proposal is actually to stiffen that problem, because at the moment people incur personal liability if they allow a company to trade on when there are reasonable grounds to expect it will not be able to pay its debts.

The Government is changing that to reasonable grounds to `suspect' that it will not be able to pay its debts. `Suspect' is a very different word; it is wider. It will mean that directors are in a much more difficult position. They will have to sit around at the board meeting and say, `Should we be suspecting something here? Let's go out and look for a suspect. Let's go out and look for a suspect transaction, because if we don't find that suspect transaction, or if we had reasonable grounds and we should have found it, we may incur personal liability'. We are concerned about that. We do not believe that that is necessary. It is something that the Government has probably not turned its mind to, and I think it ought to, and it ought to reconsider its position.

In respect of stock exchange settlement procedures, the Bill makes amendments to the Corporations Law necessary to enable the Australian Stock Exchange to introduce a new clearing house electronic sub-register system. This will make the Australian Stock Exchange more competitive internationally and speed up security settlements. The reforms will benefit Australian business and are welcomed by the Opposition.

But the real game at the moment in respect of corporations law is simplification—re-thinking it and making sure it is a coherent whole. The Government's approach has been to knit these little patches, which it hopes one day to sew into a patchwork quilt, which when put together lack direction, lack cover and lack foresight and forethought. The great task is to start thinking back from basic principles as to what we need in our corporations law, how we are to simplify it and how we are to harmonise it to economic objectives. They will be the features of the coalition's approach in government to corporations law. We will have a complete review of the way in which it should operate as a prelude to simplification and clarification and enable the corporations law to encourage investment and recovery in the economy in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make two points in relation to the Corporate Law Reform Bill. The first question is in relation to directors' duties. This aspect of the legislation certainly did need improving. I say to the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) that there are substantial examples of directors not performing their duties. So proposed subsection 232A(4) of the Corporations Law is in my view a very important reform. I remind the House, as someone who comes from Western Australia, that the breaches of directors' duties are everywhere to be seen.

PARA.TAB: I also make the point that under proposed section 588G, in relation to insolvent trading, there are some cases that I am currently dealing with where there are breaches by directors of their duties, and there would certainly seem to have been breaches by directors in relation to trading while insolvent. It comes down to the situation of people losing their superannuation entitlements. In fact, they have never been paid across to a proper fund.

I applaud the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) for the reform in this area. I also make the point about related party transactions. Very clearly, the management companies that operated under the names of Alan Bond, Christopher Skase or Laurie Connell were there to do nothing more than milk the assets of the parent company. I believe this is a very important reform.

Subsection 232A(4), in relation to directors' duties, is of great substance. Directors should not be taking on the business of being a director in a corporation unless they carry with them the responsibility of carrying out their duties properly. In relation to related party transactions, Alan Bond's liquidator is trying to recover money that Bond has put into a superannuation fund to take it out of the reach of the liquidator. I believe this is a case where the public and the former shareholders want to see some justice done.

The general thrust of this legislation is to improve the standing of corporations law. I applaud the Attorney-General. I also make the point to the honourable member for Higgins that there are substantial consultative mechanisms now in place through the Joint Statutory Corporations and Securities Committee and the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee. So there are considerable processes for consultation. I wanted to take the time of the House to support these very important reforms in relation to directors' duties and related party transactions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank the honourable member for Stirling (Mr Ronald Edwards). I misunderstood my conversation with him on timing. I start where the honourable member for Higgins (Mr Costello) finished. May I say that, apart from his usual complaining about time for debate and all the rest of it, he did at least concede late in his little outburst that this Corporate Law Reform Bill was put out for an exposure draft in February, and probably the amount of exposure and consultation that it has had is unprecedented. Although many people may find this surprising, I thought that tonight his speech was almost gracious by his standards. We had the usual performance, but at least he did concede some things.

PARA.TAB: The last matter the honourable member mentioned was of course the stock exchange settlements, the CHESS scheme, which was at the request of the stock exchange, and that was naturally accepted by both sides of the House. Also, I want to spend a moment or two on the Harmer reforms; that is, the general insolvency provisions in the Bill which, as the honourable member for Higgins pointed out, came out of the Australian Law Reform Commission, and the work done by Mr Harmer. The honourable member did say that as late as today some representations had been made to him on some matters, and I think probably on the Harmer matter. Those representations were also made to my office.

I want to record how grateful we are for the enormous personal commitment that Mr Harmer has made to insolvency law reform in this country. He has continued right up until today to provide input. He has suggested a number of possible enhancements to this Bill before it is completed. The Government is looking at the suggestions, which I think were probably the matters raised with the honourable member for Higgins. It may be that some of them may be taken on board in the current Bill as Government amendments in the Senate while others may require some further public consultation, but those matters have been taken into account.

The other matter in that area that concerns the honourable member for Higgins is the personal liability of administrators. The Harmer report considered that that question of personal liability was essential to provide assurance to persons who engage in business with a company under administration that they will be paid. In reaching that conclusion the Commission took into account various matters—in fact, there were four specific matters that it adverted to.

The other matter which the honourable member for Higgins has always shown a good deal of concern about—misplaced in my view, but he has been consistent about it—is the business judgment rule. That of course does have its origin, as he indicated, in the United States. Not even the American Law Institute—I understand the honourable member spelt out a difference between our law and that in America—has proposed that the rule be legislated for. It is extremely difficult to legislate a business judgment rule here, and the courts have recognised in this country that directors are not responsible for honest errors of judgment. That is the fact of the matter and that is, I think, where it should be left.

The courts here have always shown a reluctance to review business judgments which are taken in good faith. Honourable members opposite know—and therefore I will not quote it tonight—what the High Court said in Harlowes Nominees Pty Ltd and Woodside. It was quite clear. In part, the Court said:

SPEECH.PARA: And their judgment, if exercised in good faith and not for irrelevant purposes, is not open to review in the courts.

We consider—and it is a difference between us—that the development of principles of common law liability is best left to the courts. It is noted, as the honourable member referred to it, in the explanatory memorandum that Australian courts have been prepared to exercise their discretion to excuse directors who have acted honestly and who ought fairly be excused. The other matters which the honourable member for Higgins raised—

TALK.START.PARA: —A statutory derivative action.
—He mentioned the question of a statutory derivative action.

Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
