That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LLOYD
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have the depressingly familiar rush of primary industry Bills and, for that matter, other Bills through this House in the dying stages of the session to beat the Senate deadline. I am not critical of the Senate for having a deadline but I am critical of the Government for not being able to program its legislation better. A number of major primary industry Bills were introduced into this House last week, and several of them are being debated this evening. That means there is not adequate time to research all the detail in these Bills. Therefore, it is impossible to say definitively whether the proposals of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) are the best way to proceed in this natural resource area.

PARA.TAB: However, in the Minister's second reading speech on the Natural Resources Management (Financial Assistance) Bill there were some positive aims. On the basis of that, the coalition is prepared to support the Bill and to monitor the progress of the consolidated arrangement. The first proposal in the Bill that the Minister refers to is his aim to combine the ministerial councils for agriculture, water and soil. His aim is to provide a more comprehensive or integrated approach to these related aspects of sustainable development in agriculture, and that certainly is a worthwhile aim.

Part of that broad proposal is to merge the national soil conservation program and the Federal water resources assistance program into the one; and that is basically the content of this Bill. The budget for this year is to be $77m. We are talking here generally about what is commonly known to the ordinary person as land care. There are, really, separate programs. There is a separate Landcare Ltd, a private company that is in a very positive way getting in private sector finance, company finance, to further promote the total soil conservation and land care ethic, and there are the water programs that are concerned with salinity, high water tables, et cetera. They have their own community groups separate from the land care groups. In fact, because my electorate is in an irrigation area, there are far more of them than there are land care groups.

We have to one side again, although it is part of the water program generally, the Murray-Darling Basin initiative, and some of the programs coming through that. They all have the aim of raising community awareness of soil, water and vegetation problems. They concentrate on community programs more than they do on particular problems on actual farms. That is where the major action actually has to occur—on farms themselves. I will come back to that later.

If these changes, or this consolidation of the legislation, simplify the application procedures and reduce the administrative delays and costs, the change will be positive because there have been confusion and complaint about this in the past. There has been a further problem in the past where the finance from these two programs has gone via the States, or through the State system, and where the States themselves have been the recipients of the programs.

In my view, and I have said it for quite a number of years, far too often the States have changed their own financial arrangements for their soil conservation officers, or whatever they may be, and put them on the Federal payroll. I know of examples in my area where the responsibility for not only officers, but research programs and even sections of research stations, has been taken from the States and loaded onto Federal programs by changing the names. That is wrong. It is a farce. In the past the Federal Government has been too soft on the States, in my view, in not requiring them to maintain in real terms their expenditure that existed in those areas prior to the Federal assistance arrangements commencing.

If I have understood correctly the aims in the Minister's second reading speech, this is where a third element of his proposal, the partnership agreements, comes in—the Minister can make comment if he feels that this is not right—which, hopefully, will overcome or reduce this weakness. I hope that the Minister is tough enough to make sure that the States are required to maintain in real terms their own expenditure while at the same time—and this is sometimes the opposite part of the problem—not establishing too much duplication at the Federal level with regard to checking how the money is spent, applications and so forth.

Land care, in the broad term, has been bipartisan and continues to be bipartisan. But there have been times recently at particular functions when the original arrangement has not been maintained, when there has not been recognition of the bipartisan nature. Where announcements are to be made relating to an Opposition member's electorate, the practice should continue where that member is given the opportunity to make that announcement, while acknowledging that it has come from the Minister and the government of the day. I make that point because I think it is very important that a general bipartisan nature be maintained. I am pleased to have been part of the original arrangements to get that bipartisan nature. I commend the National Farmers Federation and the Australian Conservation Foundation for the work that they did in those earlier days.

There is a concern that the level of budgetary provision for land care, in this broader term, remains flat—that is, it has not picked up in real terms. In fact, it is declining in real terms. With it comes another problem—and I am not saying that it is unique to this Government. For example, if one looks at just the last three years of expenditure, at the expenditure estimated for a financial year as proposed in the Budget for that year, and the figures in the Budget documents for the following year, which show what was actually spent, one sees that they are quite different figures. For example, in 1990-91 the Budget estimate for this area we are talking about was $88.5m, but in actual fact $73.5m was spent. In 1991-92 $70.8m was budgeted for, but $60.2m was spent. This year the Minister refers to $77m. I would hope that very close to that $77m would be spent. I recognise that it is silly to spend money for the sake of spending it just to meet a budgetary commitment if it is not sensible and cost beneficial to do so.

When one looks at the Decade of Landcare and that figure for the national soil conservation section of around $25m a year for each of those 10 years in real terms, the actual commitment is declining. Talking again irrespective of which side of Parliament happens to be in government, I believe we have to do better than that for the remaining years of that Decade of Landcare. For a start we have a number of land care groups. I have indicated earlier that there are other types of groups as well as those referred to as land care groups; there are over 1,300 of them. They have increased dramatically. Presumably there will be further increases.

While the money that they may want may not be able to be provided, there obviously is a continuing and growing commitment in that area. But separate to that and additional to it is the real problem of encouragement to farmers for in some cases quite costly on-farm remedial measures. This is where section 75D of the Income Tax Assessment Act has been quite important.

Talking again from my electorate, which is the Goulburn-Murray irrigation area of northern Victoria, which also has some dry land problems, I am pleased that, when this Government did remove some of the tax incentives for on-farm works—for soil conservation or for irrigation improvement—the write-off in the year of expenditure for lasering and related measures was never removed. That has been tremendously important.

There have been some anomalies that have been subsequently sorted out concerning tree planting and fencing, and some things have been clarified and improved again in recent years. But just to consider my area as an example, and it is only one example of different areas around Australia, about $25m each year is being spent by farmers in lasering and the associated better drainage, as well as the better irrigation practices—more efficient water use and less drainage access to the water table that comes with that, better recirculation of the drainage, et cetera and less, therefore, into the drainage system and into the Murray.

That $25m has been spent in some difficult years, and now close to 50 per cent of the total irrigation area of northern Victoria will be covered with these improvements. That is a tremendous achievement. That really is doing more to help in the slow but sure improvement in the quality of Murray River water from that part of the State in the sense of the drainage of irrigation water that goes into the Murray than anything that has been done by communities through land care groups, SPAC groups—the salinity program action groups—or whatever we like to call them. They are tremendous groups, all of them.

The point I am making is that the real action is and always will have to be on the farms themselves. If one looks north of the river to New South Wales, there is a tremendous amount of lasering going on in the rice country. That is also very important because of the particular problems for water tables with regard to rice production in certain soil types. Any on-farm activities are very expensive. We talk thousands of dollars for any worthwhile project. It is fortunate that the dairy and rice industries have probably had a better cash flow than many other agricultural industries, including some irrigation related ones of previous years.

If there is a low cash flow it is very difficult, even with section 75D tax deductibility, the write-off in the year of expenditure, to provide any real incentive. I believe we have a challenge here to provide incentives and encouragement for those on-farm practices so they may proceed to a greater degree than they have so far. The future of sustainable agriculture in these areas and, for that matter, in dry land areas or wherever it may be in Australia—and one can think of some other areas where there has not been such a positive cash flow compared with a couple of these irrigation areas—has to be addressed.

The land care programs and so forth which provide community awareness, which do very good things—and I would not knock them at all—have to be maintained in real terms. Additional policies or programs need to be put in place to ensure that more farmers are encouraged to do what they themselves would naturally want to do; that is, to improve the state of their farms so that, as every farmer would want, they can leave the farm to the next generation or sell it to whoever they wish in a better sustainable position than when they started. As I said, there has not been time to obtain the detail of all the ramifications, but some aspects of this do appear to be positive, and hopefully will be positive with regard to the future of the program.

TALKER.NAME: Mr JOHNS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) for his comments and support for the Natural Resources Management (Financial Assistance) Bill, and I thank the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), who is with us at the moment, for his good works. I would sum up this Bill by expressing it as the maturity of a phase that we have been through in recent years whereby there has been a blossoming of a whole set of programs to do with land, particularly soil and water conservation.

PARA.TAB: I tend to see these issues from the environmentalist's perspective, being a member of the Australian Conservation Foundation, as I have been for a decade or more. A number of issues grew from the initiatives of farmers and conservation activists with similar concerns who worked well together over a number of years, and we have now reached a point where many of these programs have proved themselves. However, there was a need for them to be brought together under one umbrella to ensure the best return for hard-earned taxpayers' dollars.

I wish to comment about the considerable amount of money which this Government has devoted to these sorts of programs. These land care and water management programs are examples of what we describe as ecologically sustainable development in practice. People are actually seeking not only to till the land and make it more productive, or to keep production levels up, but also to secure a quality in the environment, as the honourable member for Murray suggested, which will enable the producer to pass on that land in a condition presumably as good as the condition in which that person found it originally.

The honourable member for Murray used the term `the land care ethic'. This is an excellent term because this is all about changing the culture, about getting used to doing a better job of conservation while getting on with the business of making a reasonable return from the farm. A number of times the honourable member contrasted the efforts of the farmer and the costs borne by the farmer on his or her property with those borne by the land care group, which can be a combination of producers and non-producers, people in the local area.

I appreciate those comments, but it seems to me to illustrate a more general point. Certainly this Government has encouraged the use of community and producer ideas and voluntary effort, and that voluntary effort has been amplified many times over by the application of public funds. We need to caution here that it is the massive application of Government funds that has brought about an enormous blossoming in the work of farmers, conservation groups and community groups on the question of conservation.

Let me refer to some figures to give an illustration. I might say that good ideas come from the community and farm sectors. A lot of hard sweat and toil from good volunteers goes into conservation, but we will not get very far without the application of hard cash from the taxpayer. If we go right back to 1974-75 when Labor was previously in government, we see that the amount devoted to soil conservation and land care, excluding the water elements, was just $0.154m, but by 1992-93 the Budget allocation for soil conservation and land care by the Commonwealth was $26.01m, which is a substantial increase in anyone's language. There was a substantial increase between 1988-89 and 1989-90. In 1988-89 we spent $10.6m, and there was a massive jump in 1989-90 to $23m—and we have improved on those levels again.

So let me make the point that I think we have used the best ideas about integrated conservation—that is, for instance, to take people in a river catchment area, a dozen farmers or producers, and have them work together on the problems of that river catchment. But all the goodwill in the world and all the best ideas in the world will not produce a great result in the end if we do not have the application of these amounts of over $20m. I congratulate the Commonwealth on that effort.

The number of groups involved in both soil conservation and better water management has blossomed. I refer particularly to the land care groups which now exist in considerable numbers. In 1991 I think 941 land care groups were established, which is an extraordinary number. I think I will have to ring some people in the Queensland office, though, because the growth in community land care groups across the States is very uneven. I note that in Queensland there are 139 groups, but in smaller States with lesser populations and probably fewer producers there are more. For instance, in South Australia there are 200 groups, although that State probably has larger conservation problems; in Victoria, 319 groups; and, in Western Australia, 345 groups. For my own interest I might take up the issue of why Queensland only has 139 land care groups.

As I say, it is the maturity of the system that we are dealing with here. The Minister and the Commonwealth have been able to bring together a number of programs such as the Federal water resources assistance program, the national soil conservation program, the one billion trees program and save the bush programs as well as the community natural resource programs of the Murray-Darling Basin initiative.

All of those have now been brought together, and the Bill now establishes a National Landcare Advisory Committee so that we reconcentrate our effort on the nature of integrated land and water conservation, because only if we think in these integrated terms will we actually solve the problems of the intimate relationships between the movement of water and soil and the coverage on soil, et cetera. Whilst the Bill establishes the National Landcare Advisory Committee, it also seeks to abolish the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee, which, of course, had a narrower focus.

The honourable member for Murray also made a point often made in this place that wherever the Commonwealth seeks to introduce a new program or to lift the community's effort in an area the States often use those moneys to substitute for their own Budget allocations. I certainly hope that the States have not been doing that in this case, and I know that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy would be monitoring that fairly closely and smartly. The fact is, certainly in my experience, that wherever we write these programs we make sure that the State governments are not using the Commonwealth Government to substitute for their own Budget efforts, and nor should they.

I thank the Opposition for its very wise support for the Natural Resources Management (Financial Assistance) Bill. I thank the Minister for his foresight in bringing together a number of Commonwealth programs. These programs, all of which have been heralded by conservation groups, the National Farmers Federation and farmers organisations, have made a significant difference to the ethic, if I might borrow the term, of integrated land care management and conservation. It means that Commonwealth taxpayers' dollars, hard won, I might say, in addition to the efforts of producers and the community and volunteers together, are really beginning to resolve some of the most difficult questions of soil, soil degradation and water quality that we have seen in this country over the years.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Johns) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: DATA-MATCHING PROGRAM (ASSISTANCE AND TAX) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 3 November, on motion by Dr Blewett:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The data-matching program, which is the basis of the legislation before the House at the moment, was introduced two years ago by the Government as a methodology for reducing the amount of fraud and overpayments taking place not only in the Department of Social Security but also in a range of other departments; in particular, the Department of Veterans' Affairs, the then Department of Community Services and Health, the Department of Employment, Education and Training, the Australian Taxation Office and, since then, the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and the State Department of Corrective Services.

PARA.TAB: In December 1990, the Government introduced the data-matching legislation into parliament to extend the use of the tax file number to enable the detection of incorrect income support payments and possible tax evasion. Since that time, the Department has so far conducted some nine data-matching cycles. Its conduct is regulated by requiring agencies to follow a six-step framework set out in the Bill. Time limits apply to the completion of the cycle and the use of certain information which affects individuals, and they are notified before corrective action is taken.

Since December 1990, there have been two reports on the progress of the program; the first in October 1991 and the second in October 1992. At the time of the original legislation, the Opposition was concerned at the need to ensure that there was an adequate balance between the need to protect privacy on the one hand with the obvious need to ensure the integrity of the welfare system and the payment system on the other. To achieve this we agreed, with the support of the Democrats in the other place, to place in the Bill a two-year sunset clause. That was introduced to enable the operation of the new scheme, including to actually achieve savings, to be properly reviewed by the Parliament.

The object of the legislation tonight is effectively to end that sunset clause. That is not something which the coalition supports. We believe, in fact, that the sunset clause should continue for another 12 months—that is, until January 1994. That would give the opportunity at the end of October 1993 for a third report to be tabled by the agencies which are using this facility so that the Parliament would have the opportunity to ensure that the matching agency provisions are being adequately met, that the privacy requirements continue to be met—I should state that, as I understand it, the Privacy Commissioner is satisfied with the level of privacy at this stage and will be so reporting in due course—and also that the costings which were wrong right through the process to date can in fact be effectively justified.

The Minister for Social Security (Dr Blewett) claimed on 11 September this year that the social security system is `as tight as can be in a democratic society'. If this is so, the question has to be asked: how can we believe the Department's claims that it can capture an extra $153.7m this year and $213.8m next financial year if the data-matching system continues?

The matching program has been in force, as I said, for nearly two years. The Department has saved $25.3m in 1991-92 compared with estimated savings of $290m in the same period, a massive shortfall by anyone's analysis. The results were $266m less than estimated; nevertheless, the Government has congratulated itself, saying, `Substantial savings have been achieved and will continue to be achieved'.

The estimated savings for 1992-93 have been downgraded from $300m to $153.7m, despite a record increase in the number of pensioners and beneficiaries who are currently drawing from the social welfare system. Consequently, how can we believe the new estimates which the Minister tells us the Department can now meet. These estimates are, of course, from the Department of Finance. They are presumably supported by the Department of Social Security but, nevertheless, as we have said throughout the last two years, they continue to be grossly inaccurate.

The other area of concern with the legislation relates to privacy. Concerns relating to privacy are important. The Secretary to the Department of Social Security has already claimed before a Senate Estimates committee that departmental officers face a `nightmare' trying to safeguard the Department's extensive databanks. The questions which this Bill generates are whether the data-matching program has been successful and whether the national interest sufficiently outweighs privacy concerns for it to continue.

So far privacy conditions have been met and the Privacy Commissioner has been cooperating with the Department on this program. We are pleased that this is so and we trust that it will continue. However, it has been reported that the Commissioner is concerned about the expansion of dealing in personal privacy information, and he has expressed these concerns to the parliamentary inquiry into the protection of personal information. Bernard Lagan from the Sydney Morning Herald has reported:

SPEECH.PARA: One picture to emerge from the Lavarch inquiry is that the ICAC's findings—
that is, the New South Wales inquiry—
on the illegal information trade have been treated less than seriously by the Federal Public Service as it devises ways to gather yet more information on Australians.
The worrying thing about the ICAC inquiry in that most of the evidence suggested that the Department of Social Security was a major source of this information. Lagan also reports:

The DSS has complained that the ICAC report painted a remarkably negative picture of the security of its files on Australians and it maintained the ICAC had no evidence to support allegations of the unauthorised and corrupt release of information.

Nevertheless, that was the outcome of the ICAC report and we have not yet seen an adequate response from the Minister, who is now at the table, as to what the Department proposes to do about those problems. The coalition remains concerned, therefore, about erosions to privacy which may flow from the data matching programs and any other agreements the DSS may have with other departments, including now State departments such as prisons.

PARA.TAB: The importance of data matching within the Department is also worth some serious consideration. When considering the risk to privacy posed by the data matching program, the coalition is concerned that the comparatively low level of savings has not demonstrated sufficient evidence for keeping the program, especially now that the Department is down playing its importance in the whole scheme of overpayment identification measures. I gather, from a close examination of the figures, that most of the savings have come from the fact that the data matching program is now being superseded to some extent—and this is actually in the report—by other proposals which are now being utilised by the Department.

On the other hand, the evidence is quite clear that much of the success of data matching has effectively come from the deterrent effect of the tax file number system. People have dropped out of cheating the system voluntarily because of the effect of the tax file number, which is not necessarily part of the same exercise. The data matching program's October 1992 report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the savings are not as high as originally estimated for a number of reasons. The most significant reason for this is the better than expected performance of the Department's other control measures. The Australian social security system is very tightly controlled and minimises, as far as possible, incorrect payments and fraud. It contains a series of filters which detect incorrect payments and fraud at various stages. The Data Matching Program is a major element in this filtering process but as other measures become more effective,—
and that is the important point—
the number of discrepancies which remain for detection through data matching is reduced.
However, in 1990 the Minister said in his second reading speech:
The advantages of matching data on income, family structure and tax file numbers are enormous. This facility will virtually eliminate a major cause of social security and tax fraud.

Therefore, the emphasis is clearly different to the previous statement. Senator Richardson, when he was Minister, claimed repeatedly that `$400m was being ripped off Australian taxpayers by cheats and bludgers'. Some two years later we need to ask the Department: where is this $400m? Why can it not be captured and roped in with all of this new technology and law which are at the disposal of the Department?

PARA.TAB: The data matching program was lauded as the centrepiece of the Department of Social Security's fraud identification techniques. My colleague Senator Patterson has pointed out that when the Senate proposed to change one word in the Bill the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, wrote to the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) claiming that some $150m would be lost and alleged that we, the Opposition, would be held accountable for this loss. Every time Senator Patterson questioned the savings she was again given assurances that the estimates were accurate.

After the first data matching report was released and Senator Patterson expressed doubt about the estimates, she received a letter from the Minister for Social Security claiming that the annual savings were based on the operation of a fully implemented program and the program was not yet fully operational. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: As you know, action is proceeding to achieve these outcomes and the results so far suggest that when they occur, actual savings will be close to those estimated.
Clause 21 to repeal the Act in January 1993 was suggested by the Opposition to:
. . . enable the operation of the new scheme, including the actually achieved savings, to be properly reviewed by Parliament.

I think the fact that we have had access to two worthwhile reports fully justifies the action taken by the Opposition parties, with the support of the Australian Democrats in the Senate at that time. Our scepticism was clearly justified.

PARA.TAB: I do not think this Parliament has had the opportunity to review the scheme properly. The point needs to be made that while it can be said by the Minister that it has been in operation for two years, in fact that is not strictly true because much of the first year was used just getting the system into place. Therefore, we have not had a full two years of the scheme operating at maximum efficiency, which is another reason why there should be an additional 12-month period for the final review process. The current Minister stated in his second reading speech for this Bill that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . progress has been slower than anticipated in 1990 because of the time it has taken to allot a Tax File Number to every recipient of Commonwealth assistance.

However, the Department, in an answer to a question on notice in September this year, claimed that the recession has meant that it is more difficult for people to find work and therefore opportunities for incorrect new claims are reduced. I have some difficulty with the logic of this statement. Clearly the Government is now saying that it is the fault of the recession that not as many people are trying to cheat the welfare system and that is why the data matching program did not meet its estimates.

PARA.TAB: These vague statements have not satisfied my colleagues, and the coalition therefore wants to know exactly why the savings were not met and why they were so massively inaccurate. We want to know whether the new savings can be believed, when they can be believed and what worthwhile changes, if any, will be incorporated in the foreseeable future to achieve the objectives set by the Government. We need the Government to clarify the data matching program's significance in detecting the total overpayments of the Department. We are therefore amending the Bill to extend the sunset clause for another year and to require a further report on the progress of the fully operational program in October 1993.

In regard to the other amendments, I understand that these have been approved by the Privacy Commissioner and his staff have had an input into making these amendments. The 24-hour time limit for step 5 to take place will be increased to seven days. I think it will be necessary for this to be teased out in the Senate so that members of the Senate—regrettably, this House will not have the opportunity—can understand why seven days was chosen; why it was not longer or perhaps even shorter. The evidence needs to be before the House. Step 5 is the stage where the data matching agency puts together all the data and compares it in order to establish whether people are receiving inconsistent payments.

The other amendment relates to the 28-day appeal period against an adverse decision. The period will not apply to decisions which arise from a mistake by the agency. I understand that the Privacy Commissioner also approves of that amendment, and my colleagues in the Opposition will not object to those proposals at all.

In terms of the actual report of the data matching program, I want to draw attention to two points. The Department has referred some 115 cases, identified through the data matching program, to the Director of Public Prosecutions for consideration and prosecution action. When this report was tabled an additional 121 cases were being considered for referral to the DPP. A major case of multiple fraud was detected through the data matching program, and it is referred to in the report. The pensioner concerned had been receiving no less than 10 payments, using assumed names, for many years and the moneys to be recovered amounted to nearly $591,000. This is one of the biggest single cases of social security fraud ever detected in Australia. So one would have to say that, on balance, there have obviously been some advantages in the system as it currently works. But, as I have said, we need to keep it under closer examination.

Another interesting observation in the report was in terms of the effect of the tax file number requests on the rate of voluntary surrender of payments. I made the point earlier that, for example, in 1991-92 the Department saved $8.4m as a result of clients who were sent requests for their tax file numbers voluntarily surrendering their payments in the period following issue of the letters. Because of the timing of the mail-outs, savings and outlays are apportioned across financial years. In other words, the point is that as soon as the TFN system became effective, as was expected, in its own way it made significant savings which were quite separate again from the whole question of the tax file numbering arrangement.

I shall be moving the appropriate amendments at the committee stage of the Bill. I urge the Government to give the Parliament the opportunity to once again review this very important piece of legislation in an additional 12 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Amendment Bill 1992. I think, first and foremost, we need to look at the Government's whole belief in terms of the Social Security Act and the philosophy behind what this Government is about in terms of its delivery of programs within the Department of Social Security in particular. In fact, our Government is about targeting. In that capacity, this Government is committed to assisting those people in need—those people who are deserving of assistance and those people whom we believe have a right to government assistance. Indeed, the whole range of data matching is based on that premise.

PARA.TAB: In this data matching program, as the Opposition rightly points out, we are looking at the question of the Privacy Act plus the integrity of the program. However, I find it somewhat extraordinary that members of the Opposition continue to debate the whole notion of the data matching program in relation to this question of integrity when it is they who go around the countryside constantly making claims about the number of people who are in fact rorting the system and are perhaps not entitled to their payments of social security. Yet when the Government is attempting to address the issue constructively through the data matching program, yet again we see Opposition members trying to stop the program continuing and trying to create situations whereby they can block it.

The data matching legislation was debated in 1990 and an amendment was moved in the Senate, and accepted by the Government, to provide a sunset clause. We have heard all of this. The idea was to take stock of the operation of the program in a reasonable time after it had commenced, given the concern about the role of tax file numbers in the program and the cooperation of so many operations in the exercise.

What I find quite extraordinary is the opposition at times by honourable members opposite to the whole question of tax file numbers. Indeed we saw quite a debate on that when they were pursued as being de facto Australia cards and a whole range of other things. At the same time, the Opposition was suggesting to us that there were many people who were receiving payments from the Department of Social Security who did not have entitlements.

What is important, and what we recognise in the wider Australian community, and what in fact the Australian community is about, is a fair go. It is significant that the data matching program has not been controversial in its implementation. There has been little public comment or criticism of the operation of the program and there seems to have been no appreciable number of representations about the program. Many people who are social security recipients welcome the notion of data matching because they recognise that they have an entitlement, they believe the Government considers them to have an entitlement and they want to acknowledge that they, through the provision of their tax file number, are doing the right and correct thing. There is no doubt, partly because the program has been managed carefully but also because of the privacy protection included in the Act, that there has been very little public controversy.

Perhaps it is useful at this time to look at the kinds of protections that are included in the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act. The first of these worthy of mention is section 5 of the Act which, among other things, ensures the operation of the Privacy Act alongside the provisions of this Act. The Privacy Act allows an individual who considers that his or her privacy rights have been breached to complain to the Privacy Commissioner, who can investigate the allegation and may even order compensation for loss. Thus, the Data-matching Act exists within a web of legislative protection of privacy. That is very important because, given the role of government and the role of the Department of Social Security Department and others—the Australian Taxation Office and other agencies within the whole complexity of the provisions of the Privacy Act—we need to see the data matching in that context.

The Act describes in detail how data matching is done. Thus an individual can find out what information about him or her from what sources is compared as part of the program. The use of tax file number data is strictly regulated by the Act. This also cuts down on freedom of movement of government agencies involved in the program. In short, they must follow the Act in doing data matching, not do what they might consider to be convenient or what many members of the public would demand, which is active pursuance of those people they believe are in breach of the regulations.

The Act requires that all transfers of data between agencies are to be by means other than on-line computer connections. This is to guard against the creation of composite Commonwealth databases of personal information accessible by several agencies. The Act limits the aggregation of databases and limits agencies' access to such data as is aggregated. The Act also ensures that any aggregation of data is for a strictly limited period and purpose. That is a very important and crucial fact which is often overlooked by many in the Opposition. The Act is quite clear and specific about what it sets out to do, what it hopes to do and what it knows it can do.

The Act prescribes time limits for: the length of a data matching cycle; the time taken to match the data; the time taken to act on a discrepant result; and the time allowed to destroy data found to be of no use or not yet assessed. This means that data matching products do not lie around for possible fishing expeditions at will by the agencies.

The Act requires that an affected person must in most cases be notified before adverse action can be taken as a result of a data matching cycle. The affected party has up to 28 days in which to show cause why action should not be taken. Payments continue during that period. Should payment later appear not to have been warranted the money can be recovered. But in many instances the money is not recovered. I would say to members of the Opposition that it is that 28-day period which has also meant that some of the savings which it was believed we would make through the data matching were not able to be made.

Section 12 of the Act deals with the obligation of all agencies to comply with data matching guidelines issued by the Privacy Commissioner under the Act and appearing in the schedule. These replicate a number of the above privacy safeguards and require the production of a program protocol by the agencies to assist the Privacy Commissioner to assess whether the program is being conducted properly. They require also a technical standards report to assist the Privacy Commissioner to monitor technical aspects. Sections 13 and 14 deal with the processes for the handling of alleged breaches of privacy.

The Privacy Commissioner's staff have been intimately involved with the program. They have been present at crucial stages of the Data-matching Agency matching procedures and they have been satisfied that the program operates as it should. In 1991, the Department of Social Security made savings of $25.3m. It is estimated that in 1992-93, $146.9m will be saved by the Department from the program, and that figure rises to $161m. It is a fact that the 1990 forward savings estimates were higher. However, the full implementation of the program is predicated on all recipients of Commonwealth assistance having a tax file number and on clients providing their tax file numbers to the Department of Social Security. The Department has been careful to give people every possible opportunity to provide their numbers before taking any action to stop payment. This has limited the savings until this time.

Many honourable members opposite would recognise the concerns which many of our age pensioners had in this regard. It was out of the interests of compassion and care for our age pensioner population in particular that the demands of tax file numbers for the Department of Social Security were not implemented in a heavy-handed way but taken over a period. This has, of course, limited the savings until now, but we recognise that people can be confused at times and we are prepared to ensure that their payments are made over a period.

The Bill also provides for two other amendments to the Data-matching Act. The first of these is to extend the time available for completion of step 5 of a data matching cycle from 24 hours to seven days. We have heard some discussion about the nature of that and of the problems in relation to the 24-hour limit. Experience has shown that adherence to the current 24-hour limit is in no-one's interest. It allows only one hurried computer-run to generate match results. Should there be a minor imperfection in the match algorithm, an artificially high or unrealistically low number of discrepancies will be generated. The amendments to sections 7 and 9 to extend the time limit will allow a source agency to test sample match results and suggest changes to the algorithm so that the final results are as reliable as possible.

The Privacy Commissioner has been fully consulted on this amendment. He agrees that the current time limit is too severe, given the value of a testing element to improve the quality of the results. I think all of us would agree that what we are about is ensuring the integrity of the system while ensuring that individuals' rights are maintained. As we have said, the Privacy Commissioner is involved in this. It is crucial that we have the very best result. The amendment to move from the 24-hour limit to the seven-day limit takes cognisance of all those facts. As a government we continue to remain committed to the integrity of our Department of Social Security, because we believe that government has a very important and crucial role to play in the life of the citizens of this country.

We do not believe, as many members of the Opposition do, that government has a very limited role to play in the life of the country. We are not about laissez faire. We are not about the survival of the fittest. We are about ensuring that everybody has a fair go. We are about access and equity and, as such, we are about ensuring that people who have rights have those rights maintained through the Department of Social Security, but that those people who do not have rights also need to be caught within our system. It is not in the interests of taxpayers in general or of the wider community that people rort the system, as it is commonly known. Indeed, it is simply through this data matching program that those people who, in fact, abuse the system are caught.

This Bill amends section 11 of the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act 1990. (Quorum formed) As I was saying before I was so rudely interrupted, the data matching program is part of this Government's commitment to ensuring that those people who have an entitlement through the Department of Social Security receive that entitlement and that those people who set out to abuse the rights and privileges that being a member of the Australian community brings will, in fact, be caught and not be able to participate.

The data matching program has operated successfully for almost two years. It represents a practical example of a measure achieving a proper balance between the financial interests of government, the individual's right to privacy and the individual's right to protection by this Government. These amendments will ensure the program's continuation and improve the operation of the Act. I commend the Bill to this House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing Mr P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that the Minister for Social Security (Dr Blewett), in his second reading speech on the Data-matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Amendment Bill, failed to give a satisfactory reason for the repeal of the sunset clause that would have seen the cessation of the data matching program on 22 January 1993. The Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that experience with the program for the best part of two years has shown that, while for the reason outlined earlier, savings have been less than anticipated, substantial savings will be generated by the program with, at the same time strong privacy safeguards applying.

The Minister cited the data matching program report to substantiate the continuation of the program. The report acknowledged the comparatively tiny amount of savings generated through the operations of the data matching program. The original estimates of savings touted at the time of the introduction of the principal Act were $290m for 1991-92 and $300m for 1992-93. The actual results achieved by the program were significantly less, amounting to $25.3m in 1991-92 and a downgrading of the 1992-93 estimate to $145.9m.

PARA.TAB: The Data-matching Agency in its report attributed the shortfall in savings to a number of circumstances. Those circumstances have already been canvassed by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), in particular the reason outlined about the recession making income matching less effective. It said that as the economy improves and employment and incomes rise, it is reasonable to expect that savings from the program will also increase. Also, there was talk of a delay in the passage of legislation which affected the timing of the issue of the request for tender for high speed matching equipment. In fact, according to the Data-matching Agency, the early cycles were undertaken using the Department's existing hardware.

I am not at all convinced that the privacy provisions are now operating satisfactorily, notwithstanding the Minister's claims that a balance has been achieved between the conflicting interests of protecting public expenditure and protecting individual privacy. I would have thought that the poor results in savings using the Government's own estimates as a guide require the sunset clause not only to be retained, but also to be extended, as proposed in the amendment circulated in the name of the honourable member for Bradfield, to allow proper scrutiny by the Parliament before the program continues and as it does so.

I turn now to a matter of concern in my own electorate, where data matching has apparently failed. Not only has it failed, but as a result it may also have cost law abiding constituent businessmen and a valuable export industry a large amount of money in failing to provide a more satisfactory and effective method of detecting social security and taxation fraud alleged by the Australian Taxation Office and the Department of Social Security to be rife amongst casual employees of the strawberry growing industry in the area to the north of Wanneroo in my electorate.

On 27 November 1991 Federal Police and officials from the Australian Taxation Office conducted raids, or site inspections—as they like to euphemistically term those raids—on strawberry farms operated by a number of my constituents. As a result of the raids, many of the employees fled. They had national backgrounds where there was the presence of policemen and officials, usually enforcing strict communist government policies back in their home countries. This wreaked havoc on the harvesting of the strawberry crop that was then under cultivation. This caused an estimated loss of $1.5m to those growers in the area affected by those site inspections. It dealt a telling blow to a valuable niche export market of Australian fruit to South East Asian customers, a trade valued at around $5m.

As a consequence of those raids or site inspections, as they are called, which came after some years of discussions about the best methods of detection of social security and taxation fraud, I wrote to the office of the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) requesting information as to who was responsible for these site inspections, why they were undertaken, and what alternatives had been discussed prior to undertaking those raids or site inspections.

Senator McMullan, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, replied and told me that the site inspections were initiated jointly by the Department of Social Security, the Australian Taxation Office and the Federal Police. That letter also stated that nine people were charged and convicted of 12 offences under the Taxation Administration Act. I specifically asked why raids were conducted instead of using alternative methods, which I mentioned included data matching of computer records and inquiries with the Department of Social Security with which my constituents were prepared to cooperate. To this, Senator McMullan responded that `expensive data matching was undertaken prior to the site inspections'.

I also asked what happened to work undertaken by my predecessor, Mr Allen Blanchard, to arrive at a satisfactory resolution to the problem of stamping out the use of false identities by workers to avoid taxation and also to fraudulently claim unemployment benefits. I would like to acknowledge the work undertaken by my predecessor when he was the honourable member for Moore. Senator McMullan responded that the Taxation Office had no record of any correspondence from Mr Blanchard concerning any matters of that nature and that the Australian Taxation Office was unaware of any offers of assistance from any grower prior to the raids.

I was told by my constituents that the Strawberry Growers Association had had discussions with the Tax Office officers as early as 1986. In furthering the representations on behalf of my constituents I would like to add the following comments. As asserted by my constituents, who have tried to do the right thing at all times—at all times they have asserted to me that they have undertaken to comply with the letter of the law—surely there must be a more effective way of investigating the allegations of social security and taxation fraud attributed to some casual workers employed in the strawberry growing industry; an industry that employs a considerable number of people during peak growing times?

The requests of those growers for an act of grace payment as compensation for the financial losses caused by the conducting of those raids or site inspections on their farms rather than more discreet and effective alternative methods of detection was rejected by the Treasurer. As a result of what occurred, I initiated a cooperative council in my electorate between the industry and the various agencies of the Federal Government which have an interest in the detection of alleged cheating by employees in the industry. That council comprises members of the Strawberry Growers Association; representatives from the Department of Social Security, and I acknowledge to the Minister for Social Security, who is present at the table, that his Department was cooperative in coming to help form that particular council; representatives from the Australian Federal Police; and representatives from the Commonwealth Employment Service.

That council, originally chaired by me, has met on a number of occasions. I will continue to take a great interest in the outcomes from its discussions and from those consultations between the strawberry growers and the agencies of the Federal Government that have an interest in the detection of the particular allegations of fraud that have been perpetrated on the Department of Social Security and the Taxation Office.

In conclusion, there is a need for an ongoing review of the data matching program as a means of detecting cheating and fraud of government payments, as well as in the interests of protection of the rights of citizens and their individual privacy. The Opposition's support for the retention of section 21 of the principal Act not only reflects our concerns for the protection of rights of citizens vis-a-vis their privacy and the exchange of information that is pertinent to their affairs between government agencies; it gives us the opportunity to review the operations of the Data-matching Agency before the expiry of the two-year life of parts I and II of the principal Act. I support the Opposition amendment for the sunset clause to be extended to 22 January 1994, as indicated in the amendment circulated in the name of the honourable member for Bradfield.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I will take up the last general points made by the honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing). I welcome methods that do not have some of the effects he was suggesting in relation to dealing with the problem of social security fraud and taxation fraud, although I must say that those issues have nothing to do with data matching. None of those sorts of activities could have taken place in relation to a data matching activity. Obviously we will take on board the comments that he has made.

PARA.TAB: The major criticism that the Opposition has launched in relation to the proposal to remove the sunset clause has been the fact that the savings fall well below the estimates that were originally made. We accepted that. We pointed out both in the report and briefly in my second reading speech the reasons for that. I will just reiterate the reasons why those estimates were not achieved.

The first and most important reason is that the collection of five million tax file numbers from clients of the Department of Social Security was an operation that took much longer than we had anticipated. This was partly because we wanted to be particularly sensitive to that collection. Therefore, the whole system cannot be at its most effective until we have all of those tax file numbers in.

Secondly, as honourable members have noted, at the same time as the data matching operation was under way, other control measures were developed. Perhaps the most important new measure was the accelerated claimant matching system. I notice that no member of the Opposition has pointed out that that accelerated claimant matching system saved $88.4m more than was estimated. That obviously affected the benefits we could have got from data matching. It should be noted that this other major program, which came in roughly at the same time, brought $88m more in savings than we had anticipated.

Thirdly, I point out that in recessionary times it is more difficult for people to secure other forms of income, which is the chief source of the problems within the social security system. Therefore, I think one would naturally expect that a matching system would have a reduced effectiveness because it is not so easy to get other jobs and to receive other incomes in recessionary times.

Fourthly, as honourable members noted, it is impossible to estimate what effect voluntary compliance had. There is no doubt that the introduction of the tax file system and the data matching system have led to an increase in voluntary compliance. There is a pattern of reasons why the estimates were not realised in this initial period.

We have great confidence, on the basis of what has been achieved and now that we know the system, in our ability to achieve the estimates that have now been laid down, based on this experience. We are also confident, as is the Privacy Commissioner whose officers have supervised the data matching process, that the privacy considerations in this area have been met.

I want to take up one other issue before returning to the amendment that has been proposed by the Opposition. On the ICAC findings, which were introduced by the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly), the Department of Social Security and the Federal Police have looked at the cases of all DSS staff named before the ICAC inquiry. It is significant that only one Department of Social Security employee admitted to improper release of information in that inquiry.

A small group of others admitted to releasing slightly too much information under the DSS client confirmation scheme which operates to confirm to State and local authorities that a person receives Department of Social Security fringe benefits. This is to assist State and local authorities. Those were innocent releases in relation to addresses and none of those would have been amenable to prosecution. However, we do need to tighten even that system, which is designed to assist both local government and State governments, in order that people might get their fringe benefits.

The Department of Social Security employee who admitted fault has been successfully prosecuted, and ICAC's inquiries into other Department of Social Security staff did not disclose any basis for prosecution. I and my Department do take the ICAC implications seriously, as is exemplified by the follow-up action already taken. I have asked the Department to cooperate fully with the Privacy Commissioner and the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, chaired by the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Lavarch), in their separate inquiries into matters related to the ICAC report. I have no doubt that my Department will cooperate in those matters.

I now turn to the amendment that has been moved. We are confident from our experience that we will make this system work effectively. We are confident—as far as we can be confident on estimates based on our experience; and our discussions with the Privacy Commission confirm this confidence—about the way this system has enabled us to deal with privacy issues in relation to data matching. We are so confident in the system that we are prepared to accept the Opposition's amendment to allow a further period of time for the Parliament to confirm completely that this is a major weapon which we can use against fraud, not just in social security but also in a number of the other major systems. Therefore, the Government will not be opposing the amendment to have a sunset clause for another year.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.
Clauses 1 to 5—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Proposed new clause 5A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Connolly Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased with the Government's decision to support these amendments and to allow the sunset clause to go through; I think it is a sensible one under the circumstances. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Page 3, after clause 5, insert the following new clause:
"5A. Section 12 of the Principal Act is amended by inserting after subsection (2) the following subsection:

PARA.TAB: `(2A) In addition to the requirement that the matching agency and each source agency table a comprehensive report in both Houses of Parliament eighteen months after the commencement of the first data matching cycle (as required by Guideline 12 of the Guidelines issued by the Privacy Commissioner on 27 September 1991), the matching agency and each source agency must prepare and present for tabling in each House of the Parliament by the end of October 1993 a further comprehensive report including references to all of the matters identified in Guideline 12 of the Privacy Commissioner's Guidelines of 27 September 1991.'.".

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly am happy with the second of the amendments, which is the one that I addressed in my opening remarks. I am assured that the first one is simply consequential, so we accept both of them.
