VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS AMENDMENT BILL 1992]

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 4 November, on motion by Mr Humphreys:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is now considering in cognate debate the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), a Budget related Bill, and also the very important Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill, which might be short titled the Bushell Bill, in respect of definitions under the Veterans' Entitlements Act.

PARA.TAB: There is limited time available because this debate has been guillotined as part of a guillotine of no less than 51 Bills as we draw to the end of this Budget sittings, and I will have to truncate my remarks accordingly. It is a great pity that some minutes before midnight this veterans legislation has to be dealt with in a rushed way. It does not allow for proper consideration of legislation, and as a consequence quite often things slip through. We have just had amendments accepted by agreement after a period of confusion. I know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that you are a stickler for the correct forms in these matters. We need time if we are to properly address the legislation before the House, including these two veterans Bills.

Most of the measures in the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill are welcome and the coalition will not oppose this legislation. Included in its provisions are adjustments to the defence service home loans. As the honourable member for Mallee (Mr Peter Fisher) has pointed out repeatedly, the age of the veteran population today is such that many veterans are seeking to make practical adjustments to their residences, particularly enlarging bathrooms and altering bathroom railings. This provision represents worthy changes whereby DSH loan provisions will be extended to allow use of a loan for repairs or modifications to properties already owned by the holder of the loan. The Bill will also allow DSH loans to be used for the purpose of discharging an existing mortgage where convenient. That is a degree of flexibility which I find most satisfactory.

The Bill also provides some special arrangements for dependants of former prisoners of war. No Australians suffered more greatly, in many ways, than our former prisoners of war, whether they were in World War II or in other conflicts, notably those who served in the Malaya campaign and in Singapore, and were subsequently imprisoned in Changi and then sent to the Burma death railway. In some cases, those who survived that were then sent by train through Bangkok to Phnom Penh, and then, by one method or another, to Saigon, loaded onto Japanese ships and shipped to the coalmines in Japan, if they were not sunk by Allied submarines in the process. There are some extraordinary accounts of those who survived both the Burma death railway and the Japanese coalmines.

In all the circumstances, the coalition recognises that prisoners of war, and more particularly their dependants, deserve the special recognition which is afforded them in this legislation. That is welcomed within the constraints of responsible Budget arrangements.

Also included in the legislation on the Budget Bill, as opposed to the Bushell Bill, is a measure to provide, for the first time, for investments to be brought into account for the treatment of capital gains and losses from listed shares and other listed securities. This legislation is parallel to measures in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill. Some of these Bills will not commence operation until 1 September next year.

I want to make the point that embedded in this legislation is a move to take into account notional gains in share prices over the course of a period and to adjust downwards in certain circumstances service pensions as far as this legislation is concerned, and age pensions as far as other legislation is concerned, where the share prices go up even though the veteran or the pensioner may not sell the shares. So it should not be forgotten, and I highlight it to the Parliament, that this legislation is introducing a form of notional capital gains tax and one which the coalition undertakes to study very carefully, especially in relation to the fairness and the actuality of the implementation of this proposal. We will examine its implementation on a technical basis when in government. We will have the chance to do that in government prior to the commencement of this Budget related measure. I highlight to the pensioner community and the veterans community that this legislation introduces the notional capital gains tax form in terms of reducing income of veterans and pensioners who have a notional gain in share values. That should not pass without comment. It will be very carefully examined by us in government.

The coalition does not oppose the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill, which is just one of the 51 Bills being guillotined through the House at this time. So rushed is the legislation that bits of paper slip into my hand. I am holding a newspaper article quoting the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans) in Hong Kong where he is commenting on the dog of the Governor-General of Hong Kong going missing. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Governor's dog is probably a supreme delicacy. They'll turn it into hors d'oeuvres for Deng Xiaoping who, I'm told, eats four puppies a day.

TALK.START.PARA: —What has that got to do with veterans?

—They are careless remarks in the Asian context, but if I were to dwell on them I would be the subject of a point of order from the honourable member for Dobell, if not the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) or someone else. I will not dwell on them, except to say that they are careless remarks and injurious to the trading relationship between Australia and China.

PARA.TAB: I turn to the Bushell Bill, which is actually entitled the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill. It overturns the effects of a recent High Court decision in the case known as Bushell v. Repatriation Commission. Dare I say that I have the presence of mind to suggest to the House at this late hour that it is this Bill, rather than the previous Bill, which causes the advisers box to be well staffed on this occasion.

Nevertheless, the House is considering a very serious measure. It goes to the core of a determining system and what might constitute a fair go for those who served their country during time of war. Of course, those who did serve their country in time of war are entitled to the maximum generosity that a responsible government can afford and provide in terms of all that might be made available for looking after those veterans and their dependants, the ex-service men and women of Australia.

It is essential that the determining system be overly fair to our veterans. Many have served with great difficulty, many have been disadvantaged in one dimension or another in the period following their service. I emphasise that, to provide a fair go, the legislative framework quite often has to go that step further to ensure that people do not drop through the system and get unfair treatment. Equally, I accept that the determining system must have credibility, must be a system operated effectively, responsibly, and that is available to be accessed by the veteran but not lead to any form of rorting. I know that the veterans community and the organisations that represent it are responsible. Some of the most difficult panels constituted by the VRB and other related organisations are occupied by ex-service personnel because they have an ability to examine a claim very carefully and they are the first to deal with any erroneous claims where they are forthcoming. No-one denies that erroneous claims are made, but equally our responsibility as a parliament, and the responsibility of the government of the day, is to see that all genuine claims get genuine treatment from the system.

We examined this legislation against that background. There are complex legalities involved in relation to definitions. Senator Jocelyn Newman, the shadow Minister for veterans affairs, will be dealing with this legislation in more detail in the other House. There is nevertheless a suspicion that the Government has achieved a stated objective with indecent haste—namely, to overturn the effects of the recent High Court decision in Bushell v. Repatriation Commission—but through an unintended consequence it may do something more than that. That, of course, would be of acute concern to members and senators of the Liberal and National parties.

In that context I would like to quote from two communications, the first of which is a letter from the National President of the RSL, Brigadier Alf Garland, dated 10 November 1992. I note, to his credit, that he is in the gallery at this late hour watching the progress of the debate and consideration of this legislation. On page 2 of the letter he says:

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed amending legislation—
namely, the Bushell Bill before the House—

has such linguistic and practical difficulties that it will be incapable of being applied intelligently or consistently by most decision-makers in this area, including at Board and Tribunal level. It will inevitably generate much litigation, noting that it has taken seven years to obtain a cogent explanation on how to apply the 1985 amendments.

It is against that background that I move on to quote from another document which has been made available to me in the form of legal advice and consideration in respect of the Bill. This document says:
The legislation is very poorly drafted and will be a field day for the lawyers. Money will be wasted in legal expenses that should have been spent on sick and disabled veterans.

The difficulty for members of the coalition, and members of the House more generally, is that in the circumstances of the guillotine, in the relatively short time the Bill has been made available, there has been a limited opportunity to tease out and establish in absolute form what the impact of the new definitions will be in practical terms in respect of the determining system. I know this concern is shared by the Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), and by the shadow Minister for veterans affairs, Senator Jocelyn Newman, who is in the gallery at this time.

PARA.TAB: It is against that background that the Opposition will not oppose the legislation in the context of its deliberations before the House. But it will provide that the legislation on the so-called Bushell Bill—the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill 1992—be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for very proper and detailed consideration, especially with regard to the legal exactitudes extracted by the Bill and what the end outcome might be in relation to this seemingly hasty drafting of the legislation.

It could well be that after consideration the Committee will find that the Bill does no more or no less than seek to provide for returning the system to where it stood with the original 1985 definitions. But it could also emerge that the practical impact of the definitions and amendments contained in the Bill could do far more than that and knock out those genuine cases which are seeking proper and fair determination under the determining system.

It is against that background that the coalition has determined that this Bill should go to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. It is not as a delaying tactic and not as a point of prevarication but as a point of responsibility to those whom we represent: veterans who served their country in a time of war and conflict. I declare an interest; I am a veteran. This is serious legislation requiring this approach from the Parliament.

We are concerned at the speed with which the fundamental provisions of the Veterans' Entitlements Act are sought to be altered. We are concerned about the Government's total lack of consultation with the ex-service community in the formulation of the Bill. I understand and accept that there were briefings in the very late stages of the process with representatives of the RSL, AVADSC and others.

To some extent there still has been a legislative process by stealth. That is a little unusual because over the years the Department of Veterans' Affairs has sought to consult comprehensively. Perhaps the argument is that, as the court's decision came down only on 7 October 1992, this process had to be truncated on this occasion. That is another reason why the Bill should go to the Senate Committee to be properly sourced out to ensure that errors which could be injurious to the veterans community are not going to be made.

Our third concern is that the Government says that this Bill will achieve the elimination of the Bushell decision—the so-called Bushell anomaly which some would argue is not really an anomaly. I simply say that I am not a lawyer and I would never seek to be a lawyer. Let me place on the record of this Parliament that I have concern at times, dare I say, that there may be one or two lawyers too many in this Parliament. I refer to members from both sides of the House and of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —You've got McGauran.

—I must now go and make peace with the honourable member for Gippsland. Notwithstanding that, that is another reason why a complex matter of this nature should quite properly go to the Senate Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. If that Committee recommends the passage of the Bill, we will also press for the reintroduction of the Veterans Entitlements Act Monitoring Committee. It would have a direction to report to the Parliament on the operational effects of the new legislation.

PARA.TAB: We are not going to create undue difficulty, but we are going to establish due process in respect of this guillotined legislation. I must also add that if in practice it is shown that the effect of the Bill is to go further than the pre-Bushell position on pension determinations a coalition government will reconsider the legislation, especially taking into account any recommendations made by the Veterans Entitlements Act Monitoring Committee.

I do not want to preclude others from speaking in the limited time allocated for this debate. It has been a busy year on the veterans front. Most notably, there was the opening of the Vietnam War Memorial in Anzac Parade. I speak on the eve of Remembrance Day, in the fiftieth anniversary year of so many of those key events associated with World War II, including the Battle of Australia, the Kokoda Trail, the Battle of the Coral Sea, El Alamein just to mention some. Many of us will have the opportunity to go to the Australian War Memorial tomorrow to take part in that Remembrance Day service. Excellent services are conducted there and in so many centres around Australia.

I make a plea to the Minister to hear us out in relation to our concerns on this legislation. We are not seeking to impede its progress through this House in the context of the limitations of the guillotine which prevails, but we are making it very clear that it is our absolute determination to see the Bushell Bill—the key Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill—go to that Senate Standing Committee as the next step in the process. That process will ensure that all these matters which are emerging can be properly canvassed in that jurisdiction.
The coalition is not opposed to the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), which is a Budget Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join with the honourable member for Farrer and Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) in noting that this debate is taking place immediately prior to Remembrance Day. I suppose in Australia greater emphasis is given to remembering on Anzac Day the sacrifices made by veterans and their families. It is very correct and proper that Remembrance Day in our country is the day when we pay just tribute to those who have served their country in a time of war. I join with the Leader of the National Party in noting this fact as we are discussing this legislation.

PARA.TAB: I think the most important part of this debate is the bipartisan nature of the debate on the proposals which are before the House. The Leader of the National Party has indicated that there will not be a division in this House tonight on the two Bills. He has made it clear that he has some concerns about the proposals in the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill and that it is his view that it should be investigated further by a Senate committee. I will make a few comments about the merit of that proposal later. The important point is that there will be no party political division in this House on these proposals tonight.

One may well ask why the Parliament needs to pass legislation to overturn a decision of the High Court. It is not the first time that the Australian Parliament has sought to pass legislation altering the interpretation of Acts of parliament which govern the rights and entitlements of veterans. As a member of the Parliament elected in 1984, Mr Deputy Speaker, you would be aware that there was a lot of debate about the proposals which were introduced during the term of Senator Arthur Gietzelt as Minister for Veterans' Affairs in 1985.

At that time the Government introduced legislation because it believed that a number of decisions had been made by the courts which would have virtually allowed almost every veteran who applied for certain entitlements to receive them, irrespective of the merits of each case. I know that in those days I had a number of constituents tell me that they believed that people who were not entitled to TPI benefits were starting to receive them because of those decisions by the various courts. In the past there were very strict requirements before people could receive the TPI entitlements. Because of the various court decisions during a certain period, it was clear that the tests which were being applied, or the legal standard which had to be met, were very different from those which applied both before 1980 and after 1985.

The fact that the Opposition has not sought to undo the changes that were made in 1985 demonstrates that neither side in politics in Australia will seek to go back to the situation that existed in that time—that is, after the O'Brien decision where it was virtually impossible for the Repatriation Commission to disprove some of the claims. In certain categories, virtually all applicants could be entitled to the benefits which the Parliament originally intended to be paid only to those who had genuine war caused disabilities.

The fact that the Opposition has not committed itself to repealing the changes that took place in 1985 in subsequent elections, when people such as the honourable member for Farrer were the spokesmen on veterans affairs, demonstrates that there is a bipartisan view of the Parliament that, as the Leader of the National Party said, a fair go should be given to those people who served their country in time of war. A fair go does not mean that a TPI pension is given to those with very serious disabilities and the same TPI pension given to those who have relatively less serious injuries. I know that is a view that extends across this chamber in both parties. Governments do not have an unlimited capacity to obtain money from taxpayers, and it is our responsibility to ensure that the scarce resources are directed to those who have suffered most in time of war. That is the theory behind the views that many of us put in this House, not only on this issue but on many others.

Why is the Parliament looking at overturning the decision of the High Court which was handed down on 7 October 1982 in Bushell v. Repatriation Commission? The reason is that the advice which the Government has received argues that this decision virtually means that a person no longer has to provide a reasonable hypothesis of the relevant war service connection before a claim is granted. As you know, Mr Deputy Speaker, that was a test which was inserted in 1985 to try to ensure that those people who have a genuine claim are successful.

We all know that that requirement for having a reasonable hypothesis was inserted because of the O'Brien High Court case. That was before 1985. It was the intention of the Parliament to seek to ensure that the O'Brien case was overturned by inserting the requirement for a reasonable hypothesis. The reason we are debating this legislation tonight is that the advice that the Government has received is that the Bushell case virtually means that a person no longer has to provide a reasonable hypothesis. A person virtually has only to obtain the hypothesis of one medical practitioner qualified in that field. In those circumstances, it is virtually guaranteed that the veteran making the claim will be successful.

Mr Deputy Speaker, you may well ask how much money that will cost. In the second reading speech of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), he had some estimates which, I take it, had been prepared by his Department—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what they are—they are estimates.

—As the Leader of the National Party points out, they are estimates. Estimates are often wrong. Estimates made by people day after day on both sides of parliament are often proved wrong as days go by. But it is certainly clear that—and I am sure the Leader of the National Party would concede me this point—if the Government and the Opposition had not voted together to make the changes in 1985, there would have been a much higher expenditure on veterans affairs than is the case today. I hope that the Leader of the National Party will concede me at least that point. It is clear that, if this legislation is passed by the Parliament, some people are less likely to be successful with their claims than if the Bushell case is simply entitled to stand unaffected by legislation in this House.

PARA.TAB: The estimates which were contained in the Minister's second reading speech stated that, in 1992-93, a sum of $10m to $15m would be required to provide additional program expenditure. This would rise to $60m to $105m in 1993-94 and to $235m to $440m at the turn of the century. These are quite substantial sums of money. It is right that the Parliament is seeking to discuss whether we should let the High Court decision stand, or whether we should try to ensure that, as the Leader of the National Party said, there should be a fair go for veterans so that those who have the greatest entitlements and the greatest need are those who receive the scarce resources that are available.

The legal advice given to the Government is that this legislation will bring us back to where we were in 1985. That is all I am prepared to accept, as a member with a very large veteran community. The Minister, who is at the table, knows that and he has given assurances that that is the advice that has been received from the experts in this field—that is, we are simply trying to go back to the position we were in when there was a requirement for a reasonable hypothesis. That situation was supported, as I said, by both Government and Opposition people in 1985. I hope we will again get bipartisan support at some time in the future.

The Leader of the National Party stated that he wished the advice given to the Minister to be tested in the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. I do not have total objection to that process. I would prefer for there not to be a large loss of money to taxpayers by allowing some people who in the past would not have received TPI pensions and other claims to receive them. I hope we will not get a flood of applications going through before the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee examines this issue, because it would be unfair for people who have less worthy claims to be successful today when more worthy claims lodged perhaps six months or a year ago were unsuccessful.

We can imagine what would happen if the Senate Committee looked at this matter and supported the Government's proposal, the law was returned to where it was in 1985 and worthy claims were again unsuccessful. If only those which were processed in a very short time, with less worthy arguments, were successful, that would be unfair to everyone.

I am sure that veterans will be very keen to ensure that this matter is resolved speedily so that we have some certainty in the system. If this legislation is referred to a Senate committee I hope that it will do its job as quickly as possible, while discharging the obligations which the Senate might give to it. But, as I said, it is the advice to the Government that the proposal before the House will return us to where we were in 1985. That is something for which I hope we can obtain bipartisan support.

Turning to the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), I am very pleased to see that veterans and their spouses will be receiving a one-off increase on 4 February next year, an increase which has been brought forward from March. That will be welcomed by many in my electorate—an increase of $6 a fortnight for single pensioners and $10 a fortnight for married couples. As you would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, that maintains the Labor Government's commitment to maintain these pensions at 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. We are certainly determined to ensure that, unlike the Fraser years when pensions fell from 25 per cent to only 21 per cent of average weekly earnings, we maintain that target of 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. Whatever happens at the next election, I will bet that because of the actions of the Hawke Labor Government and Minister Gietzelt and Minister Humphreys in veterans affairs no future government, Labor or Liberal, will ever be allowed to let that pension rate fall below 25 per cent of average weekly earnings without facing the wrath of the Australian community, pensioner and non-pensioner.

I would also like to compliment the Minister for introducing in this legislation proposals which will allow for a special grant of war widows pensions to the widows and widowers of certain ex-prisoners of war. I know that on both sides of this House there is a very high regard for those Australians who have served as prisoners of war in any conflict. I believe that this is special recognition which they and their spouses deserve, and something which I know will be welcomed by many.

I hope I can claim one or two successes in Budgets during my years in politics. One measure which I do hope to claim some authorship for is the decision to extend fringe benefits to all service pensioners. This is a proposal which has been around for many years. When I had the honour to be a member of the Prime Minister's task force on retirement incomes, I worked very hard to seek to ensure that all age pensioners and service pensioners received fringe benefits entitlements.

In the social security and veterans' affairs legislation which has been discussed since the Budget we have agreed to provide Commonwealth fringe benefits to all these pensioners. The acid test will now apply to State governments to ensure that these pensioners are not discriminated against and that they receive the motor vehicle driver's licence, electricity and council rate concessions, for example, which are provided to other pensioners and should be provided to these pensioners as well.

I am sure Mr Alf Garland, the National President of the RSL, who is in the gallery tonight, would be very keen to ensure that all service pensioners receive the fringe benefits to which they are entitled and that we do not have a two-tier system where some service pensioners receive full concessions and another category of service pensioners do not receive full concessions from State governments. I hope that is a principle which the various State governments around the country can adopt very quickly, because from 1 April next year the new fringe benefits cards will be provided to service pensioners and aged pensioners. I hope by that time all State governments will have ensured that all pensioners receiving those Commonwealth fringe benefits will get all the State fringe benefits as well.

Finally, in the few minutes left to me I wish to take up one issue on behalf of a former member of this House, Mr Michael Maher, the former member for Lowe, who was highly regarded on both sides of this House for his integrity and the concern he had for his constituents on public transport issues and the rights of veterans, among other things that he raised in this House over many years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bus stops.

—I did mention public transport issues. I might need to make it clearer so that the Leader of the National Party understands it. But, yes, he was known in some quarters as a member who worked very hard for his constituents on all of the things that were of concern to them. One thing which Michael Maher has sought to do for people who live in his former electorate is to help veterans who have claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs.

PARA.TAB: In a recent conversation with Michael Maher I learned that, because he is a lawyer, he is disqualified from appearing free of charge for friends or former constituents at the VRB to help to ensure that they get a fair go in the VRB hearing. I quite understand why the Government believes that lawyers appearing for a fee should not appear before the VRB. We do not want to have a situation where all the legal argument that takes place in other tribunals in veterans' affairs starts to seep into the Veterans' Review Board.

I believe that the ban on lawyers receiving a fee should continue, but I believe that if a lawyer such as Michael Maher is seeking to help a friend or former constituent free of charge he should be allowed to do so. Perhaps that will be addressed in legislation which might be brought before this House in years to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a very brief intervention in this debate to further express the bipartisan support to which the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) referred. It is most important that our veterans receive a fair go and perhaps an overly fair go, as I think the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) put it.

PARA.TAB: In noting this so-called Bushell legislation when it came out, it struck me that from the High Court we have had a bit of robust Australian rough justice here. Here was a situation of a veteran who had long been denied justice, and the essence of the finding—and I do not profess to be a lawyer or even to have mastered this very long and difficult judgment—was not that a `reasonable hypothesis' was no longer required, but if one acceptable expert put forward a reasonable hypothesis linking the service to the disability, then that should not be overruled by any large number of other `experts'. Without pressing that any further, it seems to me also to touch on the situation of constituents of mine, Mr and Mrs A.J. Gellately.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Nehl)—Order! The time allotted for the remaining stages of this Bill has now expired. The question is that the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the remaining stages of the Bill be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.
Debate resumed from 4 November, on motion by Mr Humphreys:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take up the case of this veteran, Mr A. J. Gellately. This is not a pension matter; it is a matter in relation to defence service homes. I am not quite sure of the purview of this legislation, but I have been pursuing the case of this veteran ever since the devastating storm in the Wahroonga area in Sydney in January of last year. In effect, it almost boils down to one expert—and one initially nominated by the Department of Veterans' Affairs—taking a view on one side and the Department making an offer to this veteran, and then subsequently withdrawing it on obtaining another expert's opinion on the other side.

PARA.TAB: It did seem to me that there is a great difficulty in that situation and that this bit, as I referred to it a moment ago, of robust justice from the High Court might engender a more reasonable view on that matter. I will leave my intervention at that point, but I do press the Opposition case that as this matter is so important it must be referred, as is proposed, to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I take this opportunity to thank the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) for his contribution and for accepting the Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill. I would also like to thank the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Harry Edwards), who has been putting a case to me for quite a while in relation to defence service housing. I especially thank the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee), who makes many representations to me on behalf of the veterans in his electorate.

PARA.TAB: I know the concerns stressed by the Leader of the National Party, the honourable member for Dobell and also the RSL and other veterans organisations in relation to this legislation. I am glad to see that the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Bill (No. 2) has been accepted and note that there are concerns with the other parts of the legislation in relation to the Bushell case.

All we are trying to do, as was stipulated in my second reading speech, is go back to the original intent. I remind the National President of the RSL, Senator Newman and honourable members with an interest in this evening's debate that we have the runs on the board in terms of trying to maintain the meaning of the Veterans' Entitlements Act. I stipulate the Federal case in which three Federal Court judges found that once one reaches the age of 65 one is no longer totally and permanently incapacitated and that one should no longer have a TPI pension.

No complaints were made when we in this Parliament went back to the intent of the law and legislated to make sure that, once a TPI was granted, it was granted for the whole of a person's life unless there was fraud or unless that person became better. I want to make sure that everybody understands that we are fair dinkum as far as the veterans are concerned. On both sides of the House we all appreciate that in Australia we have the best repatriation system in the world. There is none better. That is not to say that we cannot make it better where we should, and we will continue to do that.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Truss)—Order! The time allotted for the remaining stages of the Bill has expired. The question is that the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question now is that the remaining stages of the Bill be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that it is the wish of the House to debate this order of the day concurrently with orders of the day Nos 13, 14 and 15.

PARA.TAB: Mr Lloyd—It is not the wish of this side of the House, Mr Deputy Speaker.

TALK.START.PARA: —There being no objection, the Chair will allow that course to be followed.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LLOYD
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The States Grants (Rural Adjustment) Amendment Bill, the Farm Household Support Bill and the Income Equalisation Deposit Laws Amendment Bill are each major Bills in themselves. It is rather absurd that they should all be here together in the early hours of the morning only a few days after they were introduced. That is the state of the Government and the way it introduces legislation into this place.
—Positively a machine legislative process.

—That is a very accurate comment. When one looks at these in total, I think it is logical to start with the income equalisation deposit scheme because the better the IED scheme, the less need there is for a rural adjustment scheme. One of the major criticisms that we have had of the Government in this whole area is that it basically ruined the IED scheme that we had put in place. In the 1970s, it started off with the drought bond scheme from the 1960s. It made changes in the mid-1980s on coming into government; it recognised the failure of that a couple of years ago by changing the scheme, but once again did not allow the scheme to operate properly. Remember that the purpose of the scheme is to encourage farmers to self-insure so that they can put money aside in good income years and take it out in years when there is a natural disaster of some form or for some other reason. There has to be an incentive for them to do that. The Government removed that incentive when it made those changes in the mid-1980s.

PARA.TAB: When it announced that it would be improving the scheme again, it gave 12 months notice before it commenced. Had the scheme been allowed to commence from the time of the Budget announcement, there would have been a considerable investment by wool industry people because at that time the reserve price was still in place. By deferring that introduction, the Government did very well with the provisional tax that came from the wool industry and also prevented considerable investment from the industry, which would have been to the value of those woolgrowers now and would have meant, of course, less call on the rural adjustment scheme.

The fact that we now have further changes to the scheme indicates that the Government has recognised the inadequacy of it. It has in fact brought in two schemes, including a farm management bond scheme as well. When one looks at the combination of the two schemes, the better elements of both could be the basis for a worthwhile scheme. First of all, if there is to be a worthwhile scheme, really there should be no withholding tax because the farmer has already paid provisional tax. In one of the two schemes, the withholding tax comes down to 20 per cent. Secondly, to be part of an incentive, there should be interest paid on as high a percentage of the investment as possible, of the deposit as possible, and that goes up to 80 per cent with one of the two.

There is also the recognition that if we are going to get more people to take on the scheme, we have to broaden the criteria. One of the two schemes reduces the minimum deposit to $1,000 and then lifts to $300,000. It has been suggested to me that $300,000 still does not take into account the big money we are talking about with the larger farmers, particularly the crop producers who require big amounts to be available to take on, if you like, a planting after a failed crop the year before.

The National Farmers Federation, in its recommendations for a worthwhile scheme, linked what it saw as reasonable criteria, and that is why the Government has the superannuation arrangements with payment on 85 per cent of interest. Of course, the NFF also makes the point very clearly that, if we are really going to encourage people to take part in it, there is no point having a withholding tax.

If there is to be a worthwhile scheme, those points all have do be taken into account. I remind honourable members of these three points: why should a farmer get interest on only 61 per cent of the money that he deposits in IEDs when his normal tax rate would almost certainly be less than 39 per cent; why should a farmer in a desperate situation such as a severe drought pay 20 per cent withholding tax when he draws out of either scheme, when he has already paid provisional tax; and why should a farmer who experiences a personal tragedy suffer a loss of interest on 19 per cent of his farm management bonds deposit because he draws out at a time that is not designated to be a drought or a serious natural event? If we are going to be serious about this, we have to take these into account. The coalition will be announcing its policy on income equalisation deposits in due course.

With rural adjustment, the proposals by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) in this legislation simplify the existing scheme by implementing a single interest rate subsidy scheme of up to 50 per cent subsidy on interest rate for those considered viable, and there is to be an additional interest rate subsidy in exceptional circumstances, such as severe drought, but the extent of that additional subsidy will depend on how much the States are prepared to provide. It seems to me that as usual the States are not prepared to provide too much. I believe that the States have not been as forthcoming in this scheme over the years as they should have been, and I do not say that as any criticism of the Minister about this scheme. I just think the States have not accepted their share of the responsibility.

What is a simplification of the scheme with a single interest rate subsidy type operation becomes complicated because the application of the household support component—that is, for those considered not viable—is transferred to the Department of Social Security and away from the State rural adjustment authority. Household support, as now has been put forward by the Minister, recognises the failure of the Government's previous attempts to tinker with the Job Search allowance. Honourable members will recall that in this place about 12 months ago 2,000 farm families, or farmers, were to become eligible. The rural sector said at least 5,000 needed to come within the criteria if it were really to make an impact. My understanding is that eventually only about 300 came within the scheme and it has been dropped.

I think it is sensible that it has been dropped because the Government has finally recognised what we recognised as far back as 1977; that is, when one is dealing with a self-employed group—in this case the farmers—the ordinary schemes for the salaried and wage earner sector do not fit for those who are in this separate sector. That is why we went to household support and away from unemployment benefit as long ago as 1977. Of course, in those days there was not even an assets test. Since then the assets test has come in to complicate, together with the work test, the applicability of the ordinary unemployment benefit or Job Search allowance to this high capital, self-employed sector of our society.

But, in general, the Minister's household support proposals move closer to the coalition policy and I think that is sensible. They provide some horizontal equity, if you like, between the self-employed sector and the salaried and wage earner sector by providing an income tested and off-farm asset tested equivalent for a nine-month period as a grant, provided that the farmer then leaves the farm. They also increase the rehabilitation grant to $45,000.

I commend the Minister for that because one of the real problems that a farmer faces in making that very hard decision as to whether or not to leave the farm property is the problem of a home for the family. This situation is quite different from a family living in a town or city where, generally speaking, the house is separate from the business and where there is still a market value for that house. In the farm situation it would generally be absorbed onto a neighbouring property. There would be no market value for that house for practical purposes and the farmer in that situation would have no ability to provide a home for the family somewhere else without this type of assistance. I believe that is a very realistic and sensible part of the total proposal.

However, there are some problems with the proposal. I am talking about rural adjustment and household support together because they have to be considered as two parts of the same problem. The first problem is that by having this separation it seems to me that a decision has to be made at a point in time as to the future of that farmer. It is as if the farmer goes up to a drafting gate and is immediately drafted as viable or non-viable. I do not believe that is a fair or realistic situation. If we are taking into account—as I understand the Government is in this scheme—a greater emphasis on productivity, how do we assess productivity in a drought if a farm is facing that situation at that time or if there is a downturn in commodity prices for the product which the farmer sells? How do we calculate at that time whether a farmer would have a viable future in 12 months time?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a long term assessment, not short term.

—The Government should accept that if the farmer is not accepted for an interest rate subsidy he is then shunted off to Social Security for household support. I do not believe that is a fair way in which to handle a farmer in that situation. He needs time to be able to work his way through that situation. The market or climatic situation which could help to determine his future may sort itself out.

PARA.TAB: That is why I believe the breathing space that the coalition policy provides—that is, a nine months income tested welfare grant equivalent to the Job Search allowance which is not conditional upon whether or not the farmer finally leaves or not; in fact it puts our original policy of many years ago back into place—is a far fairer, more sensible and more equitable approach.

The second problem concerns the splitting of two parts of the one problem between two different institutions—the State rural adjustment authorities and the Department of Social Security. I know that the State adjustment authorities are very happy about that because they have only the good news part. They will deal only with those people who will have viability positively determined and they can then work their way through the interest rate subsidy. I believe it is better if the farmer in this difficult situation remains with the one institution, irrespective of what part of the process he is finally placed in—whether it is viability and therefore he continues in farming, or non-viability and he is assisted out of farming. This is an area that I will be watching very closely in order to see whether it is working.

I have no confidence whatsoever in the Department of Social Security with regard to the farm sector. This attitude comes from fairly long and bitter experience over 20 years in parliament. I have been close to these particular problems of adjustment over these years, I have been very much a part of all the problems which have confronted farmers over those years and I have seen how they have been handled by different authorities. I hope that I am wrong on this occasion, but this Government's previous scheme with regard to social security was an abject failure. One can say that that is not the fault of Social Security; it is the fault of the Government. But the total result has not been of any value to the farm sector.

We have here a welfare equity situation which is of great concern. Farmers are in hardship situations with no real cash flow and there is a problem of putting food on the table at short notice and doing this in a way which does not prejudice them from day one with regard to their future decision making. I have many doubts about what is being proposed in this legislation.

The third problem concerns the drought aspect of the rural adjustment scheme. The Government has refused to implement the recommendations of the task force concerning incentives for drought proofing. It is allocating some money for management and so forth, but I say again that I do not know how someone from Brisbane, Canberra or wherever can go and talk to a Mallee farmer about risk management. I really find that laughable. I cannot think of any group of people who have had to adjust themselves to risk—climatic risk, market risk and so forth—more than people in some of our farming areas. They can be compared with people from secure employment situations who have no practical knowledge of what is confronting these people. But somehow or other as part of this scheme we will be improving the risk management of this group in our society—our farmers.

In the drought section of rural adjustment, the Minister has recognised that the Government cannot walk away completely from providing some assistance to States, and through the States to individuals, in times of severe drought. Hence there is the allocation of $14m to New South Wales and Queensland. But the Government has steadfastly refused to put severe drought back into the natural disaster arrangements. I believe that is a further weakness in the total scheme.

I acknowledge that an interest rate subsidy is a reasonable way of handling, at an individual farm level, the different problems that a farmer would face in working his way through a drought. But there is a budgetary limit each year on the rural adjustment scheme and that budgetary limit cannot handle the shock loading or the additional requirements of a severe drought coming on top of the ordinary adjustment requirements through the rural adjustment scheme. In fact, the Minister acknowledged that fact by way of the additional budgetary commitment of $14m. That is why the coalition will be putting severe drought—and I emphasise that it is only severe drought, not ordinary dry periods—back into the cooperative Federal-State natural disaster arrangements.

The coalition does not oppose the legislation. I believe the Minister is sincerely trying to overcome some of the problems that exist now and I commend him for the action he has taken. I doubt whether some of the changes in the legislation will work to the extent that he would hope they would work and believe that there will be a better way of handling this very difficult problem. Therefore, we will be monitoring the situation and, in government, changing the scheme where necessary and in line with the policies that we have announced over a period.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is worth noting that this legislation will pass through the House with the support of the Opposition. That is to be commended. I will not go through the detail of the legislation again. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) covered that adequately in his second reading speech. However, I would like to pick up on a few of the comments made by the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) and see whether we can clarify some of his points.

PARA.TAB: It is true that we have been dealing with modifications particularly to the rural adjustment scheme and income equalisation deposits for the whole term of this Government. There are reasons for that. I think the honourable member would understand that the starting point from which this consideration began was the scheme that had been left behind by the Opposition, a scheme that was being widely rorted through the farm sector. In my early years as a member of this Parliament and a member of the Prime Minister's country task force, we had a number of discussions with organisations such as the National Farmers Federation and it was conceded that the structures that were in place, left behind by the former Government, were a mess, along with all of its tax legislation. These were being widely rorted. It is true to say that in the initial clean-up this Government had to set in place some new basic parameters and to work through from there. Nobody could say anything other than that this Federal Labor Government has been very sensitive to these farm related income support issues during its term. That is worth noting and understanding.

It is also worth noting, as the honourable member for Murray did, that the States have not played the game when being given the rural adjustment scheme to administer on behalf of the Government. There have been a number of examples of the States taking grants and lending them to farmers with interest rate premiums added, and with quite strange judgments about viability. Overall they made it very difficult for the Federal Government to have a consistent and fair scheme in place.

I can remember that when the current Minister for Primary Industries and Energy took over that portfolio, at one of his very first meetings with the Caucus primary industry committee there was a discussion about the means by which we could make adjustments to household support for farmers and their families who were suffering difficulties. A number of modifications have been made since, on the Minister's initiative, to display that sensitivity. That is demonstrated most in the formal form of the Farm Household Support Bill, which is part of this package of legislation. We have reached the point where the Government is formally acknowledging the need to recognise farm household income as a special case and to deal with it as such.

Before going to the main point that I want to make—and that is, in a sense, contrasting the sensitivity of the Minister and the Government to perhaps the attitude of others—I would just like to pick up on the observation made by the honourable member for Murray about the Department of Social Security. In the last Parliament I had the role of chairing the Standing Committee on Community Affairs. One of that Committee's tasks was to do an analysis of the service provided by the Department of Social Security at the counter and office level. We found that the officers of the Department had great difficulty in dealing with these sorts of issues and particularly in dealing with the small business and farm sector.

Why is that? One of the reasons is that most income support structures—and these measure are the same, and so they should be—are based on trying to determine household net income after taking account of ordinary business expenses and the tax situation. Whenever farms are being dealt with, what we find is a broad range of, if I could use the term, corporate structures. We can have someone wander in who is still a sole proprietor but who might as well to all intents and purposes be an ordinary wage earner for this kind of treatment. We can have partnerships, trusts, family trusts and companies. We are entitled to ask ourselves: why are all these farm households structured in all these strange ways?

Of course there is a reason for that, and I do not need to explain it too broadly. But the simple fact is that these structures have been set up to maximise the use of whatever measures are around to reduce tax. So it becomes very difficult when, on the one hand, one is structuring one's family business in a way to minimise the income one earns in order to minimise the amount of tax one pays, but then, on the other hand, presenting to the Department of Social Security a measure that shows that that income really deserves more household income support. That is a very difficult situation for the Department of Social Security and the Government to work its way through.

I think the measures that have evolved during the last eight years have been honest attempts to meet those changing circumstances. I noticed, for instance, in the recent round of local government capital works that substantial amounts of funds were made available to rural councils to supplement the job programs that the honourable member for Murray mentioned. Again I commend the Minister for his heavy lobbying within the government process to ensure that these second incomes could be available to the farm sector. Because most farmers are in some corporate structure or other, it is very hard for them to be recognised as unemployed. So special treatment had to be made, it has been made and, again, the treatment has been sensitive.

While the honourable member for Murray may lack confidence in the Department of Social Security in its administration of these things, I would ask him to take note of the fact that the farm sector does present its affairs in a very difficult and technically structured way because of the various tax measures that it does its best to make the best use of—and that does make it difficult for the officers of the Department of Social Security.

Finally, I think there is a contrast here in sensitivity towards these issues. I want to make that contrast particularly in relation to the events that have occurred in Victoria today. Members of the National Party, in particular, wander around Australia telling country people that the Labor Party is totally uninterested in country areas, that it does not care about farmers, that it does not care about country people—and, in fact, I think the term that is most often used is that the Labor Party's interest ends at the end of the tram tracks in the city. Yet for the entire term of this Government, every attempt has been made to approach these issues sensitively and the legislation has continually reflected that, as does this legislation which we are debating tonight.

What has happened in Melbourne today? Following the change of government in Victoria, what has been the very first step taken by the new State Government, the Liberal-National Party coalition? Is it to sensitively address the issue of unemployment in the State? Is it to sensitively address the issue of workers and how incomes can be managed? No.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. We are dealing with narrow title Bills. I remind the House of the titles of those Bills: Rural Adjustment Bill, State Grants (Rural Adjustment) Amendment Bill, Farm Household Support Bill, Income Equalisation Deposits Laws Amendment Bill. They bear no relationship to what happened in Victoria today.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott)—There is no point of order. The honourable member for Burke is referring to the Government's participation in the rural community.

TALK.START.PARA: —All I would say to the honourable member is this—(Quorum formed) The sensitivity shown by the Labor Government in the Farm Household Support Bill to families who traditionally support the Liberals and Nationals I contrast with the attitude taken in Victoria today by the Liberal-National Government towards the workers of Victoria.

PARA.TAB: Here is a classic case. We have an Opposition in here which continually claims that the Labor Party and the Labor Government does not care about country people. For as long as I have been in this Parliament, we have spent time working on issues like rural adjustment and household income support for rural areas and we have continually failed to get any acknowledgment from the Opposition about these sorts of measures. We have continually heard the bleat that the Government and the Labor Party do not care about country people. As soon as we get a change of Government in Victoria—and all it is doing is reflecting the Opposition's policies, except it has brought them on a bit early—the first thing we see happen is an attack on the workers. The Victorian Government has not taken a sensitive approach to try to address incomes and income support; it does not have fair measures to deal with these things. There has been a straight out attack on the workers.

I am sorry that my colleagues have been disturbed from the other activities they were involved in around the House. My colleagues have been brought in here simply because the honourable member for Murray is a little embarrassed that I am able to say in this chamber that, for eight years, various Ministers—through the Prime Minister's country task force—one after the other have worked their way through these issues of household support for the farm sector, income equalisation deposits and rural adjustment schemes. They have sensitively helped families all across Australia. We find the contrast to that with this rhetoric that builds itself into a kind of a hatred and contempt for ordinary workers who can do nothing but defend themselves; they are not people who are in trusts, partnerships, companies, family trusts and all sorts of other tax measures. Some of my colleagues were not here before, but had they been they would have heard the honourable member for Murray say that he does not trust the Department of Social Security in its administration of these schemes. What he does not understand is that just about every farm household that comes along and presents for assistance presents with some kind of fancy corporate tax scheme aimed to reduce the tax that is paid.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is absolute rubbish.

—No, it is not rubbish. The honourable member for Murray should tell me the number of farms that are ordinary sole proprietorships, that have not already structured themselves to have one form of tax reduction.
—They have no taxable income anyway.
—Order! The honourable member for Murray will resume his seat and will cease interjecting.
—I ask the honourable member for Murray to tell me when that is the case.
—You don't know what you are talking about.
—I warn the honourable member for Murray.

—What is the case with ordinary workers? Why were these schemes in a mess? Those opposite will never talk about the reason they were in a mess. The rural adjustment scheme, the income equalisation deposits that we picked up on day one were left in an absolute mess by the Opposition. The National Farmers Federation admitted to us directly, `Yes, we agree it was rorted; yes, we agree you had to do something about it; yes, we agree that your initial legislation was not bad. Now what about finetuning it?'. That is what we have done year after year—finetune it sensitively. I just wish those opposite would ring up their Victorian colleagues and ask them to show the same sort of sensitivity to ordinary workers in Victoria that we have shown to these people all across Australia in our approach to these farm support Bills.

PARA.TAB: I am sorry that a quiet little discussion in the chamber with no opposition to the Bills was disrupted. The Opposition is not opposing these Bills; it is not calling divisions; it is supporting the legislation. That is evidence that the Government has gone about this matter sensitively, that the officers have been responsive to the issues that have been raised and that the Minister has brought forward legislation that genuinely reflects the changing income support needs of the rural sector. I commend the legislation. I commend the Minister and his Department on the work that they have done. I just regret that some of those on the other side of the House are not acknowledging that more specifically and, more importantly, are not encouraging their colleagues in Victoria to take a similar approach in dealing with the problems of all households.

TALK.START.PARA: —I regret that, even though we have such important Bills before the House which will affect my constituents in the drought ridden areas of my electorate very severely, we have only a matter of seconds to discuss the legislation before us because of the guillotine. It is typical of this Government; it sits on its hands throughout the year, then rams a stack of legislation through the House in the early hours of the morning, late in the session, and expects people to take it seriously.

PARA.TAB: That is what is happening here tonight. We have four Bills before us: three of them concerned with restructuring the rural adjustment scheme and one placed there to marginally improve the income equalisation deposits scheme. It gives me no pleasure at all that I, who will be representing 40 per cent of New South Wales under the new electoral boundaries, do not have a proper amount of time to discuss this legislation.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott)—Order! The time allotted for the remaining stages of the Bill has expired. The question is that the Bill now be read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question now is that the remaining stages of the Bill be agreed to.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.
Consideration resumed from 3 November, on motion by Mr Crean:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Motion (by Mr Crean) proposed:

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Bill be now read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because these Bills have been guillotined, it is necessary to be very brief in my remarks on the States Grants (Rural Adjustment) Amendment Bill 1992. There is a general concern in the community that the Government has inadequately responded to basic household support needs of the rural community. In the first place, the Government once boasted that its program to give cash strapped farmers access to unemployment benefits had been a turning point in rural household support. It is not and never was. The program is near to collapse.

PARA.TAB: The scheme had been designed to allow farmers to take up the Job Search allowance to see them through difficult times but official statistics show that the plan has essentially bombed. The Minister at the table, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean), will recall his prediction last October that some 2,000 farmers would be eligible for the allowance. Yet, by the first week of March 1992, only 42 farmers nationwide had received the granted assistance.

The reason for this is that the eligibility test for the scheme had been poorly designed and paid no regard to farmers' real circumstances. Unemployment benefits, as the Government ought to have realised, are inappropriate for self-employed, heavily capitalised farmers. They are frequently disqualified from obtaining assistance because of the assets tests, work tests and working capital limits which apply to Job Search allowances. As at March this year the rural adjustment authorities had received 321 applications for assessment for entry to the new unemployment scheme promoted so vigorously by the Government, but the Department of Social Security had only granted 42 new allowances to farmers across Australia. The stunningly low response rate reflects the difficulties in determining asset wealth for farmers. This has been cited over and over again as the main stumbling block for expanding the scheme.

The Government would have done better by farmers if it had adopted the income tested household support scheme of the National and Liberal parties. The scheme provides for non repayable direct assistance to struggling farmers and avoids the administrative nightmare which has sunk the Government's program. Rather than have farmers queue up for a battery of assets and other tests, a direct household support policy puts food on the table straightaway. That should have been the Government's priority but, instead, it has buried farmers in a bureaucratic quagmire at the time of their greatest needs.

Similarly, it has done the same to rural families seeking access to Austudy. What we want from the Government is not complicated rural policy, just plain commonsense. Many farm families suffer very serious hardship. They are unable to obtain any government assistance—that is, Austudy, family allowance or other household income entitlements—because they are subject to the assets test which is not in the least bit relevant to their present financial position.

This issue has been on the political agenda for years, but the Government has refused to give ground. In these circumstances, a simple income test is all that is needed. This would ensure that welfare goes directly to those in greatest need. The Government should drop the assets test altogether and rely on the National and Liberal parties' policy of direct household support.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Les Scott)—Order! The time allotted for the remaining stages of the Bill has expired. The question is that the Bill be now read a third time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a third time.
Debate resumed from 3 November, on motion by Mr Crean:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been discussing tonight—in three pieces of legislation before the House, including the Farm Household Support Bill—in a very shortened debate, the best way to assist farmers at this time of great hardship. We have spoken about household support and rural adjustment, but I also want to bring to the Government's attention yet again the impact of squeezing families out of the entitlements system because of the Government's approach to rural household support.

PARA.TAB: The plight of the Legge family was widely publicised through the pages of the Weekly Times in the middle of this year. Members of that family are known to me because they are my constituents and live in East Gippsland. Their story is very common throughout the rural community.

The Legge family run Australia's biggest Poll Dorset stud. It is called Ridgehaven. The Legges will have to borrow money to send their eldest daughter, Ruth, to the University of Melbourne next year. The reason for this is that the Legge's income is negative, but Ruth cannot qualify for Austudy because of the assets test. This is a story that anybody representing a rural electorate comes across on a daily or weekly basis at worst.

The Legge family has suffered more than its fair share of bad times. There was the drought of 1972, the cattle price collapse in 1974, fire in 1978 and flood in East Gippsland in 1990. Moreover, Mr Legge underwent a triple bypass heart operation very recently, and that cost the family approximately $15,000. During his stay in hospital away from the farm his wife and two eldest daughters helped to run the farm; the girls had to mix running the farm with their school work.

Although the Legges have pruned their debts and cut their running costs, the fact is that they still cannot afford, on their income alone, to send any of their children to tertiary education because they have a negative income. It is just tragic that people who have nothing to live on are being denied an entitlement that others, with at least an income, are entitled to.

There are many families in the same situation as the Legges. Because they are subject to this assets test which does not take into account income, they find themselves on the outer with regard to almost every government assistance entitlement.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
