TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 7 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 949 (Hansard, 8 October 1991, page 1481), did he say that Australian Defence Force (ADF) sniffer dogs were not used at the Hilton Hotel for bomb detection at any time and that the ADF did not have dogs in 1978 trained for that purpose.

(2) Did he say in an amendment to his answer to question No. 949, provided on 5 November 1991, that sniffer dogs trained for bomb detection were not used at the Hilton bombing scene before the explosion, since their use was not requested by the NSW police but that three sniffer dogs were used after the explosion to detect further bombs and that they were deployed by the ADF which did have such dogs available to it in 1978.

(3) Is he able to say whether TCN Channel 9 in Sydney televised a segment of news film on 6 June 1991 showing three men in uniform deploying three dogs during daylight hours near the entrance to the Hilton on a day preceding the explosion; if so, is he able to say, (a) who were the persons shown, (b) to which organisation they were attached, (c) if they were ADF personnel, to which unit they were attached, (d) what function they were performing, (e) what assistance the dogs provided in the performance of that function and (f) if the dogs were sniffer dogs being used to search for explosives.

(4) If the dogs referred to in part (3) were sniffer dogs trained to search for explosives, were they deployed to detect any bomb which might be placed at the Hilton before it exploded; if so, (a) can he say why was the bomb in the garbage bin outside the Hilton not detected, (b) on what days and at what times before the explosion were they deployed and (c) were sniffer dogs deployed by security forces at the Hilton at any time during the three days preceding the explosion; if so, in what areas and at what times; if not, why not.
(5) Were Commonwealth agencies used in the investigation of the bomb used at the Hilton.
(6) Who collected the physical evidence of the bomb at the scene.
(7) Who made the forensic examination of the bomb evidence.

(8) Were determinations made on the basis of forensic evidence as to (a) the nature of the explosive and (b) the type of bomb; if so, in each case, (i) what were the determinations and (ii) when were they made.
(9) If a forensic examination and determinations were not made, why not.
(10) Do Commonwealth agencies believe the explosive used was gelignite; if so, what was the basis for that belief.
(11) Is it a fact that (a) the bomb scene was not secured and (b) bomb evidence was swept up and disposed of by Sydney City Council staff.

(12) Has his attention been drawn to the 60 Minutes program televised on 14 July 1991 which dealt with the Hilton bombing and the references in that program to a former ASIO operative identified as "Ron"; if so, (a) is the person referred to a former ASIO operative who infiltrated the Ananda Marga, (b) was that person introduced to Crown Prosecutor Mark Tedeschi at Mr Tedeschi's chambers on 5 September 1989 by an ASIO officer to provide a statement and (c) did that person provide a statement to the Crown Prosecutor; if so, (i) what was the substance of the statement and (ii) did the person say to the Crown Prosecutor that he (A) was an ASIO operative, (B) undertook training in the use of explosives as part of his duties or (C) entered ASIO's service trained in the use of explosives.
(13) In 1978 did ASIO employ personnel trained in the use of explosives; if so, (a) how many and (b) for what purposes did ASIO need explosives-trained personnel.

(14) Did (a) ASIO or (b) Commonwealth Police personnel infiltrate the Ananda Marga and become members of it; if so, with respect to each organisation, (i) how many personnel were involved, (ii) when did they become involved, (iii) for how long were they involved and (iv) for what purpose were they involved.

(15) Did any ASIO operative or Commonwealth Police officer who infiltrated the Ananda Marga give evidence in any court proceedings or to any inquiry concerned with either the Hilton bombing or with any criminal charges or any convictions for crimes involving any Ananda Marga members; if so, (a) what evidence and (b) what proceedings; if not, why not.

(16) Has the Inspector-General of Security and Intelligence received a complaint concerning the failure of security and intelligence agencies to make personnel available to give evidence along the lines referred to in part (15); if so, (a) has the Inspector-General been requested to inquire into the circumstances of that alleged failure, and (b) will such an inquiry be conducted; if not, why not and (c) has he directed or otherwise prevented or discouraged the Inspector-General from conducting such an inquiry; if so, why.

(17) Has his attention been drawn to references in the 60 Minutes program televised on 14 July 1991 to a member of the Ananda Marga in 1978 known as "Abhiik" who spoke with an American accent; if so, (a) does he know the identity of Abhiik, (b) did Abhiik leave Australia after the bombing, (c) is he aware of Abhiik's whereabouts, (d) has Abhiik been located and interviewed in connection with the Hilton bombing; if so, what was the result and (e) has any Commonwealth or State agency sought to locate and interview Abhiik in connection with the Hilton bombing; if not, why not.
(18) Were ADF personnel assigned to any duties outside the George Street entrance to the Hilton; if so, (a) at what times were they assigned to that duty and (b) who were they.
(19) Were any ADF personnel rostered for duty in the same location in the hours preceding and at the time of the explosion; if so, who were they.

(20) Has the Commonwealth investigated whether any Commonwealth agency or personnel breached any obligation under the Crimes (Internationally Protected Persons) Act 1976 or the Public Order (Protection of Persons and Property) Act 1971 arising out of acts of commission or omission in connection with the explosion, deaths and injuries at the Hilton; if so, what was the conclusion; if not, why not.

(21) Has his attention been drawn to a letter dated 2 June 1983 from the former Attorney-General, Senator Gareth Evans, to Mr Terry Griffiths; if so, did Senator Evans state in that letter that (a) he had serious misgivings about a number of aspects of the Hilton bombing, (b) he accepted that the question of whether ASIO played any role in the incident was a matter which fell squarely within the Attorney-General's portfolio, (c) the terms of reference of the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies was sufficiently wide to permit discussion of these matters and (d) it was difficult for him to proceed with these matters until the Royal Commission had reported.
(22) Was the Royal Commission referred to in the letter from Senator Evans the Protective Security Review (PSR) conducted by Mr Justice Hope.

(23) Did any Commonwealth personnel give evidence to the PSR concerning their role and their agencies' roles in providing security for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting at the Hilton in 1978 or their knowledge, views or opinions concerning the Hilton bombing or any other matters related to those events; if so, (a) is he able to say what evidence; if not, why not, (b) will he make a transcript of the evidence available; if not, why not and (c) will he re-examine the evidence and take the matter further as proposed by the former Attorney-General; if not, why not.

(24) Did his predecessor in a letter of 17 August 1988 to solicitors acting for Mr Terry Griffiths and he in his answer to question No. 949 say that, if the NSW Government were to decide that there should be a further inquiry, the Commonwealth would co-operate fully; if so, does that undertaking still apply; if not, (a) why not and (b) what is the Commonwealth's current position.
(25) Has the NSW Attorney-General requested the opening of a joint Commonwealth-State inquiry into the Hilton bombing; if so, will he accede to that request; if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duffy The Hon M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the honourable member's question, I have arranged for research to be undertaken, with some difficulty and at considerable expense, into available sources of information about the Hilton bombing which occurred 14 years ago, when the Fraser Government was in office. As appropriate, I indicate in the following answers the source of advice to me about these matters:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. I said: "the Commonwealth Government understands that sniffer dogs were not used." I also said: "I understand that in 1978 the only sniffer dogs available in the Sydney region belonged to the Army and were trained for different and specifically military purposes."
(2) The account of what I said is partly correct. On 6 November 1991, I said:

ANSWER.PARA: "In view of information now available to me, this answer replaces that previously provided to Question 949 (House of Representatives Hansard of Tuesday 8 October 1991, at pages 1482-1485). My amended answer is as follows:

PARA.TAB: "(13) I am advised by the Defence Organisation that sniffer dogs were not used before the Hilton bombing, since their use was not requested by the New South Wales Police. As noted in the previous answer to question 5(e), the New South Wales Police were responsible for security outside the hotel. A Mine Dog Explosive Detection Team, consisting of three dogs, was employed after the Hilton bombing to search for any additional explosive devices. No such devices were found.

(3) TCN Channel 9 in Sydney did televise a segment of news film on 6 June 1991 showing men in uniform deploying dogs. I am advised by the Deputy Chief of the General Staff that, based on evidence from within the news film, the footage shows an Army Mine Dog Explosive Detection Team on the morning following the bombing. Evidence within the footage indicates that it was not taken on the day preceding the bombing. In relation to the other parts of this question, I am advised by the Deputy Chief of the General Staff as follows:
(a) Corporal Keith Burley and Sappers Mark Owen and Paul McEwen.
(b) They were an Army Mine Dog Explosive Detection Team.
(c) The School of Military Engineering, Casula, New South Wales.
(d) and (e) They were deploying dogs to search for any further explosive devices after the explosion.
(f) Yes.

(4) I am advised by the Deputy Chief of the General Staff that a thorough search of Army files has been conducted, and there is no evidence that Australian Defence Force sniffer dogs were deployed to search for a bomb outside the Hilton Hotel before the explosion. Details of deployment of the ADF sniffer dogs were given in the answer provided by the Minister for Defence to the honourable member's question No. 1240.

(5) Apart from the Defence involvement as outlined above, the Deputy Commissioner, Operations, of the Australian Federal Police has advised me that the bomb explosion outside the Hilton Hotel involved offences against the laws of the State of New South Wales. Responsibility tor the investigation of those offences rests primarily with the New South Wales Police. Neither the Australian Federal Police, nor its predecessor the Commonwealth Police, carried out investigations into the incident. The Commonwealth Police did, however, provide an officer to facilitate liaison at the Commonwealth level by the NSW police task force investigating the bombing.
I am also advised by the Director-General of Security that ASIO provided assistance to the New South Wales Police.
(6) to (11) As I have said in answer to (5) above, responsibility for the Hilton bombing investigation rested with the New South Wales Police.
(12) and (13) Consistent with the practice of successive federal Governments, I do not propose to confirm or deny matters which relate directly to ASIO's operations.

(14) and (15) Consistent with the practice of successive federal Governments, I do not propose to confirm or deny matters which may relate to any covert operational measures which might have been taken by federal agencies.

(16) The Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security received a complaint on 20 August 1991 that, on the basis that ASIO had informants in the Ananda Marga, it would have been in possession of vital information which would have been relevant to the investigation of the Hilton bombing.

As the events occurred before the commencement of the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security Act 1986, the Inspector-General, in accordance with that Act, sought my approval to undertake an inquiry into the complaint. I gave my approval to conduct an inquiry in so far as it involved matters relating to ASIO.
I am advised by the Inspector-General that he has commenced a full inquiry which, he anticipates, will take several more months to complete.
(a) I am advised by the Director-General of Security that Abhiik was the Sanskrit name adopted by David Hart, also known as Jason Hoffman Alexander, and that Alexander was born in the United States.

(b) I am advised by the Director-General of Security that Abhiik is believed to have made several overseas trips before leaving Australia in late 1979 or early 1980, and that he is believed to have last visited Australia in 1982.
(c) I am unaware of his whereabouts.
(d) & (e) I refer the honourable member to my answer to (5) above.

(18) I am advised by the Deputy Chief of the General Staff that a thorough search of Army files has been undertaken and that there is no indication that any ADF personnel were assigned to any duties outside the George Street entrance of the Hotel before the explosion. Details of deployment of the ADF sniffer dogs after the explosion were given in the answer provided by the Minister for Defence to the honourable member's question No. 1240. I am advised by the Deputy Chief of the General Staff that, apart from a Mine Dog Explosive Detection Team, an Explosive Ordnance Disposal Team and associated support personnel, there is no indication of any other deployment of ADF personnel in the vicinity of the Hilton Hotel after the explosion.

(19) I am advised by the Deputy Chief of the General Staff that a thorough search of Army files has been conducted, and there is no evidence that ADF personnel were rostered for duty in the same location in the hours preceding, or at the time of, the explosion.

(20) I have been advised by the Deputy Commissioner, Operations, of the Australian Federal Police that there is no record of any such investigation. As I have said in answer to (5) above, responsibility for the Hilton bombing investigation rested with the New South Wales Police. See also my answer to part 25.
(21) Yes, I have seen that letter.
(a) Yes.
(b) Yes.
(c) Yes.
(d) Yes.

(22) The reference was clearly not to the Protective Security Review (PSR), which was not a Royal Commission and which had reported by the date of Senator Evans' letter to Mr Griffiths. Senator Evans expressly referred to the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies (RCASIA) which reported in December 1984.

(23) The report of the PSR lists 26 submissions presented to it, most coming from people outside government. The PSR files, which are held in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, contain over 150 records of conversation held in association with the PSR of which some 60 were with Commonwealth personnel. A preliminary examination of this large number of documents reveals that few relate to the Hilton bombing, which is to be expected as the terms of reference of the PSR did not include an investigation of the bombing. In view of this, it is unlikely that major expenditure of time and resources on detailed research into the files will yield information pertinent to the matters which the honourable member has raised.

The honourable member's question mentions only the PSR. Nevertheless, I believe he may have had in mind the RCASIA and so, as I wish to be as forthcoming as possible in addressing the issues of interest to him, I add the following. An examination of the index of the Royal Commission's records (and there are over 800 files) revealed one file apparently relevant to the bombing. One document from that file has been passed to the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security in the context of the inquiry referred to in part 16 above.
(24) Yes. The undertaking still applies as I have made known to the former New South Wales Attorney-General in correspondence.

(25) The former Attorney-General of New South Wales requested a joint Commonwealth/New South Wales inquiry into the Hilton Hotel bombing. I did not accede to that request because, as the honourable member will see from the answers I have given above, the matter is primarily one for New South Wales. The arrangements in place in 1978 between the Commonwealth and New South Wales for the security of the Sydney CHOGRM made the physical security of the Hilton Hotel area a responsibility of New South Wales authorities. Also, the investigation of the incident, as a matter of criminal law enforcement, was and is a matter for New South Wales. Accordingly, it is clear that, if the New South Wales Government believes there is a need for further investigation into the bombing, or for investigation of its investigation so far, it has the power and responsibility to initiate any inquiry. The proper position for the Commonwealth is that, in the event that New South Wales, pursuant to its view of the matter, decides to initiate an inquiry, the Commonwealth will co-operate fully with it. That is the position which I have expressed previously, and which I now re-affirm.

The Government's position is based on its judgement that the information available at the moment does not warrant incurring the expense of a major new inquiry. Nevertheless, I assure the honourable member that, if any material were to be put before the Government which changed this situation, it would naturally be willing to reconsider its attitude to an inquiry. The Government has no conceivable interest in suppressing or frustrating any inquiry which would be likely to cast any light on the shocking events of 14 years ago.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 27 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: Has he recently advised the Attorney-General of New South Wales that the Commonwealth will cooperate in an inquiry into the Hilton bombing on condition that (a) certain evidence from Commonwealth sources will be made known only to the Commissioner of the inquiry and the bar table and (b) he would have the power to determine what evidence from the Commonwealth would be presented subject to this restriction; if so, (i) why is this conditional cooperation being sought and (ii) to what classes of evidence is the restriction to be applied.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the honourable member's question, I advise as follows:

PARA.TAB: When I wrote to the former Attorney-General of New South Wales, Mr Peter Collins, on 18 November 1991, I reiterated my undertaking that Commonwealth agencies would cooperate fully with any inquiry into the Hilton bombing that New South Wales initiates, and reminded him that, in the past, the Commonwealth has cooperated by making available, under agreed arrangements, sensitive information relevant to a State-initiated inquiry in this matter. Without wishing to be overly prescriptive as to the nature of any arrangements that may be appropriate for any new State inquiry into the Hilton bombing, the Commonwealth's position is that it stands willing to disclose any information relevant to a State inquiry into the bombing, subject to the need to ensure that national security considerations are not compromised. Access to some material may therefore need to be restricted in certain ways.

I also refer the honourable member to my answer to part 25 of his question No. 1189 in which I outline the Government's reasons for not participating in a joint inquiry with New South Wales and again affirm that the Commonwealth will cooperate fully with any inquiry the Government of New South Wales may establish.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Office of Multicultural Affairs: Access and Equity Plan

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 6 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does each Commonwealth department and agency produce an access and equity plan; if not, which departments and agencies produce them.
(2) Is the aim of each access and equity plan to evaluate the effectiveness of the Government's social justice strategy; if not, what is the aim of each plan.

(3) Was Ernst and Young paid $10 000 by the Office of Multicultural Affairs to examine the effectiveness and efficiency of the Government's strategy in achieving its objectives under the access and equity plan; if so, why.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Individual Commonwealth departments and agencies are not required to produce access and equity plans; the requirement is that plans be prepared on a portfolio by portfolio basis. In a small number of cases agencies have opted to prepare their own plan in addition to the portfolio plan.
There have been two rounds of access and equity plans. All portfolios met their commitment for first round plans, and the completion of all second round plans is expected by the end of this year.

(2) The aim of each access and equity plan is not to evaluate the effectiveness of the Government's social justice strategy. An access and equity plan is a 3-year forward planning mechanism used to address linguistic, cultural, racial and religious barriers that may impede access to programs and services by Australians of non-English speaking background and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples. It aims to ensure the equitable delivery of programs and services to all eligible Australians.

(3) Ernst and Young was paid $10 000 to prepare an analysis of data provided by departments and agencies on costs of the Government's Access and Equity Strategy and of effectiveness and efficiency in terms of the Strategy achieving its objectives.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 7 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Government funding research on the possible nomination of the Lake Condah region in southwest Victoria for World Heritage listing; if so, (a) what sum (i) was spent in 1991-92 and (ii) will be spent in 1992-93 and (b) under what programs are the funds being allocated.

(2) Is (a) the Victorian Government or (b) any private consultant a recipient of the funding referred to in part (1); if so, in each case, (i) who is the recipient, (ii) what sum (A) was received in 1991-92 and (B) will be received in 1992-93, (iii) what results have been obtained and (iv) which researchers have archaeological qualifications or training in or experience of searching for Aboriginal artefacts.

(3) Have any museums or university departments been involved in work undertaken at Lake Condah by her Department, private consultants or the Victorian Archaeological Survey; if so, (a) which museums or university departments, (b) what program did each participate in and (c) with what funds were they provided.
(4) Will Lake Condah be a priority project in 1992-93 for World Heritage listing.
(5) Will tourism benefit from World Heritage listing of Lake Condah; if so, (a) what is the expected benefit and (b) what studies have been conducted to examine the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (3) The Department of Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has not undertaken any work at Lake Condah, and I am not aware of any private consultants conducting research on the possible nomination of the Lake Condah region.

I am advised by the Victoria Archaeological Survey (VAS) that no museums or university departments have been involved in the work undertaken by the VAS at Lake Condah during its 1988-1992 project to assess the significance of this area.
(5) It is difficult to speculate at this stage whether there would be benefits for the tourism industry from the World Heritage listing of Lake Condah. No specific studies have been conducted.
